Pours dark brown with a 3 finger, dark khaki head that has great retention and leaves nice lacing. Aroma is roasted nuts, roast, sweet chocolate and and some light woody notes. Flavor is roasted nuts, bittersweet chocolate, toasted bread, hints of dark roast coffee, a touch of smoky char and a little woody hop to the finish. Palate is light to medium body with a slightly oily entry, dry finish and medium, but pretty sharp carbonation. This is a really solid porter, pretty standard flavor profile, but really well done, not too impressed with the mouthfeel.

12 oz bottle. Poured a brown/black with a small head. Aroma: understated smoke, deep roasted malts, chocolate. Taste carried out the nose but with a understated hop profile. Medium body. Good depth and balance. Overall: very good.

0.355l bottle @ Henrik, Bergen. Pours a near black body with a small, bubbling beige head. Really strong chocolate nose with good hints of coffee and roasted malts. Lively carbonation and medium-bodied. Roasted malts and lots of it! Explosion of milk-chocolate, some coffee and other roasted goodies. Really good, and Im impressed that this is only 6% abv.

12 oz bottle from Binnys...pours almost pure black with thin tan head; nose has hints of chocolate and coffee but not overpowering...more bitter (hmmmm...hops) than sweet.  Malty , full bodied..This one is a winner.

Large dense mocha colored head leaves good lacing atop a black body.  Big, roasty aroma with threads of chocolate, chicory and dried fruit.  Earthy flavors of the roasted malts are reminiscent of a hearty black bread washed down with a strong cup of coffee.  Aftertaste swings toward a bitter, hoppy, long lasting finish.   Mouthfeel is smooth, full bodied, moderately carbonated and delicious.

UPDATED: FEB 10, 2011 Aroma: caramel, bread, roasty, resin, floral

Appearence: red brown, hazy color, frothy head

Taste: dark sugars with balanced hops. Perfectly sweet and bitter.

Palate: medium everything. Slightly creamy. Not to carbonated. Long malty finish.

Great beer.

Bottle pours almost black with thin tan head.  Aroma roasted malts.  Taste predominantly roast with a prolonged roast finish.  Medium palate with slight carbonation.  Alcohol not evident.  Very slight hops, almost an afterthought.  A little better as it warms.

To me the roast dominates too much.  I couldnt appreciate the other flavors others noted.

12 fl oz bottle. Pours dark brown with a small chocolate brown head. Aroma is dark roasted malty, vague vanilla touch and slight acidic. Dark malty, hardroasted, mild sweetness and chocolate. Bitter and roasted malty finish.

clear very dark brown, smooth light brown head.
nice aroma of lots of coffee, chocolate, roasted grains and a hoppy herbal balance.
flavor is sweet roasted grains,  malts,  slight charchoal note. well balanced.

Bottle. Pours black with a dense tan head. The aroma is tobacco, hard roasted malt, dark ripe fruit and chocolate. The flavour is very roasted with some coffee and chocolate notes. Very powerful for the ABV. Long roasted finish. Quite creamy texture. Absolutely a great porter.

Pour is black with a small tan head which quickly diminishes. Nose has some resiny hop presence, as well as some chocolate and coffee notes. Taste is mostly the same with the roastiness coming through more in the end.
Dark pour with a brown head. Aroma is roasted malt, chocolate/cocoa. Taste is nice, roasted malt, little bitter chocolate. Creamy mouthfeel. Great lacing.

(Sample Date: 7/11/2010   Source:Other)   Burnt sugar, creosote, chocolate, coffee with floral resiny hops in aroma. Black with frothy tan head. Flavor of coffee and chocolate. High hop bitterness and a resiny floral hop flavor. Medium to full body and mouth feel.

Bottle from Ølbutikken.  Pours a very nice completely black with a frothy dark brown head that hangs on. The nose is extremely roasted and the coffee profile is up front. Behind the rostyness there is some faint sweet caramel notes and laqurice. The taste actually reminds me of how Guiness tasted years ago when served on tap in England. That impression with a shit load of coffee added describes is pretty well. The texture and body is medium with a long bitter finish where notes of chocolate reviels its selves. Good beer

355 ml bottle @ Patricks. Very dark brown, almost black body with a big, foamy beige head. Aroma is strong dark chocolate, malt, coffee and fruity hops. Very promising aroma, and the flavor deliver as expected as well. Dominating, rich chocolate  flavor with moderate roasted malt, coffee and hops. Well-made, delicious and tasty, quite impressive at less than 6% ABV.

Bottle 355ml @ Patricks Pub og Restaurant, Kristiansand
[Thanks to Beer2000] Pours black with a tan head. Aroma has notes of chocolate, coffee and burnt malt. Taste is medium sweet and light bitter. Body is medium to full, texture is oily, carbonation is soft.

Bottle @ Henrik, Bergen. Pours a deep brown, near-black body with a medium off-white head. Nose is licorice, molasses, chocolate and hints of yeast. Taste is chocolate and roasted malts with hints of licorice. A pretty nice porter, but a bit overrated in my opinion.

[email protected]/* <![CDATA[ */!function(t,e,r,n,c,a,p){try{t=document.currentScript||function(){for(t=document.getElementsByTagName('script'),e=t.length;e--;)if(t[e].getAttribute('data-cfhash'))return t[e]}();if(t&&(c=t.previousSibling)){p=t.parentNode;if(a=c.getAttribute('data-cfemail')){for(e='',r='0x'+a.substr(0,2)|0,n=2;a.length-n;n+=2)e+='%'+('0'+('0x'+a.substr(n,2)^r).toString(16)).slice(-2);p.replaceChild(document.createTextNode(decodeURIComponent(e)),c)}p.removeChild(t)}}catch(u){}}()/* ]]> */ .Pours black with a tan head.Aroma is chocolate, grains, hay, roasted malt and caramel.Flavor is sweet and chocolaty with some grainy notes.Medium body, average carbonation.Nice porter.
Bottle courtesy of beerman6686, thanks daniel.  A real solid porter.  Taste is dominated by bitter chocolate and dark malt.  Nicely balanced.

12oz bottle into a Portsmouth Brewery pint glass. Roasty malts, chocolate, metallic aroma. Opaque dark pour, small tan head, okay lacing. Tons of sweetness up front, but bitter middle and fairly long bitter finish. Toffee, semi-sweet chocolate, burnt malts. Medium bodied, creamy texture even with a more than average carbonation for a porter. Nice example of the style.
One of my favorite porters that I have come across. Its more malty than sweet. A little more dry than most porters but a keeper none the less.

Bottle at home - shared with Mette. Black - brown head. High malty, sweetness, roasted, nice burned, oiley notes, cocoa, chocolate, nice medium hoppy, light bitternrss, coffee notes. Very nice - high drinkability.

Purchased at Archer Liquors in Chicago, IL; enjoyed on New Years Eve day during a warm winter Chicago rainy day.  Appearance is an oil black with a large, frothy tan head.  Aroma of roasted malt and hops, not really apparent but also not faint.  Taste features huge chocolate and coffee notes, creamier than a lot of stouts Ive had, very much roasty and delicious.  Very much recommended.

[3504-20101204] Tap. Little roasted engine oil aroma. Dark brown black body with a medium-lasting creamy tan head and some spotted lacing. Bitter roast malt flavour has some coffee grounds. Full rough body. Rough and robust, good.
(@ Blue Monk, Buffalo, NY)
Pours black with a thin tan head.  Faint roasty cocoa aroma.  Medium body, prominent roasted malt and aggressive hopping.  Bitterness dominates the finish.

12 oz bottle. Pours black with a thin tan head. Nice roasted malt and coffee aroma. Good roasted malt and bitter chocolate flavors. A hint of fruit in there too. Body thickens up nicely as it warms. Good porter.

Thanks to iNBe for the trade. This was a nice porter. The first sips had a lot of coffee flavor but it almost was too aggressive. Tasted like the grounds a bit. I got busy doing something and came back to the beer after it had been sitting out for a while and the flavors had all mellowed very nicely and it was like drinking a different beer. Serving: Bottle
UPDATED: DEC 29, 2010 Poured very dark brown, almost black.  Pretty opaque for a porter.  Tan head.  Very nice chocolate aroma.  Taste is delicious: chocolate, toast, dry hop finish.  A great porter.

UPDATED: SEP 21, 2012 Cask? (GBBF2010) - shared by one of the UK RB crew - thanks!
7 Massively sweet chocolate raisin aroma - nice!
4 Cloudy red, no head (left).
5 Ug. Strong and aggressive taste compared to the aroma. Too burnt, too astringent
4 Smooth palate, carbonation low. Finish is nice and coffee-ey, but the late fnish is citrussy.
12 Pretty nice overall. The aroma wows you, but the taste is pretty damned offensive in comparison.
Rerate: 355ml bottle (Drink Shop, Tallinn) (7:5:7:4:13=3.7)
Looks great, black and a huge tight head. Aroma lovely and burnt, but soft about it. Taste more burnt, but not quite as astringent as the cask sample 2 years back, still a little harsh. All-in-all, I do like it, but its gone beyond my porter comfort zone. Once its warmed up a bit, it does mellow a little.

UPDATED: JAN 27, 2015 1/15 rerate.............I see other postive rates and the smutt Baltic porter is my favorite beer so had to retry bumped slightly from 3.1  but end of taste is too much - roasted charr bitterness. ...........................................ok, not near the top of my porter list - complex aroma with too much roasted and alcohol smell - same thing in the taste; its complex but not for me..

Bottle. Light to moderate malt notes of dark chocolate and mild coffee, light resin and leather for the hops and yeast, with background notes of charcoal, vanilla and cola. Head is small, creamy, light brown with good thick lacing and is mostly lasting. Color is very dark brown. Flavor starts lightly sweet and moderately acidic, then finishes lightly to moderately acidic and  moderately bitter. Palate is medium, between watery and creamy in texture and has a soft to lively carbonation and a dry finish. Fairly light aromas are more than made up for by the "Robust" flavors in this Porter. As bold as it is, it is very easy to drink.

2010-12-04. Black body with a small creamy brown head. Dry toasty roasty aroma, light coffee overtones that grow more roasty as it goes on. 7+ Flavour is similar with a dry roasty character up front, a sweet dark base hat keeps it from being too dry. Light bitterness throughout. 7+ Smooth medium bodied palate. 3+ A very well made porter, simple, but a bit too heavy on the roast for my own taste. On tap at Blue Monk, Buffalo

A: The pour is a dark brown color, almost cola, with reddish highlights and a thin tan head.

S: A nice roasty nose with a slight creaminess. Some good coffee aromas along with bitter, dark chocolates. Really simple but its quite pleasant.

T: Theres a moderate bitterness to this beer that I wasnt fully expecting. Lots of roasted malts and bitter chocolate to go with a moderate coffee note. Theres a bit of vanilla that creeps in and provides some creaminess and sweetness that I was surprised by.

M: The body is probably a bit thin, with a medium level of carbonation.

D: The beer is pretty good, but a little on the bitter and thin side. I can get past it though, and I liked this one a fair amount.

12 oz bottle. Pours nearly black with a creamy light tan head. Aroma is very nice toasty rich chocolate cocoa dark  and a touch burnt toasty and nutty. Flavor starts with a soft creamy roasted malt chocolate note before gaining some sweet cocoa powder and a nice candied nut note. Finishes a touch bitter and coffee notes. Medium to medium full creamy body with a softer carbonation. Excellent warming porter on a snowy cold Chicago day
12oz bottle pours black with brown head.  Aromas of toasted malt coffee and bitter chocolate. Taste is bitter with a bit of hop resin. Body is medium full almost creamy.

12 oz bottle from Archers. Aroma is roasty chocolate malt, cream and hops. Pours black with a big foamy head and great lacing. Flavor matches aroma. Palate is a little thin but otherwise quite good. Not a bad tasting porter.
coffee, caramel aroma. pours black/brown, lacy head. taste roasty caramel and malt, nice amount of bitterness. goodbalance. not overly sweet. better than fullers imho.

Appearance: Pours a dark brown with a frothy creamy tan head. Leaves behind spotty lacing.

Aroma: Roast, herbal hops, coffee.

Taste: Dry ,roasted malt,spicy hops, mineral supplements, black coffee, ash. Finishes bitter and spicy.

Mouthfeel: Slightly foamy, full bodied.

Overall: Flavorful full bodied dry porter.

pretty much true to the commercial description..aroma of cramel and toasty and roasty and burnt maltiness you can decipher chocolatey scent in there too as well as very slight hops..dark brown to black appearance with tanhead some lacing..taste is again burnt maltiness,chcocolate,coffee,spice and slight tingly hop flavor with lingering aftertaste flavor changes more towards the roasty malts and chocolate as it warms hops and spice in the middle ...aftertaste has return of the maltiness with again a very slight bitterness..overall very good to excellent and reasonably priced so cant really find much to complain about except maybe could be even better at like 8 %abv
Pours black brown with tan head and lacing. Mild aromas of coffe and chocolate with a rich but not heavy palate. Very good.

When an American brewer uses a term to strong, robust in this case, it usually means to prepare for a monster. That is not the case here and this is of relatively normal gravity for a porter of this country of origin and is rather good for a beer of any level of alcohol. The appearance is a nice, dark brown color. The head is small and tan and the lacing spotty. The nose is rich and roasty. It is mostly coffee w/ a maltiness that implies a bit of sweetness. The beer is only a tad sweet though, just enough to bring out some rich chocolate and mocha overtones. It is medium bodied w/ very reserved carbonation, which works quite well for the style. A mild earthy bitterness rounds things out in the finish. This is a nice beer, it is not strong but fully flavored. There are better porters out there of both higher and lower gravity but this at the level where if Im in the mood for a porter, it will always do just fine.
This is one of my favorites!  Not too malty with lots of dry bite and good coffee flavors.  Easy to get through one or many more.
Very robust actually. Has a hard and strong flavor too it. Not for amateur beer drinkers or Budweiser fans.

Pours a deep black with a medium to large tan head with lots of intricate lacing. The aroma is an enjoyable interplay between coffee and tastiness, sweet floral and citrus rind hoppiness, and a mild sweet molasses character. There is a faint bit of resin in the aroma as well that shows its self later on. The flavor has plenty of roasty bitterness and bright hop presence. There are deep notes of vanilla and charred oak and a bit of licorice and berry as it warms. There is a little water like cleanness mid palate which is really weird and provides the only lack luster character of the beer. The beer finishes with an almost burnt bitterness. The palate displays a pleasant carbonation and is a bit slick but has a decided smoothness to it. Really a very tasty beer.

On tap at the Bavarian Lodge.  Pours deep brown with a thick and foamy medium tan head.  Very nice lacing.  Nose is full of roasted coffee and bitter chocolate.  Taste is similar and earthy with some malt.  Medium bodied and lingering coffee flavor.  Not my favorite style, but this is a very good showing.

It took me quite a while to learn to appreciate stouts, porters might take a bit less time.  Pours very, very dark brown with a small head.  Coffee and a bit of dark chocolate aroma.  Taste is toasted malt and coffee to start (the coffee sticks around a long time) followed by quite a bit of hop bitterness.  Creamy mouthfeel, seems pretty well carbonated.  Its OK, but Im still getting acquainted with porters.

Black with fair, creamy, tan head / Nose of coffee, caramel, and vanilla / Medium body, some acidity, with good balance and toasty, dry, finish / Flavors of dark roast coffee and cigar box with notes of prunes and caramel /

From the bottle with a nice calzone dinner. Some nice smoky, caramel, maybe even coffee malts. I found myself drinking it and finishing it before my dinner was at the table. Very nice porter from Smutty. Even if the cashier thought I was being gross when I asked for a "Smutty Porter".

Truly an outstanding representation of the style here.  Chocolate and coffee flavors blend well with the smokiness.  Touch of hops to add in a trace of bitterness.  Medium to thick mouthfeel, very low bitterness, really distinct flavors.  This is quite possibly my favorite porter out there

Pours a deep, dark mahogany brown, almost black, with a small, tan head.  Nose isnt overly powerful, but is mostly roasted malt and espresso.  Reminds me a bit of walking into a coffee shop.  Flavor is bitter espresso with a bit of sweetness in the background, and some smoke on the finish.  Really, really nice beer, and this from a guy who prefers stouts.

Bottle.  Pours black with a little more head than I was expecting.  Aroma is chocolate; flavor is chocolate backed up with a little hop bitterness.  Very solid and enjoyable beer, but not outstanding.

Black colored with little brown head. Smooth coffee aroma with dominating chocolate, roastiness and dry piny hops. Medium bodied. Flavor is also dominated by dark coffee and chocolate, some bitter hops also here. Aftertaste dries strongly with some pine still.

Bottle. Pours with a black body and a dark brown creamy head. Sweet malts dominate the aroma. Dark chocolate, dark roast coffee and oat notes from the malts and a slight grass hops bite. Very tasty, but a bit on the watery side. A good porter for big eating.

Bottle 33cl @ mondial de la bière. A dark beer with medium head. Smell is nice very roasted and smooth. Aroma is properly roasted and toasted, quite dry, good and creamy, heavy roasted notes at the finish. A nice porter, easy drinkable, nice.
Dark, roasty, chocolaty, and malty. Very full and toasty. A nice porter. One to be savored, not chugged.

12oz bottle. Clean pour into my Cigar City snifter. Thin, beige bubbly head, but quickly fades and disappears. The aroma isnt super strong, but I got hints of dark chocolate  and coffee. The taste is just like  the  aroma, chocolate, coffee, and barley. Good amount of  carbonation. Very tasty.
chocolate (roasted) bitter coffee and hops in the aroma and flavor. looks dark as a stout. very aromatic and robust for a 5.7% beer. not surprised, but very pleased

Bottle best by feb 11.  This is quite a nice beer, a little rough, but its a porter so thats okay.  Pours a nice dark shiny dark chocolate color with a sticky sudsy fine frothy khaki head.  Aroma of lots of chocolate and balanced crunchy coffee and roast, hint of burnt coffee, piney hops, smooth and rich, warming alcohol.  Flavor follows, rough combo of roast and plenty of chocolate, dark and milk, nice roast acidity, piney hops leave a nice tingle on the finish with a bitter piney punch, some citrus hops too it seems in the front, lasting bitter coffee and milk chocolate aftertaste, wonderful, not quite Founders though!  Medium/full bodied, creamy with not sharp sizzling carbonation, the fresh hops really add to the crispness, nice finish, clean but definitely leaving some goop in the corners of my lips.

12 oz. bottle from Soho Organic Market.  Pours dark brown with a thin khaki head.  Coffee and dark chocolate aromas with light floral hops.  The flavor is smoky, rich, and "robust" with obvious coffee and chocolate.  This is exactly what I hope for in a porter.  Near the top of its class.
Pours black with fair head.  Aroma of chocolate and coffee.  Flavor is the same, plus bitterness.  Great porter.  Could be even better with higher abv and more complex taste.
UPDATED: DEC 11, 2014 The taste is coffee and chocolate with a pretty bitter aftertaste. I prefer this type of beer with less bitterness.
Bottle. Rich malt, creamy, bitter chocolate,  bittersweet finish. Well balanced hops, very nice palate.  Surprisingly full bodied and full flavored, a superior porter.

Opaque black pour with a dense tan head that leaves pretty good lacing. . Lots of coffee up front in the nose. Some roasted malts and chocolate, maybe just a slight hint of flowery hops. Flavor is more chocolatey, but the coffee does come through at the end of the sip. Slightly bitter finish that fades quickly. Nice medium body, perhaps a touch too much carbonation. Im not usually a big fan of non-imperial stouts and porters, but I found this to be surprisingly enjoyable. Color me impressed.

Very dark for the abv. Some dark ruby brown highlights show up when held to the light. Big head of craggy foam. Khaki-colored.  The aroma is quite weak compared to the taste. Theres some dark chocolate, but it also gets a touch of cola. Mostly just sugary malt. Huge coffee and dark chocolate flavors in the taste. Lots of roast. Less harsh than Id expect - the mouthfeel helps there. Mildly sweet cocoa finish. It packs a ton of flavor. Marvelously thick and creamy. A pillow of roasted malt. This beer drinks much bigger than it is, almost to the point of tiring my palate. Its good, but it would be a bit much to drink for an entire night.
Really nothing wrong with this porter at all. Straight forward robust and tasty. Nice change after all those IPAs that Ive been drinking.
bottle pours black with a medium dark tan head.  Aroma is coffee and mollasis.  Flavor is very rich.  Roasted malt, evergreen hops, robust coffee and bitter cocoa.  Very nice.

Wowee, what a porter of porters!  Pours a deep black with a light brown head.  Aroma is fantastic: roasted coffee, toast, dark chocolate. Perhaps the most perfectly hopped porter I ever tried, ending with a bitter finish that tames the initial sweetness.  Just a shame it isnt available in my dang area, so thanks to my friend for bagging one in Cali.

pours dark brown with a light brown head and some lacing. aroma is bitter sweet chocolate and some light hop notes.  taste is strong and full of chocolate, hops and a tad of alcohol.  finish is warming and a bit sweet.  This is a very hearty porter.  Kudos.

12oz. bottle poured into shaker. Pours very dark brown with a fluffy tan head. Aroma is of chocolate, oatmeal, wheat, some caramel. Very dark porter, true to the style. Reminds me of an oatmeal stout I had in the past. This beer does come across as a stout and tastes very similar. Not the best porter Ive ever had but a damn good one. 16/20
Dark, thick and lovely....  Im so happy that Lighthouse has started to carry beers from this brewer.  Not overwhelming and just right for a porter. I would recommend to my close friends :)

Cask at GBBF 2010. A deep brown/black coloured pour with a medium beige head on top. Roasty aroma. Tastes roasty, malty, sweet, coffee, chocolate, slight sourness. Decent rich tasting porter from a quality brewery.
On draught at GBBF 10. Very dark brown with a tan head. Vanilla, chocolate, roasted malts and sweet spice nose. Caramel, wood, licorice and raisin flavours. Hoppy feel. Bitter,dry finish.

Pours a super dark brown that is for all intents and purposes black. Dark tan head dissipates to leave plenty of lace on the glass. Aroma is a light roasted chocolate malty essence but is not strong. Flavor is something this beer has a surplus of. The taste is a juiced up version of the aroma with a little bit of hop bitter way at the end. Good porter, but the baltic is where its at.
Burst of flavor, more than a typical porter. Lots of dark forest fruit, coffee and chocolate, nutty and roasted malt, and even a great bit of sour. A porter I will come back to.

Black coloured beer with a small brown head. Robust chocolate malty and light roasted aroma. Full creamy palate. FInish is bitter malty roasted with a strong bitter coffee malty ending. Not a bad porter.
1 year old bottle. Big and flavorful, with chocolate, some coffee, and a fruity, sour edge with blackberries. Smooth and creamy, not too heavy. An excellent porter.

On tap at Novare Res Bier Cafe in Portland ME. Black pour with velvety brown head. Aroma is mainly roastiness, burnt toast and coffee, some dark chocolate and raisins. Taste is sweet and malty, with a good bitter roasted coffee-like finale. Medium-long mouthfeel, rich on the palate. A bit heavy overall.

Dark brown with a very small beige foamy head. The aroma is roasted malts and coffee. Strong roasted malts, roasted coffee grains, black bitter chocolate, and dark fruit flavors. Very smooth with a long lasting burnt finish. Smoky, dry, delicious. Solid and tasty.

Bottle from Half Time. Pours a blackish ruby with a sheeting, 4 finger foamy tan head. Smells like chocolate. Medium body with watery carbonation. Flavor is chocolate and smooth burnt malt. Some coffeeish bitter comes along through the finish. This is a really good porter.

Small tan head. Malty, chocolaty, and roasted aroma. Smooth, rich flavors envelop your mouth after tasting this Robust Porter. Finishes with a hoppy, coffee, and chocolaty burst. Nice solid (and bold) porter!

Bottle.  Pours a dark brown to almost black with a head that lingers then fades away.  Aroma has some earthy tones to it, some chocolate too.  Taste is also chocolatey, mouthfeel a bit thin but it finished nice and dry.  One of the better porters I have tried albeit its not my favorite of styles.

Bottle pour.  I forgot how good a porter could be.  Pours black with a tan head, 1 finger, dissipating to a lacy film.  Coffee and chocolate nose, some licorice and raisin.  Flavor is big on coffee, with chocolate and a good bitter.  Rather astringent finish, mixing with the bitter and the chocolate sweetness.  This is good.  Another win from Smuttynose.

(12oz bottle thanks to Walt, vintage of at least several years old) clear espresso brown with very light bubbles. Nose of chocolate syrup and fudge. Smells delicious. Taste of fudge, semi-sweet chocolate, light metal. A light body with an excellent chocolaty duration. Slight oxidation, might be better slightly fresher.
Very great pour of dark chocolate and a dissipating head. Nose is unsweetened chocolate. Taste is consistent with that. Dryish finish. Rated 7/3/02

Pours dark brown with a brown head. Nose is roasted malts, caramel, coffee, vanilla. Taste is bitter coffee, caramel follows, and malty. Not too heavy bodied and pretty easy drinking. Roasty finish is awesome.
From a bottle poured a dark brown color with a fair amount of head.  Toasted malty flavor with a lasting aftertaste.
Very dark brown with a big brown head.  Aroma of roasted malts and a little coffee. Heavy sweetness, medium bitterness, medium body, average carbonation, long finish. Pretty good.

Bottle.  Pours dark red and appears black in the glass, with a medium brown head and some light tan lacing left behind.  Aroma is roasty chocolate malt, slight hops, sweet toffee and coffee, some earth, hazelnut, and wood.  Flavor is bitter roasted malt and hops, dark chocolate, and vanilla.  Bitter earthy aftertaste.  Very smooth and creamy, medium body.  This is really good.

12 oz bottle into pint glass
Pours like a cup of cofee but with a head which dissapates quickly, leaving a trail of thick lacing. Smell is of dark-roasted coffee and molasses.  Taste follows perfectly but with more, adding notes of dark chocolate, nuts with a slightly bitter finish.  Mouthfeel is on the heavier side but pleasant.  
This is a delicious porter and has moved among my favorites

Pours black with a very large off-white head that lasts for an obscene amount of time. Carbonation is very present and the lacing is outstanding. Aroma is of barley, coffee, caramel, kinda smoky as well. Taste is of heavy malts, with a smooth subtle aftertaste of flowery hops. I cant pick up the taste of alcohol at all, overall its a very good beer, great interpretation of the style.

Draft at redlight redlight.  Pours a dark opaque brown, almost black, with a good tan head and nice lace.  The nose is overwhelmingly roasted malts.  Very enticing.  Hints of vanilla and clotted cream.  A very bitter roasty flavor, which is quite nice.  Just a tad of a vanilla sweetness balances it out very well.  Good mouthfeel for a porter.  Not to thick and creamy, but definitely not thin either.  This beer is an excellent example of its style.

12 oz from variety pk. Very dark brown with not to much of a laced head. Aromas of coffee, caramel, cocoa, chocolate, wood, olives, touch a whiskey, slight vanilla. Hearty flavors of hickory, wood, roasted malt like chocolate, caramel, and cocoa. Smooth, bitter , semi sweet, roasted malty finish. Delightfully pleasing. I do wish I had more of these.

A: Pours a dark brownish black with a solid brown head. Okay retention and some spotty lace.

S: Aromas of roasted malt, dark chocolate, coffee, and mild dark fruits.

T: Roasty for sure. Lots of coffee and chocolate. Not much sweetness going on here. Light floral hops in the finish.

M: Medium, solid carbonation.

Pours a very nice deep ruby with a healthy, dark brown head that is slightly rocky, has good retention and fair lacing. Looks great- bubbles are a little big and carbonation a little high. A bit of poopy diaper in the nose, roasted malt, sweet doppelbock raisin notes. Taste is a little harsh: ashy, toasty but eventually some nice smooth vanilla comes through. Still pretty mediocre.

pours a deep black with a nice and frothy tan head.  Really a great porter with a malty taste.

12 oz. bottle

Pours a dark black with tan head. Aroma is of coffee, chocolate and caramel. Taste is of mocha, bit of bitter chocolate and some caramel. Palate is quite nice. Overall a very good porter that has a nice blend of chocolate, coffee, caramel flavor and bitterness without one dominating the others.
coffee, chocolate aroma.  Dark tan head, Deep brown / black color (very good appearance overall). Medium body, creamy, soft carbonation.  Nice finish.  Strong coffee for a porter.

This was awesome, a dark brown brew which forms a nice, tan head when poured. Smells of coffee/smoke. The taste is of bitter chocolate and coffee with some caramel notes. What is great about this beer is how smooth it goes down, very easy to drink. I had two of these in about ten minutes, ten awesome minutes. I am definitely buying more of these.

Pours a black color with a medium head.  Aroma of chocolate and coffee, hint of caramel.  You really get hit with charcoal and licorice on the intial swig.  Has some hidden bitter.  But the charcoal overpowers for me.  A bit dry too.

UPDATED: APR 1, 2015 Pours opaque black with a very creamy head. Smells of raisins, chocolate and coffee. Tastes of roated malt, coffee and chocolate, but with minimal bitterness. A good beer, but not terribly exciting.

Bottle.  Pours an opaque deep brown with a medium thickness amber-brown head with some retention.  Fresh-smelling spring-leafy aroma with deep malt overtones and slight scent of wood.  Light in body with a chocolate malt flavor that finishes with medium sweetness and ample bitter.  Overall a decent porter, but needs more body.
bottle, black pour with a touch of bubbly tan foam, aroma has a lot of creamy vanilla and coffee,flavors of coffee, malt, pecan shells, dry finisher

Nose of chocolate malts, roasted malts, light to medium sweet, medium coffee notes. Balanced nice nose. Pours almost black with some cola hies. A nice tan head and super sticky lace. Chocolatey malts with nice dark roast notes. Soft dark fruity sweetness with mild dry earthy notes in the finish. Roasted malts linger in finish. Very well balanced, nice body. Very well done.

Frankly, theres little to add that already hasnt been said. If you like  full-flavored porters or stouts, this is a very good beer. Not as sweet as some traditional English porters, it strikes a nearly perfect balance between bitterness and sweetness and between thin-body and full-body. Its the best American porter Ive tasted from the American east coast.

Smuttynose. need I say more?

A- poured dark, nearly stout like. little tan head that is gone within a few minutes.
S- once again, this is a hard category for me because I dont really nose very well. but I can whiff some maltyness in there. 
T- Nice malty taste. I taste some dry malt character, little nuttyness, and I dig it. I knew Smuttynose would do this one right. It seems to me they have an English flavor anyway, so this one seemed to be right on. 
M- good carbonation, balanced well. 
D- not a heavy beer. I could drink more!

-Bye

In the bottle at the Brickskeller. Pours black with a cascading dark brown head. Huge sustaining head thats very fluffy. Big roasted coffee aroma, smoked salmon taste. Somewhat of a creamy body. Good moderate roastedness. Slight up-front milk sourness. "you know your beer is roasted when your pee smells like coffee." - P-man
Nice taste. Something a little odd about the taste but I could not place it. A small aftertaste maybe.

From a trade via "The Wheelman". Thanks.  This poured from the 12 oz bottle an opaque black with nice foamy light brown head. Nose of dried fruits and roasted malt. Medium body and decent mouthfeel. The flavor is chocolate and coffee with a dry roasted malt notes and some malty bitterness.  Quite tasty.

Nice porter that I will say from the start has excellent head retention.  Great lacing on the glass.  More of a full bodied beer.  Vanilla bean, cream, coffee, chocolate, roasted malts in the aroma.  Extremely smooth mouth feel. Coffee and chocolate mix very well.  Vanilla flavors seem to be sticking around nicely.  Great porter.
very nice strong flavored porter, deep ruby brown color, no head but some lacing, chocolates and resins, some sour notes to help it to a clean finish

Pour is a dark with a tan head. The aroma has coffee with a bit of pine. Taste is a mixture of citrus like hops with a ton of coffee thrown in. Aftertaste has chocolate come through a bit more. Body is surprisingly medium/heavy, making this a nice american porter.

12oz Bottle: Pours dark ruby brown, a nice tan marshmallow head. Aroma is strong roasted coffee beans and dark chocolate. Great flavour with lots of roasty malts, dark roasted coffee and chocolate alongside some nice hoppy bittering. Really good.

Nice roasty aroma, with hints of cocoa.  Pours an opaque black, with a finger of tan head.  Theres a bit of hop bite in this one, which Im a fan of, but then its mellowed by roasted flavors, with hints of coffee and cocoa.  Nice full mouthfeel, and quite drinkable.  Im glad Smuttynose finally made its way into Ohio.

Pours dark brown to black with a tan head. The aroma is milk chocolate and roasted malt. The flavor is strong on the coffee and roasted malt. I didnt get much if any chocolate in the flavor. The beer has a creamy mouthfeel and low carbonation. This is exactly what I am looking for in a beer of this style.
scura discreta schiuma media persitenza naso di caffè in granio torrefatto intenso caffè medio amaro

Chocolate coffee and roast. An IPAs bitterness coupled with slippery malt. The chocolate malt melds brilliantly with the bittering hop.This is outstanding. I wouldnt expect anything less from the best brewery in New England. Robust indeed.

[Bottle] Pours a deep, clear brown with a small tan head that dissipates to a ring around the edge of the glass. Aroma initially is loaded with coffee, some chocolate, a touch of hops, and a bit of vanilla. Flavor is heavy on the dark roasted coffee notes, some hop bitterness, a good deal of astringency, and a strong lingering bitterness on the finish. Wow, this one is quite bitter towards the back end. Medium-light mouthfeel and light carbonation.

A: Poured with a spare, tan-colored head that dissipated quickly to a thin ring. Body is dark black and completely opaque.

S: Very nice aroma with lots of dark chocolate and a slight roasted twinge as well.

T: Lots of dark chocolate in the flavor, and some coffee is detectable as well. The finish is actually quite bitter, and has a fairly long duration.

M: Medium-to-full bodied, very creamy, with soft-average carbonation.

D: A really nice porter, and definitely lives up to the robust in its name. Another winner from Smuttynose.

Pours black with a strong tan head. Great lacing. Aroma is of coffee, chocolate, and some faint alcohol. First sip is pumpernickel, followed by coffee, and then an astringent bitter dry finish. Not bad.

Cask at GBBF 2009, 4th Aug 09. Pure black with some tan bubbles . Full, malty body with dark chocolate and burnt caramel. The aroma hints at the delights awaiting you within the glass. Smooth, drinkable palate but really you should take your time! Excellent dryness once the dark fruit and cocoa flavours pass. A great example of a porter.

UPDATED: FEB 13, 2011 bk-opq mhgy-tnt, bubbly-br-head, chunky lace, med-bod, ^co2.

caramel licorice sweet-malt aroma.

flavorful, citrus-hop T1, chocolate-malt charred T2, chrcl sour-citrus-bitter T3Tf.

hop bitterness is predominantly burnt-citrus-seed.
Pours dark brown with a soft white head.  Aromas of dark roasted mysteries including coffee and roasted malt.  Flavor is refreshing.  Coffee, chocolate, malt.
Bottle. Thick black pour, offwhite lacing. Toasty chocolate nose, more of the same on taste. medium body. Great beer.

Pours dark brown color with light brown head. Roasty aroma with a good amount of coffee and chocolate. Flavors of burnt malts and bittersweet chocolate with a slightly ashy finish.  Medium to full body with mild carbonation.

On tap at Tylers.  Poured dark amber/brown with a thick head that released a relatively lacking aroma compared to the taste.  There is a huge malted hop taste and a smooth dry finish of chocolate/mocha malts.  Nice session beer.

Pours a very dark black. Tan head a little foamy. Head dissipates quickly with no lacing. Nose is lacking a bit. A roasted character I guess. A little malt. Flavor strong of roasted malts. Nutty. Bitter coffee finish. A little thin on the palate. Good carbonation levels. Slightly fizzy. Overall, pretty good. Nothing spectacular, but very drinkable. More nose would improve this beer greatly.

12oz bottle from total wine in greenville. pours a very dark brown, damn near black, with a nice half-inch, dark, cocoa-powder brown head and solid lacing. aroma is great with big roasted malts, dark chocolate, nutty toffee, buttered popcorn, smoke, and hints of roast coffee. flavor is excellent with big, dark, roasted coffee, dark chocolate, and sweet, dark fruits up front backed by sweet toffee, roasted nuts, hints of smoked wood, and a touch of bitter, earthy/leafy hops. palate is medium bodied and lightly carbonated with a long lasting burnt coffee and roasted, nutty malt finish. overall, a wonderful porter.

bottle: pint:  enjoyed with a delicious meal, this brew paired perfectly giving a comforting, autumn feel.  Very, very surprised with this brew to be honest, did not expect much at all.  The beer looks like a glass full of iced coffee, leaving a very thin, brown head ring.  The nose is dark, loads of roasted malts, coffee, bitter dark chocolate.  The taste is smooth, almost creamy despite the thin body.  Delicious chocolate and coffee, mild carbonation made this feel almost like dessert!  Again the body leaves you almost wanting more, however you could easily have a second (or fourth) to satisfy the craving.  Great brew!

Pours an opaque black with a nice layer of foamy tan head.  Aroma is a mix of baking chocolate and coffee.  Flavor is a nice balance of creamy lactic chocolate milkshake sweetness and roasty slightly toasted smokiness.  Overall, enjoyable.

After living Portsmouth for a year i somehow missed this gem, but now in NY got a chance to rate.  really nice looking with great smoky aroma.  tastes chocalty and smokey but not over poweringly so.  Got in the 12 Beer variety pack wish they would include this all the time instead of the Old Brown Dog.

On tap at Dunderbaks, Tampa.  Id had it in bottles before, but this was far superior.  Looks and smells just like it tastes.  Light will not penetrate the glass.  Coffee, dark chocolate and sorghum beets(?).  It hit that fine line of light carbonation that I crave in a porter.  Served cool, it  morphed nicely over 20-25 minutes. Lace hung on the glass throughout.  Bringing the smoke down a little bit might make it perfect.

Thanks go out to a few people for sending me this, but I could have sworn I rated it long ago!  Oh well.  Pours black with a small to moderate light brown head.  Aroma is definitely stronger than the typical porter with dark chocolate, wood, leaves, tobacco, acidic coffee, and perhaps a hint of oxidation.  Maybe this is old, or I stored it poorly for a wee bit too long before drinking.  Flavor is spot on with dark chocolate, caramel, tobacco, wood, leaves, earth, coffee, and peanuts.  Finishes with peanuts going down, followed by coffee, darker chocolate, and slight charred wood aftertaste.  Medium bodied, creamy, and seemingly thicker than it is, this beer gives a LOT of deep and big flavors for the small ABV.  I would bring sixers of this to parties all the time if I could.

Pitch black pour, beautiful tan head. Aroma holds coffee, chocolate, caramel malt, roast, and some dark fruit; really nice. Flavor is phenomenal; tons of coffee, roasted malt, dark chocolate, caramel, and some subtle molasses sweetness. Just an incredible and classic specimen of a porter. Ive had this too many times to write more, i just want to drink the thing.

On tap at Bacchus.  Pours a deep dark cola black with a hefty creamy dark tan head.   Roast, vanilla, caramel, nice sweetness.  A touch on the thin side of medium bodied, light astringency, bitter roast and light baking chocolate.  Finishes with a lot of roast bitterness, and some slow lingering char notes.

Draft at Mellow Mushroom - Brandon.

Poured a blsck color with an aqverage fizzy light brown head that mostly lasted with good lacing. Moderate toasted malt and chocolate aroma. Medium body with a smooth slick texture and flat carbonation. Medium to heavy toasted chocolate sweet flavor with a medium bittersweet finish of moderate duration.

Solid complex brew.

UPDATED: SEP 2, 2010 1. Cask Stillage at the GBBF, Earls Court 04/08/2009
Big fruit and roast aromas. Black hoppy and strong in alcohol woth a little dryness in a crisp and bitter roast finish.
2. Cask Stillage at the GBBF, Earls Court 04/08/2010
Fruity and hoppy aroma. Black a little rich on the palate and strong in alcohol with a hint of dryness and bitterness in a coffee roast finish.
Tap at Puck Fair. Poured a super dark brown with a beige head. Coffee malt nose.  Great coffee and chocolate and some nice burnt notes. Delicious bitter finish.
Black beer with a small white head and only few carbonation. Coffee like aroma with some malty roasted touches. Full creamy palate. Finish is bitter though rather soft ending.
12oz bottle. Well done porter. Pours very dark with a slight head that lingers. Good combination of malt, coffee and chocolate tastes.

Tap @ brasserie420
Compact foam that seems pulled with nitrogen but isnt!
A bit yeasty but one of the first pints of a new just-agitated keg. So im sure itll clarify with time. The foam is surely long lasting. Tipical creamy, roasted robust porter nose with a scent of black olives.
On the palate licorice and earthy notes with a well established burnt and resiny bitter. Black olives as well.
A bit of CSA as the Smuttynose IPA tasted earlier, but still not too strong to bother.
Nice silky body, tapped well with the right amount of co2. Overall an easy drinking balanced beer.

Tap at Beer Temple, Amsterdam. Black coloured, medium sized brown head, roasted coffee in the nose. Roasted malt, coffee and chocolate with notes of dried fruits and hops. Smooth, mild carbonation and bitter finish. Not so Robust but still good porter.

12 ounce bottle. Served in a pint glass, the beer pours dark brown with a half inch brown head. Head retention and lacing are both good. Aroma is nice, it smells like roasted malt, bittersweet chocolate, coffee, and some molasses. The taste is similar to the aroma, it tastes like coffee, bittersweet chocolate, burnt malt/smoke and roasted malt. Mouthfeel/body is medium, its creamy and silky with good carbonation. Drinkability is good, its smooth and easy to drink. This porter lives up to its name, it is quite robust and enjoyable. Id definitely buy this again the next time I get a chance to.
On tap at Bier Tempel, Adam. Dark black with heavy tan head. Nice malty and chocolate nose. Taste of malts, wheat and lots of chocolate. Very nice, just right porter. Hats off.

a surprisingly great, strong, extremely porter-tasting porter. Very dark malts with a strong roasted black coffee flavor that goes down very smoothly. This is by far the darkest porter I have ever seen. Fantastic. Bottle at 8 oz Burger Bar on Miami Beach.

Sampled at WBF in Durham - I always see this porter at my local brew haven and have been meaning to try it - well, finally I did and I now wish I hadnt taken so long.  Pour is dark chocolately color with is exactly where the aroma begins - chocolate, roasted coffee, malts and some smokiness.  Great taste of chocolate coffee balanced out by the malts and a nice creamy mouthfeel.  Ill be picking up a 6 of this next time out.
nice beer, really everything about it is good, nice dark brownish color, moka head. nose is chocolate and coffee. flavor is similar with some booze but so nicely intertwined great beer

12 oz bottle courtesy of an extra from msante79. Thanks, Mark! Pours a near black pour, reddish brown at the edges, not quite opaque, but dark, a big billowy brown head that cakes at a good level, laces very well. Aromas are a nice roasty malt, a bit more subtle, with coffee, light bitter chocolate, a decent hopping of florals, toasty, a touch of caramel. Initial is medium bodied, coats well, nothing overbearing, but good flavors throw roast, coffee, a touch of ashy smoke, faint nut, touch of chocolate. This beer is nice, a drinkable dark ale that doesnt weigh you down with sweeter dark malts, instead striking a good balance, nice flavors without being overdone. Very nice, a touch of creamy sweetness works its way in, but decent roast works well and a light floral hop bitterness lends a hand. Yum.
Really nice looking dark color.  Aroma is roasted malt, chocolate, some coffee.  Flavor is pretty much identical going through stages.  Nice brew
Bottle poured into a tulip glass produced a creamy light-brown head and almost black body.  Very smooth well-balanced ale with a light smoke (roasted) and hints of molasses, coffee, and dark fruits.

Almost pitch black body. Naked surface. Inviting smell of dark, sweet fruits with peaty undertones. The flavour profile stands out as a fine mix of tart fruits and slightly roasted, dark malts with hints of both chocolate and caramel. Medium bodied and fine drinkability. One-third pint, gravicask at GBBF, 04.08.2009).

Poured from a 12oz. bottle into a pint glass.

The smell is of roasted malt and dark chocolate.

The taste is also of roasted malts with a coffee flavor that is a bit of an espresso flavor. Slight dark chocolate, and dark fruit feel as well.

This beer is pretty light but very flavorful. The feel is a bit of a heavy/medium but is pretty drinkable and goes down well.

UPDATED: OCT 2, 2009 Bottle. Dark brown, close to black pour with little head. Complex, smoky aroma with notes of oak, pumpernickel, chocolate, cherry, vanilla and coffee. Taste brings smokiness with fruit notes in the front, developing into a dark chocolate finish in the back with hop bitterness and saltiness. Light on carbonation with medium body. Provides a quality beer drinking experience.
Roasted malt palate, rich smooth flavor of coffee and chocolate. Very enjoyable porter, definately tasty!
Got this in a trade.  Relatively creamy, and the flavor is a bit of sweet with robust (hah!) coffee and chocolate flavors. The flavors are almost like they were trying too hard... not very subtle.

Opaque brown color, small steady stan head. Toasted malty and red currant aroma. Flavor has roasted malts, red currant and some licorice. Red currant is odd here.

This poured a dar dark brown color with a light tan head. Aroma was very roasted, some hints of chocolate as well. Flavor was really balanced roastedness and silky chocolate, not so much robust like the beer says, but a pretty good balanced porter.

12oz bottle thanks to WT, consumed on August 7, 2009.  Pours an incredibly dark brown color, almost like a thick wood stain, with a gorgeous brown head.  The head leaves behind a sticky, yet patchy lacing.  Aroma is very roasted, and the flavor is of strong roast, yet light and easy on the palate.  Mouthfeel is thick and creamy.  Coffee and chocolate are most noticed in the finish... a great, great beer.
Cask at the GBBF 2009. A very dark beer with peat and moss aroma. The flavour is bittersweet with an overall roasted smokiness. Theres a nice aftertaste rounds everything off. Very, very tasty.

Very dark brown, strong tan head, thinly coated lacing.  Spent coffee ground aroma, some dry wood as well.  Biting roasted character, nearly bitter on its own.  Robust indeed, theres a gentle and persistent creamy chocolate finish with enough body to allow itself  to be cut through with the next initially bitter sip.  Super.

[email protected]/* <![CDATA[ */!function(t,e,r,n,c,a,p){try{t=document.currentScript||function(){for(t=document.getElementsByTagName('script'),e=t.length;e--;)if(t[e].getAttribute('data-cfhash'))return t[e]}();if(t&&(c=t.previousSibling)){p=t.parentNode;if(a=c.getAttribute('data-cfemail')){for(e='',r='0x'+a.substr(0,2)|0,n=2;a.length-n;n+=2)e+='%'+('0'+('0x'+a.substr(n,2)^r).toString(16)).slice(-2);p.replaceChild(document.createTextNode(decodeURIComponent(e)),c)}p.removeChild(t)}}catch(u){}}()/* ]]> */, 2009.  Almost black beer with a very roasted aroma, and a slightly rich, gently bitter and roasted flavour.  Overall an average roasted beer.

Smuttnose has under whelmed me time and time again...BUTTT this Porter is amazing. Smells great. Hits the tong with the pop I expect from a Porter and brings multiple layers of flavor. I would love to see this come out as a seasonal special smoked porter.

Bottle at the Brickskeller in DC.  Darkest brown in color with a nice tan head.  Aroma of coffee, roast, and smoke.  Flavor roasty and coffeeish with chocolate and a little smoke also present.  Well-balanced, creamy palate with a medium-full body.
6-pack from Total Wine, River Edge, NJ...bottle pours black with an off-white head...mild malty aroma with hints of coffee...nice roasty espresso flavor, dry mouthfeel...decent porter.
Bottle poured thick black. Coffee roast smell. Balanced taste with alot going on.
Pint on tap at he Flying Saucer, Raleigh, NC. Chocolate malty smell, taste was rich, smooth, creamy, milky. The body had enough backbone to warrant its namesake. Quality Porter here.

On tap at Redbones, into shaker.  Dark opaque black/brown with dark coffee head that started at about a 1/4 inch and faded to a ring within a minute.  Roasted flavor upfront, dry over the palate.  Smooth, slightly creamy/oily mouthfeel.  Good lacing.  Yum.
Fantastic porter.  Packed with delicious roasty flavor.  This is right up there with Founders porter, which I just had for the first time not long ago.  Probably the 2 best robust porters Ive had.

Bottle. Pours deep brown with a small cappuccino coloured head. Aromas of roasted malt, chocolate, coffee and fruity hops. Malty and rich flavour with notes of coffee, chocolate, caramel and bitter hops at the end. Super balanced and very well made.
Delicious and strong porter.  Coffee hints and thick boozy aftertaste make this a winner.  Smuttynose showing they can make big beers and regular beers with astounding consistency and quality.

Blind tasting - Poured red-brown. Smelled of lactose and smooth dark malt. Yum...I want to drink this beer. The taste is great--dark roast and bitter coffee with a nice chocolate note. Its a creamy one, too--smooth and medium-full bodied. Complex but drinkable, and my favorite of the 13 porters I tried.
Rich dark almost black in color a very nice frothy dark beige head.  Aroma is malty and flavor is of roasted malt and chocolate.  A very nice porter

Overall Impression: 
A nice Porter, and an enjoyable brew.  Rich and malty, coffee flavor is particularly present.
UPDATED: AUG 12, 2009 Hints at espresso...a thin body but the flavor lingers.   Pours with a great head and nice lacing.  Very enjoyable.

This is a bottle that is after the best before date, so this might not be as high as a fresher rating might get.  Has basically a pure black color with some brown head.  I can smell sweeter malts, chocolate, a little coffee, and a roasty slightly smoked scent.  Taste is full of chocolate and malts.  Similar to a good brown ale.  Aftertaste leaves a little bite, but nothing thats obscene.

Pours dark brown with a dark beige head.  Great big ol chocolate nose with a bit of coffee and roast.  More coffee flavor than chocolate but they are both still very robust and good as hell.  Medium/full body with appropriate carbonation.  Roasted dry finish.  Very very good beer.

Bottle from SuIIy!  pours a deep brown with a nice big foamy head.  aroma is bitter chocolate, espresso, some roasted malts.  exceptionally smooth with a dry finish.  medium body.  one of the best stouts/porters Ive had that were under 6% abv.  I liked this a lot.  could drink this all day.
Sample at Mr. Dunderbaks.  Nice robust flavor.  Balance of malt, chocolate, coffee, and maybe even some toffee.  Rich and dark.

Near-black pour with a frothy tan head.  Aroma is of roasted malts and milk chocolate.  Full bodied, creamy mouthfeel.  Flavor is dark, roasted malts, coffee, chocolate... a recipe for bitterness but this one is smooth.  Lingering milky chalikiness, lactose?, bit of citrus/orange hoppage towards the finish.  Solid and tasty but Im surprised its rated so high with so little complexity.

12oz bottle from Total Wine (Tampa, FL)> Pours a dark brown to black with one finger white-tan head. Aroma is roasty and malty with notes of chocolate, brown sugar, ripe dark fruit, some hints of wood. Flavor is sweet and roasty with notes of chocolate, coffee, toffee, brown sugar, some ripe dark fruit, hints of wood. Generally medium body with a pleasing roasted malty finish.
35,5cl bottle. Thanks a lot Maxxdaddy. Pitch black with a creamy brown head and lacings. Bitter roasted coffee. A bit ashy and very smooth. Medium bodied. Very solid and tasty!

[Draft @ EB+B] Poured an opaque black color with a small, tan head that left nice lacing on the glass.  Aroma of roasted malts, dark chocolate, some smoked wood, nuts, and dark fruits.  Taste of dark fruits, raisins, roasted malt, bitter dark chocolate, smoke, and a dry, coffee finish.
Pours dark with an offwhite head, head lasts a little while Strong coffee and roasted chocolate  notes in both taste and nose, not much of an aftertaste

UPDATED: JUL 5, 2010 Very nice!  Pours black with a decent light-brown head.  Nice smoky aroma.  Flavor is roasty, roasty, roasty!  Appearance is beautiful with lotsa lacing, looks like tree rings on my glass.  While not as thick & heavy as an Impy Stout, it is a bit heavy for a porter.  Very glad to finally give this one a shot & will certainly buy again!
Decent beer. Also goes along my category of if youre at a store and you need a 6 pack this is a good buy
Bottle pours black with off white head.  Aroma is coffee and chocolate.  Silky smooth mouthfeel.  Flavor is roasty coffee and bittersweet chocolate.  This is a solid brew.

12oz bottle.  black pour with a thick tan head.  muted aroma of chocolate, coffee and roasted malts.  kind of bombarded with a variety of tastes:  milk chocolate, licorice, molasses and bitter coffee.  a light tingly carbonation with a medium to light texture.  finishes off with a lingering chalky bitterness.  pretty tasty.

Bottle from Charleston NC piggly wiggly.  Aroma is smoky and roasty very dark portery.  Flavor is coffee and roast.  Finish is dry bitter and very clean porter.  I cant belive that this low alcohol beer has so much flavor.
Bottle  Pours a black body with a tan head.  Roast y coffee and bitter hop resins with light chocolate accents.  Nice.

Ahh, this is the porter I was looking for. While not as heavy on the coffee smell or flavors of the Edmund Fitzgerald, Smuttynoses example is one to behold as well. This porter is just plain smooth with a healthy balance between the roasted malts and hops. While hops usually seem to get pushed to the back in beers like this, a slight bitter after taste means they are there, which is nice to see and taste for a change. My only question for this beer is, which is heavier? The girl or the barrel?

On draft at Blind Tiger.  Pours very dark brown with minimal head.  Aroma is roast, toasted malt, coffee, chocolate, and some spice.  Flavor has grilled/smoked notes with rich malt, coffee, and dark chocolate.  Medium body.  Good porter that I would have again.

opaque, good head, lacing. strong espresso, smoke, char aroma. large body considering the relaively modest ABV. a sweet start and a dark chocolate dry late finish. some salt on the sides suggest a pretzel pairing. imperial taste without the high alcohol.
really nice porter. a step up from a lot of regular ones. falls in the middle of the pack. would benefit from food. porters, for me, unless double or oak aged just miss something.

12oz bottle, Variety Sampler Mixed 12pk.  (GOLD @ 2008 GABF),  Very dark brown/black pour.  Thick creamy tan head.  Heavenly aroma.  Big semi-sweet chocolate.  Lots of roasted grain.  Deep roast.  Flavor is a rich, thick malt.  Sweet dark chocolate.  Nice roasted character.  Slight nuttiness. lots of coffee bean character.  Then follows the bold hop.  Nice woody pine comes out of no where.  Very well rounded.  A bit on the heavy side (for a porter), still extremely sessionable.  I dream of a pub that has only one tap with only this Porter available.  Cheers!  21mar09
Dark pour with a small, tan head. Not very smooth. The beer has a strong flavor, that of ground coffee beans and smoked varmit.

Pours very dark with attractive half inch tall mocha head. The aroma is roasty with burnt edges and notes of earthiness and faint molasses. The taste begins pretty smooth with notes of highly roasted malts and hints of molasses easing their way into the picture. Toward midway burnt malts surface along with a touch of chocolate and a certain dark roasted coffee bean flavor that take it to the finish. Coffee, burnt malts and mild earthiness seem to hang around into the after taste.
Pours very dark brown with a small tanish head. Nose of chocolate, coffee and smoke. Flavor is the same with a very nice hop presence that dry through the finish. Very awesome porter.

UPDATED: MAY 31, 2009 pours dark with an off white head that lasted half a beer smell is of coffee and malt. taste is coffee start maybe hints of chocolate finishing into a roasted taste in my mouth not much of an after taste most of the taste comes at the beginning.  smells fantastic taste is alright.

12 oz. Bottle. Pours excellent, dark brown. Creamy/Dark tan head. Instant malt flavor, followed by a chocolate(cocoa)/coffee and nutty after taste. Just the right balance between the bitterness and full body flavor. I wouldnt want much more in a porter, it has all that I love about a nut brown ale, encased in a lovely porter body. One of our favorite beers, easily.

UPDATED: NOV 28, 2009 Malt, iron, coffee aroma.  Another time i have had it I found it remarkably skunky.

Malty, oatmeal and sweet dark chocolate. Then good smokey coffee in the finish with a lightly hopped dryness.

Quite a thick beer, drinkable when well chilled but a bit much as it warms up. Quite sticky.

12 oz. bottle.  Pours almost black with small ruby highlights.  Small, creamy, tan head.  Notes of raisins, chocolate, caramel, coffee, alcohol, and a touch of prune in the nose.  Medium carbonation with a thick, rich mouthfeel.  A nice hint of dryness in there too.  The palate tastes of coffee, mineral, caramel, bittersweet chocolate, along with a nice hop bitterness on the back end.  Rich and creamy at first then finishes with a bitter dryness.  Quite nice!  An excellent brew for sure, but I would classify it as a stout.
Bottle. Pours black with moderate off-white head. Aroma and flavor are rich with chocolate. Some malty notes. Finishes dry with citrus hops which linger. Medium bodied.

fantastic porter. aroma is rich coffee, chocolate, burned malt, and sweetness.  drinks smooth with a nice bitter coffee and semisweet chocolate. some roast malts in the middle but this one finishes clean with some coffee. no after taste. this one is crisp!

A fitting name for this beer, one fine porter indeed.
Pours oily black, with mahogany/mocha head.
Aroma of strong dark fruits, chocolate and malts.
Taste simply loaded with chocolate, roasted malts, full body, light bitter hops, robust at best and could easily pass for more than 5.7%.
Poured pitch black. Malty, coffee aroma. Taste was mainly roast malt, coffee and cocoa. More bitter than I expected. Not too bad.
On draft at Redlight Redlight.  Nice porter.  Pours a dark brown with a ton of roast.  Smooth flavor with a nice burnt coffee flavor.  Relly good.

[Bottle] Pours dark brown with a small tan head. Aroma is very nice at first, with lots of chocolate, and very faint notes of dark fruits and smoke. As it warms, it gradually changes, taking on a more burned popcorn character that is not nearly as appealing and really quite astoundingly different from the initial smell. The taste has a fair amount of chocolate, but it is largely dominated by the charred malt that came out in the aroma. It isnt bad, but it makes it a little one dimensional. Medium mouthfeel with a long finish. Overall this was an interesting beer that I am glad I had a whole bottle of to drink. The aroma is so jekyll and hyde that had I rated this at a festival, or at a tasting, I would have most likely missed out on one of the phases that it goes through. If the charred malt were toned down just a bit I would really like this beer.
On tap at RedLight.A perfectly named beer.It was chocolatey and robust.Semi sweet with some chocolatey bitterness.A full flavored to the last drop brew

Draft at Redlight Redlight.  Pours a really dark mahogany brown color with a chestnut edge.  A foamy, tan head settles quickly, leaving delicate splotches of lace behind.  The nose is very roasty and smooth, with bold notes of dark milk chocolate, burnt caramel, deeply roasted barley, and espresso.  Flavors follow suit, with rich, dry, dark cocoa and scorched caramel dominating.  Bitter, earthy hops and black coffee linger well after the finish.  Medium-full and dry roasted, the mouthfeel is substantial, but suffers from over-carbonation and a hint of chalkiness.  If not for the palate flaws, this would be a killer porter.  As it stands, it is still pretty damn good.

Bottle.  Poured near black with a small brown head.  Lots of nice lacing.  The aroma was of roasted malt, chocolate, and a little smoke.  Medium bodied, very smooth.  Flavor is malty, lots of chocolate tones and light smoke.  Good.
Near black, full-bodied with an enduring creamy head. Warm chocolate and coffee malts, licorice, and a smoky, hoppy presence in the finish. Itd be hard to find a better porter.
Pours a dark brown color with a nice thick brown head. aroma was sweet and full of roasted malt. Flavor was creamy and sweet. had a slightly hoppy coffee finish.

12oz bottle. Pours a deep dark brown (almost black) with a ruby-brown highlights and a thin dark tan head leaves narrow sheets of lace on the glass. The aroma is a complex blend of earthy hops, sugar malts, sweetened espresso, bitter cocoa, and hints of dark fruit. Flavor is earthy and roasty with strong coffee. It has a strong flavor with very little sweetness, light earthy hop flavor, and subtle alcohol. Mid-palate brings firm earthy bitterness with some very bitter cocoa and light malt sweetness. The finish is sharply dry and bitter with hops and coffee. The mouthfeel is crisply carbonated - almost too much - with a dryness that coats and makes the medium-full body feel lighter. Overall, a very strongly flavored porter. The roastiness is intense  - but rich, not burnt or acrid. It is also surprisingly strong with earthy hops.

Tallahassee, Fl. - Liquor Loft - 12 oz bottle. Pours an asphalt black with a long lasting creamy mocha colored head that leaves good lacing. Rich aroma with plenty of dark bittersweet chocolate and some day old coffee. Flavor is full of fresh back dirt, dark chocolate and coffee. Mouthfeel is nice and chalky. A most excellent porter.
Draft at Redlight Redlight. Dark brown pour, creamy tan head. Very strong aroma of dark chocolate and coffee. Flavor was very bitter, very little sweetness, and extremely full bodied.

draft @ redlight redlight.  Fruity chocolatey aromas, dark fruits, chocolate covered raisons, smoked dates, with hints of coffee.  Pours black with a thick off white head.  Chocolate and coffee, with dark fruits, raisons, roasted malts, bitter chocolate, with traces of licorice.  A very solid porter.

Bottle thanks to mcox90.  Dark brown red glints and a full finger of tan head.  Aroma of licorice, molasses, roast malt, soy sauce, chocolate.  Taste is nice molasses, licorice a bit of bitter coffee.  Nice beer.

bottle.jet black pour with a small tan head,some lacing. aroma of coffee and cocoa.flavors of bittersweet chocolate,coffeea nd roasted notes. nice bitter finish,medium mouthfeel ,low carbonation and a little slick. excellent

Bottle.  Pourspitch black with a medium tan head. Aroma is a malty chocolate with a touch of hops.  Flavor is chocolate, coffee, brown sugar, malt, and a little raisin in there.  Medium mouthfeel, leaves a bit of a stick film.  Very good porter, especially for the price.
Super malty porter from the East does the trick on a colder winter night.  There is just a perfect roasty bitter balance.

bottle.  hard pour which resulted in small brown head (quickly and fully dissapated) into black body.  aromas of mod cofee, mod cocoa, light hops, and a touch of molasses.  flavor is initially bittersweet but finshes with stronger bitterness. slightly chalky mouthfeel.  long finish duration.  pretty darn good stuff.

12oz bottle.   Black with a creamy tan head.   Smooth roasted malt and cocoa aroma.   Lots of roast and chocolate flavor, sweet but balanced by a nice hop bitterness and roast.   Finishes clean, with a slight tinge of acidity.   Medium, almost full bodied but quite drinkable.   Nice stuff.   This is definitely my kind of porter.

Pours a deep, slightly reddish opaque sable with a dark tan, almost brown, head. Rich aroma makes me think of fine roast coffee and has hints of molasses and unsweetened chocolate. Thick, heavy, mocha flavor has a smoky overtone and hints of molasses, honey and hops. Texture is thick and smooth, leaving behind a delightful tingle.

Smuttynose, welcome to Atlanta!

UPDATED: FEB 22, 2009 (bottle) Pours black with a dark tan head and decent lacing.  The aroma is initially really bizarre, theres a good base of chocolate here, but theres also this odd aroma of butter and tartness.  Smells of must and wet dog as well.  This label with the dog on it is appropriate.  Taste is just heavily roasted french roast coffee, maybe some dark chocolate, but this is really walking that tightrope between being pleasant or astringent, and the circus theme on the label again describes this beer perfectly.  The obnoxious snap pea flavor is also noted right before the finish, which pushes it over the edge.  The finish is ok, with a bit of sweetness that rounds out to a light bitterness.  I hope this is just a bad bottle, because this beer was pretty disappointing. That was definitely a bad bottle, because this new bottle is so much better.  Nice chocolate aroma, with some hints of licorice and roasted malt.  Not must or wet dog this time.  Taste is really good too, some rich chocolate, perfect roast, and hints of tart berry skin.  Far more enjoyable, and definitely worthy of its score.

Decent off-white head. Nice black color. The head sticks around for a while, which is nice. Nice aromatic coffee/chocolate/ash aroma. This is very nice. A pungent aroma with this beer. Wow, this porter is actually very tasty. It has a nice strong flavor. Nice sweet flavor that just lingers on your tongue. This is actually a very good porter. Nice smooth palate. Overall, just a wonderful beer. The hops are great as well. They linger on your tongue and make the beer well rounded.

Bottle. Poured black with a tan head that left light lace. Aromas of milk chocolate and a hop backing. The flavor found a nice mix of chocolate, coffee, roast, and a hoppy background. Medium body. Decent!!

Bottle.  Pours dark, almost black with a tan head and lots of lace.  Aroma of roasted malt, lots of chocolate.  Taste is also roasty chocolate, with some nice bitter notes in the finish.  Mouth is nice and creamy, with light carbonation.  Overall, a very nice porter.

almost opaque black under a medium sized brown creamy head.  rich dark chocolate aroma.  dry bitter full bodied palate.  flavors of bitter coffee grinds, dark chocolate.  robust indeed.  low to moderate carbonation give it a creamy texture.  impressive.

351 mL bottle.  Dark chestnut brown, almost opaque, with a ring of beige head.  A dense, creamy (?!) aroma, with cocoa and earthy hops.  Tonnes of cocoa in the flavour, with malty sweetness and bitter roast fighting it out for your remaining attention.  Alcohol is well hidden.  The body is quite full at first, but thins out at the end.  The high carbonation may have something to do with this.  Nice porter, though.

Bottle from Charles St.  Easily the best label in beer.  Nose of milk chocolate coffee, which has scarcely been made but deserves presence.  Flavor is non-buttery but smooth, sharpish milk chocolate, and etherea.  Well done, but not the best thing in Smutty,
Decent porter. Very dark. Lots of chocolate and coffee.  Very sweet finish. I like.

12 oz. bottle.  Glad to see this brewery expanding distribution into Georgia.  Dark black pour with a thin, light tan head.  Aroma of dark chocolate, roasted malt, and licorice.  Full, thick mouthfeel.  Flavor is really nice.  Tons of chocolate and coffee.  Finish is bitingly bitter.
Dark brown with dense tan head.  Aroma is light.  Hoppy and roasty flavor and a medium palate.  Nothing spectacular here.

Nice aroma right out of the bottle, roasted coffee, chocolate, other malts.  Brown/black body, thoroughly opaque, and a decent size tan head.  The flavor is roasted coffee, dark chocolate, fairly sweet overall.  The finish has a bittering from the roasted malts, and a modest bit of hops.  Excellent representation of one of my favorite styles.

Nearly opaque black with only the slightest twinges of crimson-brown around the edges. Chocolate milk colored head that fades rapidly, but leaves a nice lace. Bitter chocolate, toffee and ash, faint hint of black cherry in the nose. Full bodied, sweetened coffee, with a long crisp finish of burnt cocoa. Best of the style Ive ever had!

UPDATED: MAR 4, 2009 Bottle. Pours black with one-finger head and great lacing. Nice mix of sweet lactose and roasty malts on nose and tongue. Sweet coffee and notes of chocolate as well as sweet cream. Nutty hints as well. Light silky palate. Quite good.

Pours a silky black with a very small head. Aroma is delicious - caramel, nuts, roasted malt, some hoppiness. Taste is the same plus chocolate and coffee. Very drinkable and enjoyable. Ill be drinking this one regularly.

Taste 2/9 Bottle. Looks: Black with tan foam. Aroma: Chocolate and coffee malt roasts.  Nice, but nothing spectacular. Taste: A good clean, rich thin bodied porter.  Not very dry. Good to drink but nothing awe inspiring either.

12oz bottle, pours a dark brown...OK, call it black, with a big tan head. Nose of licorice, chocolate, roasted malt. Oh my....smooth as silk, a great moouthfeel. Just enough hops to set it off, but they are definately there in back. Let this one warm up a bit before drinking - DO NOT drink this at the same temp as you would a cold Bud after work. Great stuff. Would love to try this on tap, or better yet, on cask.

Pours a really dark brown with a tan head that leaves a bit of watery lacing... Aroma is roasty with a touch of vanilla, chocolate, and coffee... Taste is quite bland with notes of coffee, and chocolate... Thin body, not much in the finish... This continues the trend of me trying to find a smuttynose 12oz beer that i genuinely enjoy...

looked like a nice porter...pitch black with a light mocha head and a bit of lacing.  mild roasted aroma with bakers chocolate, coffee, and a touch of citrusy hops.  flavor had notes of coffee and roasted malt followed by chocolate and subtle citrus.  very thin mouthfeel for a porter with a bitter cheap espresso finish.  not very robust at all!

12oz Bottle

Best Before 8/08

I received this in a recent trade with israel, thanks again! Smuttynose Robust Porter pours the darkest of browns that border on black. When the body is directly backlit there are very faint garnet hues throughout. A soft pour produced a swirling two fingers worth of khaki colored head. As it fell to the thick cap it settled at it became creamy and left some really nice sheet lacing down the glass. 

This porter has a really great nose. Its all at once roasty, nutty, and chocolaty. The roastiness leads the way and is accompanied by a nice mellow dark chocolaty goodness. Something along the lines of hazelnut comes through faintly here and there along with ghost like notes of maple syrup. The nuttiness seems to show up at different times. Each swirl of the glass brings a quick whiff of coffee grounds. 

The flavor falls just short of the stellar aroma but is very good none the less. The roastiness still has the spotlight and all the other aromas are there in the flavor although not quite as bright and vibrant. The coffee grounds and roastiness leaves a slightly bitter finish that makes this an all around solid porter. The nuttiness plays in the flavor too flashing here and there.

Robust porter sports a medium body with enough carbonation to keep things moving quickly. The roasty bitterness keeps growing as I drink. 

The drinkability is enhanced by the lighter body and solid carbonation. This is a porter than can be easily enjoyed a few at a time.

This is one of my favorite sessionable porters and I tend to pick up a sixer whenever Im in an area that carries Smuttynose. Robust Porter is incredibly easy to drink and very flavorful.

Serving type: bottle

7/11/08

Another old favorite from the college years. Been drinking a lot of Founders Porter recently and I think this is what it reminds me the most of.  A really damn well made porter.  Even after leaving a half glass of this out overnight, it still has the rich aromas  of a tasty porter.  Not quite on par with Founders, but still one of Smuttynoses better beers.

12 oz bottle purchased at Bruisin Ales in Asheville.  Poured a dark black, almost motor oil color, with a three finger brown foamy head, that gave way to tons of lacing.  The aroma was roasted malt, bitter chocolate and stale coffee.  The flavor was a solid, buttkicking, roasted malt base, with chocolate present, and a bitter coffee finish.  The palate was above average, with soft carbonation, a medium/full body and a silky mouthfeel.  This is a beer I want to drink again.

UPDATED: SEP 21, 2009 Easily one of my favorite porters, and my go-to beer when I want something with a strong roasted flavor, but without the fuller body of a stout. An excellent standby beer,  well worth keeping a few in the fridge.

12oz bonus recently, too many recent trades to figure this one out.  How I havent rated this I dont know.  Pours black with a light brown head.  Nose is sweet, and malty with big notes of coffee and chocolate.  Taste is a little thinner, but has a nice chocolate and coffee feeling.  Nice roastyness.  yum.

Bottle at Akkurat, Stockholm.
Dark red brown colour with a big head.
Medium bodied. Sweet roasted flavour and a hint of smoke. The finish is primary roasty.

Pours black with tan white head. Milk chocolate and coffee in the aroma, not a strong aroma. Chocolatey taste with coffee aftertaste. This followed the Duck Rabbit Baltic Porter and could not compare to that but was a good porter none the less

Pours a thick brown, typical of a porter.  A medium tan head emerges as the beer settles.  Nose is not very strong, but a hint of coffee, milk chocolate, and roasted malts is apparent.  Mouth feel is very creamy, almost like chocolate milk with a touch of coffee.  A solid porter but the aroma could be more complex in my opinion.  A decent beer though, good job.

Bottle from a friend.  This is nice.  Pours black with a little foamy off-white, tan head.  Smells like chocolate milk.  Good biting bitterness and coffee across the palate and lingering coffee in the aftertaste.  Like it a lot.

Bottle at Eulogy, Philadelphia 18-11-08. Last beer of the session and a nice one to finish on. Good chocolatey taste from the off with chocolate and coffee, quite good bitter dusty cocoa and cold coffee flavours. Flavours are quite smooth rather than being pushy, not too harsh and a nice roasty woodiness comes into play also. Good beer. A 7 A 3 F 7 P 4 OV 15    3.6

This porter poured a deep black colour with a nice creamy brown head. To the nose there are scents of caramel, molassass, burnt malts and coffee. First taste was smooth and quite roasted flavoured. Flavours of molassass, roasted malt and coffee, very strong coffee flavour right into the fnish. Palate as roasty at the end as it is in the beginning with a liitle added hopp.

12 oz. bottle on 10/24/208. Deep clear mahogany body, long lasting rocky tan head, and rings of lace with each swallow. Coffee, unsweetened chocolate, hints of licorice, and a little spruce. Dark molasses brings brings a fleeting sweetness, but the bitterness contributed by dark roasted malts and piney hops are the mainstays of the flavor. medium to full body, light carbonation, noticeable astringency, and a very long, pleasingly bitter finish. This could easily be mistaken for a stout. Very good, one of the best porters I’ve had in a long time.

12 oz bottle pours black with a great tan head.  Lots of coffee, burnt sugar, caramel, and chocolate in the aroma.  Coffee, roast malt, toast, slightly bitter chocolate with a great mouthfeel.  Slightly thick with a great finish.

Six pack from Gary’s in Madison, NJ. Very smooth and (obviously) robust porter that pours a pretty dark brown with a mild tan head. Has a bit of a sweet tinge to the flavor but has a wonderful bitter snap at the back end. Highly enjoyable porter.

a damn fine porter.  pours a dark brown color with a nice thick brown head.  aroma was sweet and full of roasted malt.  flavor was creamy and sweet.  had a slightly hoppy coffee finish.  over all a fantastic brew.
