Sweet chocolate roastiness in the nose.  Opaque black with a ruby glow around the edges of the glass.  Rich creamy mouthfeel with a mineral bitterness on the finish.  Notes of milk chocolate, caramel, and hint coffee.  Cheers!

Sampled from a 12 oz brown bottle this beer poured a black color with a small dark brown head. The aroma was dry and very roasty with a woody undertone. The flavor was dry, bitter and had a nice floral hop presence and moderate roasty malts. The finish was bitter, roasty and floral. Drier than I tend to prefer. Solid.

Bottle, from Bobs Package Store.  Pours a deep brown, with a wispy tan head.  Aroma of dark chocolate, smoke, and chocolate malt.  Palate is medium in thickness, and dry, dry, dry, but not cloying.  Instead, the whole package blends so nicely, as the flavor profile is all dark:  chocolate, espresso, roasts, charcoal, and some prunes.  Finish is slightly bitter, with the hops showing more prominently.  Overall, this is a wonderful, robustly flavored porter.  Pick this up if you see it!

Pours a dark black that allows a small amount of light. Head is two fingers thick creamy chestnut. Fades reasonably quick and leaves a nice lace. The nose is sweet, chocolate, some coffee, minute hints of grain. The flavor is bittersweet chocolate, some coffee roast, mild sweetness, mild hop bitterness comes through. Palate has some carbonation but relies mainly on the smooth coating character of the beer for presence. NICE.

12 oz, bb Mar 09. Opaque black with a lasting half-inch foam that frosts the glass all the way down. Nice aroma of chocolate mocha. Big flavor of dark chocolate with light caramel on front, turns more towards a rich coffee with some nice piquant green herb and hickory char. Medium-heavy body is creamy smooth and roasty dry.

Bottle thanks to Mark. Pours a black color with a medium light-brown head. The aroma is very nice; roasted malts, some coffee, light dark fruits and smoke. The flavor is excellent; lots of rich roasted malts and some chocolates. A strong hop mix balances the beer out somewhat. Lots of smoke and a nice dark fruit aspect too. Very nice.

Poured a really nice black color witha bit of an off-white head.  Aroma was roasted malt and chocolate with just the barest hint of hops in the background.  Flavor had an interesting mix of hop and roast bitterness, but there was a lot of chocolate in this one too. Alternatively smooth and bitter, this one had a lot going for it.  Nice beer.

12 oz bottle poured into glass; Pours out very black for a porter.  Very little head that dissipates very quickly.  Smells of hoppy hickory smoked coffee and tastes similar.  Bitterness and slight chocolate/coffee finishes off the medium palate.
user_location: originally from Michigan, New York, USA

text: Nice black/brown pour.  Small disappating tan head.  Very roasty aroma malt, coffee.  Nice strong roast/burnt malt with mocha and some coffee bitters.  More hop flavor than some porters, finishes with a clean bite.  Not bad at all, will look for more from this brewer.  Not quite as good as the Dark Horse I had a few weeks back.
user_location: from Michigan now in Charlotte, North Carolina, USA

text: 12oz bottle that came in Smuttynose sampler pack. Pours black with thich and creamy tan head. Nice lacing. Aroma is roasted malt, chocolate and a bit of coffee. Flavor is dry and roasty with nice amount of roasted malts, chocolate and a bitterness from coffee. Could use a little less carbonation which would make mouthfeel smoother but still a damn good porter.

Bottle. Pours opaque black with a moderate tan head. Nose is roasty, some cocoa. Taste follows suit - roasty malt as the core flavor, with a bit of espresso and cocoa coming in secondarily. Dry, roasty finish. Moderate carbonation and a medium body. Nice stout, well defined, conservative. Could use a slightly smoother body with a hint less carbonation.

This beer pours a deep brown with a light brown head.  The aroma is chocolately and coffee-like.  The flavor is big time chocolate and coffee, with some other malty notes balanced with some sublte hoppiness.  The head seems very stable, which I really like.  The body is heavy with medium carbonation.  This is a great beer!
Dark brown with coffee colored head.  Roasted malt and hops aroma.  Roasted malt with brown sugar taste and hops finish.  Very rich and flavorful.

Pours a very dark, nearly opaque chestnut brown with a medium tan head.  Aroma is primarily of roasted grain with a bitter caramel edge and a hint of coffee.  Flavor is well-focused in a relatively narrow flavor profile for a beer of this heft--the roasted flavors are close to one another without any wild tangents of say molasses, strong chocolate, or fruit--it is a study of coffee and caramel notes with good bitterness and some hops.  Pleasantly light mouth feel for the style as well that enhances the delicate flavors.

Pours dark, dark brown with only the slightest hint of light penetrating around the edges.  The tan head is dense and shows very good retention and lacing.  Aroma has big roasted malts with significant chocolate and coffee whiffs as well.  There is also a little bit of hops in the nose as well.  The taste is mostly roasted malts and coffee with some dark fruits and a bit of milk chocolate.  Mouthfeel is creamy with tons of carbonation that accentuates the coffee bitterness a little bit.  This is a great porter and yet another solid brew from Smuttynose.

This beer is much better than I remember from first trying it several years ago. Very dark color. Smells like chocolate with just a hint of coffee. Luscious mouthfeel. Really good for a moderate porter.

Pours a pretty opaque black with a tan ring for a head and some spotty lacing.  Nice molasses and baker’s chocolate nose, decent body for a lower alcohol beer, finishes with a pleasant herbal bitterness with a touch of coffee roasted character.  Quite a decent midrange porter.

Very dark brown (almost black). Latte like head was moderate but almost laceless.

 The first smell was hops and a somewhat forresty feel.

 The chocolate and malt hit at the same time. Full flavored over a nice texture. Thick, and a somewhat lively carbonation. Coffee flavor finished the drink to a slightly bitter aftertaste.

 Much better than I expected. The influence of darker stouts without being too overpowering made this a nice glass.
Pours black with a thin light brown head. Aroma is of roasted coffee and dark chocolate. Has a nice balance of hops and malts. Nice roasty and bitter finish.
Toasted, coffee aroma. Thick, bubbly, brown head, lots of lacing. Woody, toasted, coffee taste. Palate resembles drinking warm whipped cream, fantastic, but purely a winter beer.
(Bottle).  Aroma of dark chocolate and coffee.  Deep dark brown, with a thin brown head.  Roasty flavor, with a bit too much tobacco.   LOVE the bottle label!

Dark brown pour with tan head and lace it even looks creamy. Toasted malt, coffee, and chocolate on the nose. Thick chocolate flavor and burnt coffee and a very good bitter on the taste. Creamy full mouthfeel. Nice finishing bitter and a lingering choco flavor as well.

12oz bottle served in an English pint glass. Very dark brown pour capped by a thin layer of tan foam. Smells of chocolate, anise, coffee. Big rich roasted flavor with some dark chocolate, wood, and licorice notes. Very powerful flavor, somewhat reminiscent of and imperial stout. Lots of complexity for only being 5.7% abv.

12 oz. bottle.  Pours black with a moderate brown head that lasted through half the glass and left very little lace.  Very pleasant aroma of chocolate, roasted malt, and coffee.  There are stouts that I wish smelled this rich and good.  The flavor is quite different with light chocolate and roast, with a more dominating tobacco flavor.  Moderate bitterness at the finish.  I would have liked this one much better were it not for the strong tobacco flavor.

Pours an opaque black with a dense, thin mocha head that fades to ring, leaving little lacing. The nose is hoppier than expected, with loads of piney hops. There is ample dark chocolate, smoke, coffee and nuts in the aroma as well. The flavour is sharp and roasty, with smoke, burnt coffee, nuts, bitter piney hops and dark chocolate. The finish is long and roasty as well. The mouthfeel is full and oily, with tingly carbonation and a bitter lingering.

It pours a dark nut brown color with a thin head that fades rather quick. The nose is very bitter with an intense coffee smell. You can really smell the roasted nuts and grains that were used in the brewing process. The flavors is nice and roasty with hints of chocolate malt mixed with just the right amount of coffee. I like how bitter it is and the nice bitter sweet after taste it leaves on the palate. The finish is full of roasted malt and coffee.

Bottle from Janie 08’.  Black with nice beige head.  An all around well balanced and crafted porter that falls right down the stylistic requirements.  If you picture a porter profile in your mind you are thinking of this beer.

Bottle courtesy of hellbilly. Pours an opaque black with one finger tan head.  Nose is Chocolate, coffee and roasted malts.  Taste is coffee grinds, smoke, toasted malts and dark, bitter chocolate with a sour, hoppy finish.  Light to medium mouth feel.  Very good porter  thanks Joshua!
Bottle from the Smuttynose variety pack. This is my favorite from the 4 included. A very balanced porter. A lot of malt, some coffee in the nose and in the aftertaste. Solid porter would buy again
user_location: The World of Beer, Texas, USA

text: Heavy chocolate and coffee aromas on pour with a nice brown foamy head an a black, black body. A smooth porter with little disturbance on the way down the way a good one should be. Sits very nice on the palate with just the slightest of all bitterness. Me like.
Bottle. Black colour with a tan head.  Aroma is coffee, roasted, chocolate. Flavour is coffee, hop, roasted malt. balanced and a very nice beer.

Bottle. It pours an almost black body with a tan head. Pretty close to a fiver on appearance. Chocolate, some coffee, vanilla and a little fruityness in the aroma. Chocolate, roasted and burnt flavors and some vanilla in the mouth, leading to a long, dry finish with chocolate, roasted malt and coffee. Dry and dusty-feeling in the mouth. A beauty. (080509)
Pours a super dark brown with a smallish beige head.  Aromas are toasty and cofee.  Flavor is coffee grounds, toast and nutty.  Dry finish.

Pours dark brown/red with a foamy tan head. Aroma is of chocolate, coffee and caramel.  Taste is mostly coffee with some notes of smoky vanilla.  Not much carbonation leads to bitter dry finish.  Would drink again.

Pours black with foamy tan head. Scents of chocolate, sweet vanilla, and dark fruits. The flavor has coffee malt and some cookie. A dry but clean tasting beer. A little strange based on experience, but this porter is pretty good.

Bottle.  Pours an opaque yet dark brown color with a caramel/orange head.  Smell of roasted malts and coffee.  Taste is of chocolate, coffee, and a hint of citrus.  Nice hop finish that hangs around in the mouth.  Slightly creamy mouthfeel.  A really good beer overall.

Bottle.  Dark molasses black body with maroon orange hue.  Limited head, no lace.  Chocolate, coffee grounds, roasted malts, mild vanilla.  Smooth, even body, not bitter or carbonated, nor heavy as some porter overwhelm you with their "robustness".  Fudge, malty initial flavoring gives way to coffee bitterness that lingers a little longer in the mouth and on the tongue than Id prefer.  Distinctive and drinkable.  Solid offering from Smuttynose, whom I ordinarily do not prefer.

This beer pours a deep drak brown/black with a medium tan head.  The aromas in this thing are awesome!  Roasted coffee, dark chocolate, with a slight earthy hop.  The flavors are exactly the same as the aroma and weld really well together!  This is one well crafted beer Id like to have again!  Cheers!
has a very nice roast/ coffee/chocolate aroma to it, tastes very roasted almost like burnt coffee beans to me,  with an element of dark chocolate.  decent body, pretty good beer.
Very well made. Nice smoky malt aroma and flavor. Dark brown almost black pour with a small tan head. End is crisp with some hops. Good stuff.

Black in color......opaque.  Creamy head......bold roasted malt aroma.  Heavy malt flavor up front......mouthfeel has a hint of crispness.  Back filled with a blend of chocolate, coffee and toffee notes.

Bottle. Pours with a deep ruby almost black color and a medium head with good lacing. The aroams are mainly of coffee and molasses wiith a bit of chocolate. Flavorwise it is on the bitter side where coffee and dark roasted malts dominate. The finish is lingering and quite bitter.

Bottle into English pint glass.  Pours a medium bodied deep, opaque brown.  The head was actually a duo-color tan and chocolate, and it dissipated down to a thin layer that carried through the entire drink.  Aroma is even caramel, chocolate, rich roast coffee.  Frankly, Im not a big fan of coffee notes in porters, but this one is balanced as nicely as any Ive tried with that characteristic.  The flavor is an initial dark choco, almost sweet, with the coffee bringing up the rear, hangin out on the mouth.  The palate is mid-level heavy, which isnt surprising.  Theres also a smokey hazelnut coffee sort of oliy clinging that isnt quite as pleasant.  In the end, this is a very drinkable porter.  Nothing extreme, nothing paint-by-numbers blah.  Nicely done.

Pours dark brown, with brownish head that goes away on third sip. Aroma is rife with dark chocolate, espresso, tannin. Taste is very smooth. Some sweetness to counter bold chocolate bitters and sturdy hop presence. A bit thin in the body for my taste, and alcohol is a bit caustic. However, this is a fine brew, and probably the best of Smuttys non-seasonal stuff.

UPDATED: MAY 28, 2008 Thanks to JCB for this one!  Black pour, tan head and some spotty lacing.  Roast aroma.  thick and dry.  Lots of roast and some coffee on the finish.  Slightly metallic and a little sticky
Roasted malts and coffee on the nose.  More of the same in flavor with a very dry bitterness, with coffee and dark chocolate in the finish. Good brew but a little too dry for me.

Pour is a black with a average tan head.  Aroma is a nice mix of roasted malts and coffee.  Flavor is more of a bitter dark chocolate with some smoke and black liquorice. Hits all the points of a good porter.  Very decent beer that is easy to drink.

Bottle. 12 fl. oz. An opaque, black beer with a fine, dark tan head that quickly dissapates.  Aromas of brewed coffee, dark chocolate, raisin, and licorice.  Light bodied with a very dry mouthfeel.  An overall heavy roasted, bitter flavor with a decent amount of sweetness on the back end.Very tasty, but still leaves me wanting more from this beer.

"From a bottle. Pours an opaque dark brown with a thick brown head that laces all the way down the glass. Aroma of coffee and roasted malt. Little thin in the mouthfeel. Flavor is sweet and chocolatey with coffee undertones. A nice bitterness at the finish. A pretty good beer."

Beer of the Month selection: Poured from the bottle into a pint glass.  initial pour produced a brown black (and opaque, light did not get through) body topped with a large, dark tan head of foam, which lingered for a bit.  Aroma was rich with chocolate and crisp hops notes.  Flavor is medium bodied with fair carbonation and moderate bitterness.  Coffee flavors linger for quite a bit and coat the surfaces of my mouth with a dryness that I wasnt expecting.  Aftertaste is quite strong and has heavy hops and bitter coffee notes.  The hopping of this brew has given it a dryness that I have not found in many porters which have tended to be on the sticky-sweet side.  This wasnt bad at all , and I will continue to enjoy the two remaining bottles from my BOTM selection.

Bottle from Whole Foods Charlottesville. Pours dark reddish brown with a medium head.Aroma of roasted malt, chocolate, cinnamon. Taste is more chocolate with coffee and some bitterness. Creamy and full feel. Great balance.

bottle by way of pforei. beautiful dark brown pour with a cocoa colored head. mocha like aroma... coffee, chocolate, cream and a toasted nuttiness (close to candied hazlenuts). sweet smelling but it still has the savory note that i get in a lot of good porters. the flavor is mostly roasty and chocolate with some sourness and an ashy finish. mocha like aftertaste. rather dry and parching... nice! full bodied, creamy texture and a soft mouth feel. very simple and very tasty...

Bottle, courtesy of Oakes. Gorgeous looking beer, opaque with tan head and leaves lacing. Well-balanced, firmly structured bouquet blends bread crust and dried fruit. Explosion of roasted malt, long lasting with a thread of sweetness running through it for balance. Soft mouthfeel. Lovely beer.

bottle from mecchi77 thanks jason: pours a black with a nice creamy esspresso foam head. aroma is a great chocolate, fresh coffee, some roast, very chocolate. fk\lavour is very smooth again with great chcolate flavour, good roast adn some nice coffee. a great porter all the way around.

Pours a very very dark brown with a tall and full bodied light brown head. Very nice sweet, roasted chocolate aroma. Light coffee and background brown sugar. Almost honey like initial malty sweetness. Body is very full and creamy. The finish has a great lingering coffee with a hint of molasses. Very good porter, not too heavy, but very complete.
Pours black with a thin tan head. Nice roasted malt and coffee aroma. Good roasted malt and bitter chocolate flavors. A hint of fruit in there too. Body thickens up nicely as it warms. Good porter.

I thought this beer was quite good; it was the name says, a quite robust porter.  Lots of very dry roastiness with some bitterness and some nice accompanying flavors.  Very good.

It pours black with a tall root beer-like head which was tan in color and demonstrated some durability.  Aroma was lots of dry roastiness with some measure of toffee, coffee, and chocolate smells.  The first flavor that hits you is a big amount of bitterness brought on by just how much dry roastiness there is in the flavor which is accompanied by some chalky mouthfeel, followed with a sweeter and smoother finish.  About half-way down the glass, the mouthfeel seem smoother and slicker as well.

I thought this beer was quite good, and i would recommend it as a very fine (dry) porter.  I bought this bottle at Woodmans in Oak Creek.

Pours a blackish red with a thin tan head. Malty aroma with lots of coffee and roasted grain. The coffee flavor overpowers the taste, but some malt manages to peak through to give it some balance. Finishes dry roasty and clean.
Very good offering from Smuttynose here...  Nice, dark, and full of roasted malt and chocolate flavors, I found this to be a really good porter and one I could drink quite easily again.

UPDATED: MAY 31, 2008 (USA) Black color with a thin tan head. The aroma is of dry fruit / coffee with a smoky chocolate taste. Well blended brew with a dry bitter finish !!! pretty good porter, And i think the name is very funny too !!

3-13-08 bottle shared with lb4lb thanks to kmweaver and ahatcher78!! 

Black pour with a light tan head and good lacing.  Smell is subtle roasted malt and milk chocolate.  Flavor is roasted malt and sweet bitter coffee.  Great body - one of the best bodied porters Ive had.  Rather, one of the best porters Ive had.  A bit underplayed in the aroma and flavor but overall, a winner!

UPDATED: FEB 18, 2010 Rated 6/3/04.  Notes. Black in color with a nice tan head and an okay amount of lace left behind. The aroma is pretty nice; theyve got a coffee/chocolate thing going on which shines in the flavor as well. Somewhat dry with thickening malt and some roasty bitterness. Not bad.
Bottle.  Pours a dark black with a pretty small dark tan head.  Pretty much a huge coffee/roast bomb!  Very good though, especially when paired with chocolate.

Bottle courtesy of Stine. Thanks, Eben!

Gorgeous Porter. Fully opaque with a huge tan head. At least 3 fingers thick and densely packed with bubbles, looks creamy as hell. Tremendous retention and phenomenal cobweb lacing. Some Imp Stouts wish they could look this good. Nose is chalky, full of chocolate and roasted beans, dark malts and grounds, with a hint of vanilla and licorice. Damn good smelling beer as well. Fore holds all of the elements of the aroma, chocolate and coffee mainly, but also vanilla and roasted malts. Its a bit of a step down from the intensity of the aroma, but still nicely done. Back end is very roasty and with a budding chocolate presence. Medium-full bodied, perfectly creamy mouthfeel for the style. Finish picks up some hop astringency, to go along with the sweetness and roasted notes that are present everywhere else. Great brew.
Dark brown with a decent tan head. Aromas are of malt, coffe and dark chocolate. Flavors are roasted malts, coffee, chocolate, and grapes.

Another quirky photo from Smuttynose on the label.  The brew is dark brown with a tan, one-finger head, and a sweet, malty aroma.  This is a full-flavored Yankee porter with a strong coffee taste.  Solid maltyness, but not syrupy sweet.  Well-hopped too.  Nothing to gripe about in this fulfilling, well-blended beer - except perhaps the Starbucksian dominance of the flavor with coffee.
Strong malt with slight amount of old wood taste and chocolate. Dark brown color with a medium tan head. Mildy tangy bitter malts to start with a chocolate after taste. Creamy palate

Bottles from kmweaver and ahatcher78, thanks!!

Pours dark black with a rich short lived brown head.  Smell is roasty chocolately malt.  Nice and rich.  
Taste is equally if not more rich, dark and roasty and lightly bittered to perfectly balance.  Full bodied and just the perfect palate for a porter with light to moderate carbonation.  Light burnt roasty notes and some coffee flavors appear without it being a coffee beer.  Some light hops and dusty chocolate in the finish.  What an incredible and drinkable porter this is.  Up there with Troegs Dead Reckoning, and Nogne O Porter for my absolute favorites in the style, and otherwise.

(Bottle 35,5 cl) Vintage 2004. Pours opaque black with a small, light brown head. Vinous, delicios aroma with dried fruits and some burned malt. Medium body with hard roasted malt notes, a little metal and ashes but also pleasant rounded notes of dried fruit. Dry finish with a discreet malt bitterness. 120308

Bottle:  Beautiful dark brown pour with a large, creamy tan head.  Abundant roasted malt, coffee, and chocolate aromas.  Off to a great start!  Creamy mouthful with plentiful chocolate and espresso notes, but still plenty of roastiness.  Ever so slight bittersweetness.  An excellent porter.  Thanks to Imadeadguy for sending this want list item.

Bottle. Roasted malt aroma with coffee and chocolate. Flavor becomes all that more roasted, coffee filled, and chocolatey. All the roastedness remains luscious and powerful without ever becoming overbearing or soiling the palate. Strong throughout. Fine, fine beer.

Dark pour, tan three finger head
chocolate aromas mixed with dark fruits and some malt
tastes of bittersweet chocolate, dry finish

pours a dark almost opaque brown with a tannish brown head.  aroma of cocoa, coffee, sweet malt, and some earthy notes.  taste is chocolately, a bit milky, coffee, roasty malt, subtle sweetness.  mid-full bodied with a bubbly, foamy mouthfeel.  nice bitterish choco-coffee bitter tail end.  really nice!  will definitely buy again (if i ever see it around here again!).  it might be a little too chocolate milk for some, and a bit too sweet for others.  i thought it was excellent though, full of flavor.  not overly complex, but a really nice session brew.

UPDATED: MAR 4, 2008 1st Porter, and I can say this might be the last...Several hrs later Im changing my analysis.  Its not the style for me, xxx OK!!! This is an unbelievable beer exp.  Its truly all those things I said, at least at first, Later its unbelievable.  I cant stop drinking it..  Even with that said it was technically sound, xxx It f*ckin righteous.  The aroma is very complex, with hints of coffee, malt, and wine scents.  Its appearance is gorgeous.  Its dark as burnt sugar.  Its flavor is mega complex, with notes of chocolate, coffee, malt, and fruit charachters.  The only part that makes this not a grandslam is its hoppy quality, hours later its not noticable, I could drink this to it disappears, or until my blood stops moving.    I would definitely recommend this to anyone, but if you are like me who is a bit turned off by bitter it may turn you off, but not if you get a chance to really warm up to it.
Bottle. Dark amber color, brown head. Roasted coffee and cocoa aroma, tar and licorice notes. Roasted salty cocoa flavor, tar and chocolate. Quite bitter finish.

Thick solid black pour with a brown head. Rich chocolate and roast aroma  with plum, leather and smoke. Vinous, slightly sour, acrid malt flavor, burnt with some hops. Full palate. Flavorful, lingering finish. Nice.

UPDATED: JUL 22, 2008 This beer is toasty at the very start. The flavor has a burnt wood flavor with many other standard flavors in the port categories. The malts are nice and the hops are secondary but this is a great beer to have.

6/22/08-
2nd try, still has is character yet the its a bit fizzy and still smokey.

The aroma is toasty, with a sweet smoky element, earth, and cola. The appearance is dark brown with a tan head. The flavor is like the aroma. The palate is smooth and oily. Overall this is disappointing but not bad.
Dark brown pour. Lots of malt and coffee hints. Somewhat thick body, with a real nice finish. Excellent porter imo!
user_location: back in NJ!, New Jersey, USA

text: July 2006 - A good beer. Nice head, nice lacing, nice aroma. Flavor was dark roast, some lactic flavor and a twang of citrus bitterness. Smooth silk mouthfeel. Nice.

12 oz. bottle at Akkurat, Stockholm. Black with small tan head. Malty and roasty aroma with coffee, leather, chocolate and black currant. Sweetish rich malty and roasty flavor with coffee, bitter chocolate and dark fruits. Strongly roasty yet soft and balaced, excellent!
Foam Rangers January meeting. Dark black with brown head. Nose is roasted malts and fresh coffee. Dark chocolate and espresso taste with hops at the end. Another nice beer from Smuttynose.

12 oz bottle shared at Foam Rangers club meeting.  Pours dark with a light brown head.  Nice aroma of coffee and roasty malt.  Taste is of coffee.  Mouthfeel was medium-to-thin with a little carbonation and good bitter finish.

Bottle. Appearance: Opaque black, deep brown head. Aroma: Smoky roasted malt, coffee beans and dark chocolate. Palate: Thinner than I expected but still not bad. Flavor: Roasted smoky malt, espresso, dark bittersweet chocolate, all balanced by a nice little hoppy bite. Overall: Enjoyed this one a lot. By first beer from Smuttynose.

12 ouncer from glenville beverage. black as night. Tan head. Tastes of coffee and toffee. Palate is nice, not much carbonation is what I like. Smooth going down. Just what the style should be. Nice job.

Wow at first sniff I knew this brew would be a definite winner. Pours jet black with  copious frothy tan head. Toasty aromas of caramel and hops- not unusually complex but to the point and delicious. The flavour is where this porter really shines. Toasty malt and well integrated hops define this rich and complex brew. A little astringent on the hop aspect- but other than that this is a true porter- and a damn good on at that.
pours deep rich dark with tan head.  Malted coffee aroma and a hint of chocolate.  A gliding taste over the tongue of earthy malted hops and chocolate flavored coffee.  A very enjoyable beer.

bottle.  pours an average black with a nice small tan head that lasts throughout.  very pleasant malty and coffee aromas.  flavors of coffee, chocolate and roasted malts dominate this porter.  smooth over the palate with a medium body lacking carbonation... the flavors flow right over the tongue and finish with a bitter malty aftertaste.  wonderful porter - get it if you can.
Bottle (last year sometime...).  Pours dark brown, with a tan head and good lacing.  Creamy chocolate aroma, flavor similar, with some coffee, and a roasty bitter finish.  Very tasty.

12 oz bottle...very dark brown, cocoa head...milk chocolate aroma, makes me want marshmallows, oh thats because they subtly taunt me in the aroma...yummy flavors of chocolate and mocha, I cant stoop thinking about marshmallows, for some reason.....slight bitter essences, especially on the finish....some lacing, thick for a porter (robust it is)....chalky chocolate\te finish, in a good way...body is medium and soothing, tasty brew!..

Bottle from Whole Foods Market, New York. Very dark brown with a small beige head. Chocolate malt aroma overlaid by some earthy sourness. Sweet chocolate taste with a darkly bitter finish. Very drinkable; behind the bitterness is a pleasant, light fruitiness.

Pours black with a 2 finger light cocoa head that retains a laces sheets nicely. Smells of roasted malt, molassas and bit of hop. Taste is delicious. Big malt, molassas, a hint of coffee grounds and a little hop bite at the end. Medium in the mouth with a nice tickle from carbonation. Awesome drinkability. A nice robust porter full of great flavors. Try it and enjoy

Inviting aroma doesnt follow through in the flavor, but a solid, well-done porter nonetheless. Average size tan head. Dark brown to black body. The nose is filled with toasted and roasted malts, coffee and chocolate with notes of resin. The flavor is lightly sweet, moderately bitter and noderately to heavily acidic. Soft carbonation and a creamy texture. Medium body. Finishes dry and bitter.

Black pour, medium tan head that stays. Aroma is coffee, bittersweet chocolate. Flavor is coffee, sweet chocolate, a touch of raisen, caramel sweetness, and a roasty finish. Creamy mouthfeel with lots of carbonation but an easy finish. Just a good easy drinking porter.

Bottle: Black as night pour with a thin mocha head.  The nose is right on, with a great balance of citrusy hops and roasted malts.  The body starts slightly acidic, with then opens up with lots of coffee and chocolate.  Finishes with a mild bitterness that keeps this in check.  Very good.
Bottle.  Nice dark brown pour.  Aroma of coffee, burnt toast and bitter chocolate.  Smooth taste with a nice bitter hop finish.  Excellent affordable porter.

UPDATED: DEC 28, 2007 12oz Bottle: Dark brown in color w/ a nice brown head that leaves nice lacing behind. Deep roasted malt aroma w/ hints of chocolate. Major dark roasted malt flavor. Coffee, chocolate & just enough hops to even the score. Feels very heavy in the mouth. Honestly, I was very surprised w/ just how "robust" this beer is. Very well done Smutty.

Pours to a very dark brown/almost black color with a thick dark brown head thatr lingered thru mid-glass and left very good lacing on the glass. Smooth malty aroma of chocolate, coffee and a hint of caramel. The taste emphasized the sweet chocolate as well, but with enough hops to provide enough offset to keep from being too sweet. Full bodied with a somewhat warming finish, makes this a darn good beer.

Nice, nostalgic label too.

This was definetly a robust beer. It poured almost black with a thick creamy brown head that left some really nice lacing throughout the drinking. First thought was this looks like a really good stout. It was very appealing visually. There was a nice rich chocolate and espresso aroma with a malty fragrance. The flavor was a smokey bittersweet chocolate and espresso. The finish was slightly bitter, dry and metalic and the flavor lasted for a good long finiish

Bottle.  Dark brown pour with a frothy beige head.  Striped lacing.  Aromas of chocolate, coffee and toffee, mostly creamy with a bit of roast.  Flavor of  dark chocolate malts with a nice charred edge.  Richly flavored with an earthy underpinning.   Some minerally notes as well.  Full bodied and smooth.  Really nice overall.

Pours an rich black colour with small tan head. Nose of roasted malts, coffee, dark fruits, and soy sauce. Initial taste is rich with a creamy deep roasted coffee. Dark fruits lingering. Finshing heavily roasted and chocolate. Bitter hops make their presence very well. Well balanced. Fair amount of carbonation but didnt draw anything away from this brew. Palate duration is excellent with Decent head retention and lacing of the glass. Medium body. Dry finish and goes down so quick that I went grab a sip and it was already gone. Very good porter.

Pours black and dark leaving a dark brown ring for a head. Aroma is lightly roasted malts, with a touch of coffee and chocolate to boot. Taste is very rich, full of roasted coffee, leather, and soil notes. This is a really flavorful porter. This drinks more like a stout but with a lighter and cleaner mouthfeel. What a great porter from a brewery that has yet to dissapoint me. Cant say enough good things about this porter, one of my best porter experiences so far.

12 oz bottle.  Dark brown with a frothy tan head.  Nose of grapes and brown sugar.  Medium light body, light fizzy carb.  Dark roast coffee and chocolate.  Dry, hoppy finish.  Soild, but unspectacular.

Aroma carried a hint of licorice with some roast notes, it was very lovely, nice combination.  poured dark and thick like used motor oil and left a nice tan head on the beer.  flavor was really nice.  some roast, coffee, chcoclate, and a hint of licorice and anise.  very nice velvety palate.  a well done porter.

12oz. bottle into pint glass. Pours a thick, dark brown with a medium tan head that laces nicely. Heavy aromas of roasted malts, coffee beans, chocolate and a hint of caramel. Flavor is excellent with a great balance of roasted malts, and thick coffee hints with a mild toffee sweetness to finish. Mouthfeel is thick and robust. Good job Smuttynose!

UPDATED: JUN 10, 2008 Bottle thanks to artusory.  Pours a deep brown color with a nice beige head that diminishes quickly.  Aroma of roasted malts and some chocolate, with a hint of coffee as well.  Ah, a delightful taste.  Just the right mix of roasted malts, coffee, and chocolate combined with just the right amount of bite.  Nice, easy-drinking porter that is what its name suggests, robust.  Thanks a lot Ryan.
12oz, thanks BMartin, this one is great, taste is spot on for a porter, easy drinking malty chocolate roasty everything i want.... downed this bottle mighty quick... it was good.

Impressive!  Bottle.  Deep dark brown with a tan head. Heavy aroma of malts, hops, chocolate, and maybe espresso.  Taste is a complex combination of chocolate, malts, hops and coffee/espresso.  One of the better porters Ive ever had.

Pours a beautiful dark brown color into the English Pint.  A quick inch of tan head left a coating of lace on the glass.  The scent was of chocolate, barley, malt and espresso.  A big coffee taste accompany the malt presence.  Robust is an excellent way to describe this porter.  A rich and full mouthfeel and thick and full play on the palate.
12oz bottle. Pours dark brown in color with brown head. Aroma chocolate, coffee and lite hops. Taste strong coffee and bitter chocolate with bitter finsih.
Draft. Pours dark w/lots of head, some bitterness and coffee tasting and a bit of malts.
Robust is an understatement.  A perfect porter rich in roasted malts which gives way to a satisfyingly bitter aftertaste that hints at chocolate and coffee.

pours real dark brown, almost black, small medium brown head...head dissipates quickly but leaves some lacing...smoky malt and coffee aroma....taste of roasted malts and charcoal, charred nuts...very enjoyable for this style

Pours dark brown with a hint of lacing in the form of tan bubbles.  Smells of chocolate, pepper, some coffee.  Tastes of chocolate and roasted malt with some underlying bitterness.  Okay, but where are the dark fruit hints that are supposed to be common to this style?
Black color with tan head.  Roasted chocolate aroma and flavor with some coffee bean and dark fruit (cherry?) hint.  Dry but certainly not hoppy.  Medium to thin body.
Very crisp finish. Black brown with white creamy head. Much carbonation with smoothness. Good all around porter.
Cask @ GBBF 07. Pours black with decent sized head. Chocolate / smokey / coffee aroma. Roast / coffee flavour on the palate with bitter malty finish.

Pours pitch black with a nice sized tan head. Nose is dusty chocolate. Beautiful. Flavor is smooth and hearty and never waivers. Nice even malt characters with a smokey, dirty edge. Feel is great. Nice and appropriate leel of bubble on the tongue. Thicker liquid feel. Definitely drinkable. A good example of the style.
I love that this beer stinks and tastes like dirt...It has a very earthy flavor...like eating a fuckin graveyard.

Pours very smoothly with a small darker head, similar to a whole grain bread.  Has a bitter edge toward the middle-front of the tongue.  Tastes of roasted coffee with a hint of dark chocolate.  Overall, a very nice porter.
Black black beer with nice looking tan head.  The smell is of coffee which extends to the taste as well.  I really this beer.

Cask @ GBBF 2007. Pours a black color with a small tan head. Roasted malty chocolate and coffee aroma. Roasted malty coffee and chocolate flavor with some hoppy hints. Long roasted malty finish with a hoppy bitter aftertaste.

From bottle. Aroma of roasted malt and coffee. Pours like silk, dark with a brown bread head. Smooth texture, coffee. I felt the flavour faded quickly. Left a weird film texture behind. Still a good stout.

The scant aroma is somewhat chocolatey. Appears practically opaque in the glass, with no foam, just a thin ring of bubbles. The chocolate taste predominates up front, giving way to a more coffee-like bitterness.  Feels substantial but not heavy on the palate.  Overall, falls awkwardly in between traditional porter and stout.

Nice black color with tan head.  Candied sugar malts are apparent as well as roasted coffee/tofee and chocolate malt aromas.   The taste itself is a dusty smoked taste with quiet but persistant smoked chocolate flavor.

Cask gravity @ GBBF 2007, London. Dark black color with a small to average, frothy, fair lacing, mostly lasting, light brown head. Aroma is moderate malty, dark chocolate, moderate hoppy, pine, grapefruit. Flavor is moderate sweet and  bitter with a average to long duration. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is flat to soft.

Bottle.  Aroma a rich chocolate and toasty-roast with a firm but still subtle nuttiness.  Really a lot of strong scents here - coffee, a kind of starch cardboard, wood, slight bitter hops.  Opaque black pour (not-light-sucking, but still opaque) with a pretty, light brown head.  Crisp, medium-strong bitter attack on first tasting - activates and pushes the salivary glands into overdrive!  We want more!  Bitter coffee and bitter gourmet dark chocolate (though to a lesser degree) taste, roasty and salty with a nice overall malt-hop balance.  Faint touch of currant and a very nice, rounded, natural espresso flavor.  Medium-full body, smooth on whole (excepting the crisp beginning) with a dryish, nutty, salty aftertaste (somewhat reminiscent of licorice, though the edible kind).  Very robust, and yet at only 5.7% abv, not one you have to think twice about.  One of my new favorites (up there with Alpha Klaus, and thats high praise) - this is an amazing porter!

Date: 02/10/2006
Mode: Bottle
Source: Trade

dark brown, thin fine tan head, rich chocolate aroma, lots of balanced chocolate and roasted flavor, light roasted bitterness, mostly dry, 

Aroma: 6/10; Appearance: 6/10; Flavor: 6/10; Palate: 5/10; Overall: 10/20
Rating: 2.8/5.0Drinkability: 7/10
Score: *4

[email protected]/* <![CDATA[ */!function(t,e,r,n,c,a,p){try{t=document.currentScript||function(){for(t=document.getElementsByTagName('script'),e=t.length;e--;)if(t[e].getAttribute('data-cfhash'))return t[e]}();if(t&&(c=t.previousSibling)){p=t.parentNode;if(a=c.getAttribute('data-cfemail')){for(e='',r='0x'+a.substr(0,2)|0,n=2;a.length-n;n+=2)e+='%'+('0'+('0x'+a.substr(n,2)^r).toString(16)).slice(-2);p.replaceChild(document.createTextNode(decodeURIComponent(e)),c)}p.removeChild(t)}}catch(u){}}()/* ]]> */ Dark brown colour, small brown head. Aroma is roasted malts and very hoppy with some slight black coffee added. Flavour is roasted malts along with flowery hops and slight dark coffee. I was not that amazed by this one.
Pours black with a light brown head. Roasted malt aroma. Full bodied with hints of chocolate, vanilla, and coffee. Nicely balanced beer.

UPDATED: JUN 15, 2009 Cask-GBBF. Black with a small, but lasting white head. Fruity, hoppy and roast aroma. Dry, roast and bitter.

Bottled: Hops are more pronounced, from a citrus aroma to a very bitter aftertaste.

Bottle with expiration date of October 2007.  Pours a rich black with a brown head.  Not much foam or lacing but still a nice color.  Light chocolate and hops are evident in the scent. Solid mouth feel.  There was what I like to describe as a "belch-factor."  Most craft brews dont make me burp but this one did. I usually knock it the flavor rating down a tenth of a point when that happens.  Both otherwise a solid, likeable brew.
UPDATED: DEC 25, 2007 12 oz bottle. deep dark almost black color with a nice brown head. hops and chocolate armoa. delicious tasting, chocolate and molasses, smooth and tasty. Realy enjoyed this!

Bottle purchased at Ds Six Pax. Pours black brown, khaki colored head. Aroma is pine, anise, chocolate, molasses, coffee. The aroma is almost like an imperial stout. Flavor is smoky, creamy bitter chocolate, meat, pine, anise. The aroma of this beer is strong but the flavor is quite smooth and mellow in comparison. In my opinion, this is a nice example of a decent porter.
Aug. 18, 2007; 12 oz. bottle.  Full-bodied, full-flavored, with an unusually-healthy dose of hops.  Not too sweet.  Coffee & chocolate (dark) notes, as advertised. A delicious porter.

Cask gravity at GBBF 2007.  Black with tan head.  Its hoppier than the average porter, good dark bitter choc, espresso coffee, a bit like the Laurelwood Tree Hugger Porter, but more juicy in the mouth, less wide.  Its good.  A hoppy choccy porter.
Cask GBBF ... Deep black ... little hop little roast malts nose ... Very hoppy ... little iodine ... some roast ... but mostly hop. DIdnt work for me but still quite drinkable.

Gravity, GBBF. Black, small but very sticky tan head. Coffee roast aroma with a really fresh citrus note--dark chocolate orange bar dipped in espresso. Flavor is a stunning blend of pithy fresh citrus and chocolate roast, rose petals around the edges. Such an interesting combination of flavors! The pleasures of an IPA and porter in one glass.

A Mes rate: 
Gravicask at GBBF. Black with a tan head. Soft and roasty with plenty of coffee and chocolate. Hops in the finish add a lovely balance. Straight down the line but a jolly tasty porter.

bottle.  black with minimal head (large bubbles). sweet chocolate aroma.  body looks thin but has a substantial mouth feel.  chocolate and espresso with moderate bitter.  smoothed significantly as it warmed. very slight acidic bitter aftertaste.  im new to porters but i enjoyed this one quite a bit.  there wasnt much to the flavor outside the choc and bitter coffee but those flavors were rich and the overall taste was smooth.

Bottle Very dark brown pour with minimal head. Aroma of roasted (almost burnt) malts. Flavor follows with a bit of coffee and chocolate. Id say more of a dry stout than porter. Thick flavor, thin mouthfeel. Above par, but not incredible.

12 ounce bottle in pint glass.  Pours brown/black with lasting dense brown head and awesome lace.   Aroma of roasted chocolate chip cookies.   Very nice, very flavorful chocolate, slight coffee, mild fruitiness, with a great dry bitter finish.  This is a great session porter.
350 mL bottle.  Dark brown with a tan head.  Roasted malt and chocolate aroma.  Strong chocolate and coffee taste.  Quite good.

UPDATED: MAR 29, 2013 (Bottle) Aroma a creamy roast, some vanilla manifests itself.  Dark, with a little foamy head--more head than I usually see on a Porter.  This Porter strikes me as a bit more stout-like than most porters.  Flavour: not very bitter.  Too sweet, but without the caramel taste that I like in many Porters.  Some roast emerges, a burnt tone here or there.  Some of the smoothness of a stout is present too.  Eh...I think this one falls short of the real top-notch Porters.  Its a good beer but it doesnt pack the punch that it ought to.  There is not enough bitterness...and theres too much of the burned flavor.  If the burnt flavor were diminished and replaced by more hops, this would be a top-notch brew.

Note: I drank this again, YEARS later (almost 6 years to be specific) and it was a completely different beer.  Much more bitter, much more roast, and less sweet.  But still, I would prefer hops.  I cant say which I prefer.  Has my perception changed, or did this beer really change that much?
Bottle.  Nice aroma, much nicer then the actual flavor, coffee, chocolate, dark fruit.  Pours nice and dark not muck head.  Flavors of bittersweet chocolate and unsweetened coffee.
Bottle shared with fordest. Dark roasted chocolate and a nice light fruit and coffee flavor.

Very dark pour with a decent head from this 12 oz bottle I got from bstill.  Lots of chocolate and dried fruit on the aromas.  Flavors delved way more into the bitter as the sweetness was all but lost.  Pretty Good.
First impression: this very black, deep roasted brew should be call a stout.  The body or palate is just a little on the thin side.

Very fine porter. A rich and potent aroma of chocolate and roasted malts is immediately present. Lustrous dark brew with a substantial head, it also has a thick mouthfeel with a nice heavy coffee taste. Almost headed in the direction of a robust breakfast stout. Mighty good stuff, Smutty.

Smuttynose Robust Porter is black as the Ace of Spades with a creamy, frothy, light sandy brown head that is mostly diminishing.  It leaves excellent lacing.  The aroma is of roasted malt, dark chocolate and dark coffee.  There are light notes of resin and possibly vanilla and smoke.  It is medium to full bodied and dry.  The carbonation is soft and its slightly astringent at the finish.  The primary flavor is deep dark malt with dark chocolate and coffee and a good dose of resiny hops.  There are perhaps elements that lean toward nuts and cola.  It is well rounded and not extreme in any way.  This is a mature and refined porter.  Its pretty much what I think a porter should taste like.  Bravo!
Bacon and feet aroma. Black-brown pour with a thick tan head, excellent glass coating. Tastes of crisp, burned bacon and coffee. Espresso finish. Delicious!

A miniature black hole in a bottle. Shine a flashlight through and you see a dark crimson color. A cute light-brown head adorns the black hole. Smell was detectable as soon as the cap came off: chocolate, malt, and... nuts? Flavor is very very nice. Heavily roasted and "deep". No astringency throughout the entire glass; all smooth melted cocoa beans. With other porters Ive had, theres always something funky with the taste, but sip after sip was yumyum. Changed my mind about porters.

poured an opapaque black color with a 1/2 inch thick head. smells of raisons, chocolate, and coffee. Tastes of Coffee and dark chocolate. Sweet. Nice smooth and complex! Really enjoyed drinking this beer!
I liked it.  Robust it is.  Smooth flavor of chocolate malt and malty bitternes that almost feels like a weak stout.  Nice seeet and smooth finish cool black look with a head that stays.  Nice!

Pours cola-black with the slightest of ruby hues... almost opaque.  The head is large and sudsy, deep tan, and sticks with frothy lacing to the glass.  Roasts, alcohol, dark fruit, malt, chocolate, coffee, tobacco and toffee in the nose.  Flavor is a bit strong here.  I get roasted barley, bitter chocolate, tobacco, hops, coffee and dark cherries.  The finish is spot on for a dark chocolate truffle.  The mouthfeel is slick and buttery, with a proper amount of cream and bite.  This one is pungent to the palate and quite complex.

12 oz. bottle from beastiefan2k.  Pour is a deep reddish brown with a medium khaki head and a slight bit of lacing / settling.  Aroma is sweet roasted malt, quite strong could actually pick it up from about 12 inches away.  Beginning is the roasted malt, though much more coffee in it than the nose would suggest.  About halfway through there is a quick blast of sour, than a bit of sweetness, and back to a very nice roasty finish.  Wow, what a tour of taste!  Even some hop highlights.  The finish is very dry, almost like an aged whisky.  Overall, a very good beer.  Thanks again Eugene, this was a treat.

Appearance: Dark brown, nearly black, with a dense, foamy mocha-colored head which slowly settled over the next few minutes.

Smell: Malty with currents of sweet chocolate and roasted coffee beans running throughout. Faint fruity scent, as well.

Taste: Like a demitasse of espresso served with a small square of chocolate melted within. Caramel. Grains. Hops are piney and they blend quite well with the other flavors. A touch sour. Lingering dry roasty finish. 

Will you people please just relax for two seconds? All the rich flavors will come together perfectly, trust me.

Mmm. There. Delish!

Mouthfeel: Nice and creamy. Just a hair above medium in body (medium-plus?). Carbonation remains light.

Drinkability: The first and only porter claiming to be "robust" that really delivered for me. Im positively nonplussed with amazement. But also saddened by the fact that I cant regularly get this in Georgia. Plenty of flavor, well-balanced, and extreme drinkability make this an outstanding brew. 

Other porters beware! Cuz theres a new sherriff a-comin.

5/11/2007:  Smuttynose Robust Porter pours a clear, very dark brown color (near black really).  The initial foamy brown head gives way to a lasting foamy crown after it slowly collapses down.  The aroma is rich and malty and contains chocolate malt, mocha cream, and a deep, smooth alcohol presence.  Very inviting!  The flavor is rish, robust, and complex, but controlled and not overwhelming.  At first the flavor is slightly sweet.  Bittersweet chocolate, hints of coffee and cream, and a dark chocolate bitterness arose the tastebuds.  Ther eis a deep, soft fruity quality as well as hints of well-integrated alcohol that run throughout the flavor as well.  The overall bitterness is balanced and has a blend of semi-sweet and dark chocolate flavor to it.  The finish is lengthy and roasty.  All of this flavor is contained within the medium-full body of this beer.  The palate is smooth and creamy.  Smuttynose Robust Porter is a great representation of a robust porter!

12 oz bottle (5.7% Alcohol By Volume) via trade with illinismitty in December 2006.  Thanks for picking up a bottle of this beer for me during your travels last year.  I appreciate it!
Pours light body black with tan head.  Great roasted malt and coffee aroma.  Taste is slightly musty with good malt, coffee, brown sugar and molasses... but not sweet.

12oz bottle coutesy of  cbkschubert, Craig gave me this one for hosting a gathering at the house. Aroma was like walking in to a musty bar room or that you would get waling into a liquer store in the west. Black body with dark chocolate head. Good lacing and head covered the top of body thoughout beer. Carbination noticable along with some sweetness and tobacco. Mild to medium sweet dry tobacco leaf on palate . Thanks, Craig.

12 oz. bottle. Consumed at cellar temperature. Poured a beautiful oily black with tan frothy head that did not last long. Not much lace. Nose is of roasted malt and mild coffe. A bit bitter at first. Taste is of coffee, espresso, molasses, brown sugar. I loved it. Mildly bitter aftertaste. Did I mention I loved it.

What a nicely brewed Porter.   Big nose of roasted barley, chocolate, and espresso.   The pour is a gorgeous oily black with a tan head.   Some robustness in flavor initially suggests this might be a baltic porter...but the texture is somewhat thinner and less assertive.   The burnt and roasty flavors are complex and exceptionally well melded.

12 oz brown bottle purchased at the Beer Store in Moon.  Interesting label, black & white old time photo with a strongman holding some circus chick.  Pop the lid and you get that aroma of stout or porter, you know, roasty and burned wood. I must admit, it is a little milder smelling than most stronger porters. The color is opaque dark brown or black and there is a thin ring around the inside of the glass for a head. Barely any lacing around the inside of the glass as you drink. The taste has a bitter impact almost like a Baltic or imperial porter.  A little more personality than I care for in a porter.  The alky content is a little up front on the flavor, not quite in your face, but getting there. If I didnt see the % on this site, I would think it to be about 7%.  The carbonation is sparse but present, could use a bit more. Upon finishing this brew I get a back of your throat medium bitterness that hangs for a few moments. This brew could take some lessons in etiquette from Yuenglings black & tan or East End Pink Cloud.  On par with  Weyerbacher Black Hole Ale and JW Dundees Porter.
user_location: Beaver Valley, Beaver County, Pennsylvania, USA

text: This deep dark color has the coffee and malt aromas that turn into a deep roasted coffee flavor on the mouthfeel.  Notes of dark chocolate are more pronoumnced in the finish.  This porter almost drinks like a stout!

Sample at Firewaters in Atlantic City. Dark brown color with a medium light tan head and streaks of lacing. Coffee, hops and a touch of chocolate in the nose.  Rich body with a well-balanced array of flavors from bitter coffee and hops to roasted malt and chocolate. The finish is dry with a roasted coffee flavor and lingering hops. Pretty good all around.
yum. pours black, nice consistency, with a dark tan head. Lots of chocalate, coffee, blakc patent malt going on in the flavor with some pnw hops in the background. Liked this one very much.

I know its rated high and everything, but this did nothing for me.  No complexity at all, just straightforward, toasted grains.  There is some light smoke in the aroma, and flavor has just a little coffee, grains, and a dry, chalky finish. Not as thick as I would like, but a nice, black appearance.  Head fades quickly.

Light coffee on the nose.  Dark brown/black body with lots of quickly faiding brown head.  A solid porter with coffee and faint chocolate hints.  Had a dry smokey finish with a chalky aftertaste that would prevent me from drinking this otherwise solid beer again.

12oz bottle.  Opaque and brown.  Spotty beige head.  Anise and cocoa with a nice roasted nose.  Brownie aroams.  Rather full bodied.  Roasty malts with rich chocolate and toffee flavors.  Sticky finish with medium dryness.  Good coffee note.  Good sticky character.  Good dose of hops found lingering amongst the bitter and slight alcohol middle.  Well done.  Very good drinking.

Thanks to Brewfiend for sharing this one. Picked up single bottle at The Coffee Grounds in Eau Claire, WI. Pours a dark opaque brown brew with a light tan head. Aroma is heavy malt, chocolate, some coffee, nuts, cookie dough. Taste is a little metalic, slight carbonation, and a little bitter aftertaste. The cocoa aftertaste sticks around a while after the finish.
Dark brown body, beautiful tan head, chocolate nose. Balanced chocolate, coffee, brown bread and moderate bitterness in body; long finish. Nice.

I really liked this brew.  Poured a deep brown, with a creamy brownish head, that lasted a mighty long time.  Very strong roasted, choclate/coffee flavor with a slightly bitter finish (although smooth overall).  I would go for this beer again and again and again.

12oz bottle from MrBendo.  Aroma:  Nice roast upfront with some chocolate, coffee, nuts, and some sweet creaminess.  A good dose of hops with a good pine nose.  Appearance:  Very dark brown in color.  Light tan head was full and foamy with great retention.  Great lacing.  Flavor:  Roasty malt up front with some graham cracker, nuts, coffee, and chocolate.  Creamy sweetness intensifies at it warms.  Some pine and light citrus hops into the finish.  Hoppiness carries over into the bitterness, as well.  Palate:  Medium bodied.  Moderate carbonation.  Overall:  Great robust porter.  Nice balance of malt and hops that allows both to shine through.  Would drink a ton of this if I could.

12 oz Bottle: Pours a deep color, almost black with a light brown consistent head. Very aromatic Porter. Great quality roasty malts with tons of chocolate & coffee. Theres also a surprisingly hoppy character in the background. Body is extremely smooth with a creamy texture. Nice roasty malts give off a Bosco Chocolate Sauce flavor. The nice hop character to this Porter balances the malt nicely. It also gives it a subtle fruity note of orange peel. Theres also walnut hints. The finish is a nice balance of roasted espresso beans and hop bitterness. This is a great hoppy Porter.

very good for the style. a lot of interesting things going on here. chocolate, french roast...with smoke?  pours real good in the 16 oz titan glass.  not particularly my thing. nice seperation of malt and hop. cool  march and october sipper . that thinness makes this a really artsy brew.

12oz - thanks beastiefan2k - This one had the honor of being the brew I fell asleep with after the Hotshotz tasting.  Aroma is roasty chocolate malt, cream and hops.  Pours black with a big foamy head and great lacing.  Flavor matches aroma.  Palate is a little thin but otherwise quite good.  Not a bad tasting porter I regret not giving a fair shake to.

12 oz bottle from the variety pack.  Nice thick brown head, an aroma that leaps right up at you .  Roasted chocolate taste, a little on the gritty side.  This is a porter for serious porter drinkers, not the SA Holiday Porter or Saranac Carmel Porter crowd.  More hoppy bitterness than one would expect in a porter.

12 oz bottle traded with drewbeerme.  Pours black with a tall fluffy tan head that collapses with a thick forest of lacing.  Chocolate roast aromas, well of course, maybe a little nutty but thats about it.  The flavor is initially sweet but quickly turns into dark chocolate and bitter roasted coffee that lingers for a long while.  Pretty tasty porter.
Great stuff. Pours very dark with an amazingly thick head. Aroma is super roasty and sweet. Flavor somewhat lactic, but then dominates with roasted bitterness and sweetness.

12oz bottle, notched @ M for March from 46er3498, thank you Tom!  Near as I can tell this brew is black with a 1/2 finger slowly fading brown head.  Aroma is charred wood, roasted malts, some milk chocolate, and some light piney hops.  I typed up the flavor and realized it was exactly the same in the exact same amounts--not ungodly complex, but really good.  Semidry roasty finish.  Medium body with moderate to high carbonation.  Very good brew.
user_location: Ocean Beach, San Diego, California, USA

text: very smores-y.  some roasted marshmellow, milk chocolate, graham cracker, with some rich thick medium roast coffee with some toffee and some whipped creamy mouthfeel.  yum

A kind of fall campfire beer.  Very close to black.  Stoutish chocolate mousse head.  Marginally woody aroma with tones of roasted malt.  Charcoal and tobacco taste with understated notes of vanilla cola and red fruit.  Dark and satisfying, nearly full-bodied but quite easy to drink.

12oz bottle drank from a pint glass.
Pours a dark brown with some lighter shades throughout.  No head to speak of. Smell is roasted malts with some hoppyness coming through.
Taste is really good, if it wasnt for the hops.  The underlying porter has a very roasty, smooth, coffee and chocolate thing going on with an incredible mouthfeel.  The flavor from the hops is taking away from that.  A very good beer that I wish I could sample without the hop profile.

12 oz Bottle-Pours a blackish color w/not much head. Indescript aroma. Kind of bland, some chocolate & licorice, but not a whole lot. No real carbonation or malt. Wasnt very impressed by this one, or many of their others for that matter.
Bottle; nose of coffee and chocolate; clear brown with a medium tan head; flavor of coffee and some burnt grainess with some hop bitterness. Fairly good!

12 oz bottle. Pours solid black with a light brown smallish head. Aroma was of coffee and chocolate but very pleasant and inviting. This beer had a full mouth feel with noticable carbonation and tasted of coffee and burnt chocolate. Very Good Porter.

Nice black pour with thick tan head.  Chocolate and coffee aroma with some hops detectable.  Taste is really good - thick & hoppy with plenty of well roasted malt.  Chocolate & lots of coffee - well balanced.  An outstanding American porter!

This is a solid porter.  Poured a dark dark brown.  Good head and very very nice lacing.  Aroma was nicly roasted coffee not to bitter.  Flavor was mught the some with a hint of vanilla in there as well as some citrus.  Mouthfeel was a little heavy but very very nice beer.

Decent. Pours a opaque coffee color with ample cream-brown head, leaving a nice lacing on the glass. Aroma is beery and slightly sour (in a good way). Flavor is nicely roasted, coffee, more on the bitter/hops side of the balance, then the malt. Definetly coats the tongue with flavor, lingering, makingit a good one to savor over time. Overall, a upper shelf porter. Id drink it happily if offered. There are a few Id favor above it.
Black with a tan head.  Roasted coffee and chocolate aroma.  More of the same in the flavor.  Chewy.  Long bitter finish.  Very nice.

Bottle Pours a very dark brown with some redish hues.  Modest sized but very dense and creamy mocha colored head.  Lacing is rich and sheeting.  Classic porter aroma, dark roasted nd some coffee and dark fruits. Flavor is big time roasted and charcoal.  Some bittersweet chocolate and campfire type notes. Very nice smoth creamy palate, and just the riht amount of lingering bitterness. This is indeed a robust porter. Thanks to Drewbeerme for this nice one.
Black. Clean, crisp and smooth.  Coffee and roasted malts taste. Slightly bitter but goes down very well. Slight vanilla tinge at the end. Very Good.

UPDATED: FEB 7, 2010 I found this porter great for the first beer, but I wasnt able to drink more than 3 and enjoy it like I would some of the smoother drinking porters. The beer has a ton of roasted, very very burnt flavors, but it isnt particularly smooth.

12oz, best before 4/07. bizzare label but sweet. poured dark with tan head, looks like a milkshake. nose is dull bakers chocolate, rust, and floral hops. taste is actually robust, rich with chocolate and coffee. not overly roasty. palate is smooth but perhaps a bit thin. carbination is low to average. tasty indeed.
Bottle: Dark brown to black with a tan head. Aroma, roasted malts, some chocolate, coffee. Flavor, coffee, chocolate, a roasted bitterness, smooth on the finish. Medium bodied. Very nice.
The commercial description is spot on for this one.  Very nice, one of the better porters Ive had.  So tasty and drinkable.

Wooow - thank you Tom/After4ever for this absolutely delicious porter, thats how I like them, and I look forward to tasting the other gems from out trade!! The color is pitch black and the head is nougat colored and creamy. The flavour has wonderful notes of dark chocolate and bitter coffee. The flavour is incredibly harmonic and balanced, it has gorgeous notes of dark chocolate, dark roasted coffee, licorice and the burnt flavours are very, very nicely balanced. Its a porter with a LOT of flavour even if the ABV is only 5,2% - just like i prefer my "black" beers - powerful and tasty - yummi yummi.... 1869

bottle--pours opaque black with a small tan head.. smells gorgeous.. chocolate malts all over the place, some roasted coffee beans in there as well.  it is thick, and chocolaty with a burnt wood flavor coffee in there as well... the finish is exquisite, smooth with a fine coffee flavor this is a wonderful porter.

Bottle: Poured a pitch-black color porter with a nice foamy head with great retention and lacing. Aroma of rich roasted malt is quite powerful and interesting. Taste of rich bitter roasted malt is domination and enjoyable. Creamy texture with some medium carbonation and good full body provide even further enjoyment of this fine beer. I would have like a bit more chocolate malt to offset some of the bitterness but apart from that this is a fine beer.

UPDATED: FEB 8, 2007 [Bottle, February 2007] Deep brown, nearly black pour with dark brown head. Mouthfeel is slightly bitter and somewhat crisp. Chocolate, liqourice, slight raisin and oak in aroma. Flavor is a nice balance of chocolate, raisins, and roasted nuts. As it warms it becomes a very pleasant beer. Not too thick or thin tasting.

Bottle. Poured a black body with good size head. Aroma is of coffee, sweet milk chocolate, and hops. Fantastic since I love all three. Bitter flavor and chocolate undertones. Smooth and drinkable, finishes well. Enjoyable.

Pours a deep brown/black with a large head. The head turns rocky, and leaves good lacing as it slowly dissipates. Aroma of milky chocolate and deep roasted malts. Flavor has a little bitterness, especially at the end. Another excellent brew from smuttynose.
bottle poured.  dark, rich color with crema head.  aroma is chocolately.  taste is good, coffee, chocolate.  good hops.  i like it.

Thanks to Luiss for this one. Pours a nice black color with a tan head.  The aroma is lots of chocolate with what seems to be a bourbon presence--even though this is not barrel aged (perhaps Im suffering from BAO? Barrel Aged Overload...).  Medium palate with fairly high carbonation.  The taste is a tangy bittersweet chocolate flavor.  A little watery flavor, and it doesnt quite match up to the aroma in the taste department.

UPDATED: OCT 14, 2007 Ive always understood a porter to be defined somewhat as a lighter stout.  I doubt this has any veracity to it, but its an impression that has kept me motivated to continue drinking beer without feeling like a total clod.  Stupidity or a sense thereof is a great way to keep somebody out of a hobby or academic field.  Even if my assumption is off, I like my porters expressive and bold, unafraid to put a little drama in their flavor.  The Smuttynose Robust Porter, one of their few beers available at the 2006 GABF, is a nice example of how I like it done.  A solid ebony body and a dark, oaken head (even in such a small glass) are good tip offs that its going to be something I like, showing no signs of weakness or cowardice.  Chocolate forms the foundation of the aroma, only slightly bitter, followed by the more natural and more sweet scent of molasses.  Those two aromas are accompanied by a Scottish peat smell that nuzzles up to the first two aromas with an impressive tolerance.  The final element of the smell that I could pick out was a sort of generic meatiness, maybe belonging to pork or beef, but something truly grizzly in its carnivorous foundation.  If theres one way to be bold, its to put the smell of cooked animal in your beer.  However, in the end, the Robust Porter is less robust than I expected, maintaining a level of flavor that sort of bumps around in intensity but never gets loud enough to really catch my attention (or my loving praise).  Its mostly coffee and alcohol, making up some imaginative bitter cocktail flavor, and then begins a strange presentation of peat and earthy vegetable flavors, including broccoli, Brussels sprouts, cauliflower and potato.  Im pretty open to steamed vegetables, but I know many people arent, so this could draw a lot of ire from devout meat eaters.  Bold, yes, but maybe not as much as it could have been.  It tries to be tough, but chickens out at the last minute and keeps up just enough bravado to hang with the boys as a tough, but not tough enough porter.

From a 12 oz bottle from a packy in the North End.  Pours a dark brown-- almost black-- with a rich, fruity, roasty, and caramel aroma.  Flavor is perfectly balanced-- some malty sweetness, a mild coffee-like acidity, roast/burnt flavors all over the place, and a nice hop finish.  Body is medium with just enough carbonation to add some liveliness.  THIS is a good porter!
Get some chocolate,coffee and bourbon in the aroma.Pours black with a medium tan head.Chocolate and coffee dominate the flavors.Medium mouthfeel with a bitter chocolate finish.
From bottle.  Pours a dark brown with dark tan head.  Nose is spruce hops and some smoky hints.  Flavor is smoked liquorish and molasses.  Nice spruce bitter in the finish.  Palate is slightly thin.
Pours a deep brown with a nice tan head. Aroma is smokey, nutty and malts. Flavor is a great mix of bitter malts and a good amount of hops. Also a nutty smokey finish. Very good.

Bottle via trade with Thaichile.   Pours a dark brown with a small dark tan colored head.   Aroma of coffee, chocolate, malt.   Flavor is coffee, chocolate, roasted malts.   Palate is medium full, medium carbonation, bitter, sweet finish.   Wonderful.

12 oz bottle. Black with a brown head. Noe is hoppier than expected, citrusy, over a deep medium chocolate and coffee. Full, thick body, satiny smooth. Bitter coffee and semisweet chocolate flavors. Medium bitter chocolate finish. Excellent!

Bottle. Poured a dark brown with a ruby tint. Thin dark tan head with some decent lacing. Nice roasted malts, coffee, and dark chocolate. A bitter, vinegary first sip with a sweet mocha finish. No carbanation, which is how a porter should be sometimes. Very smooth, above average, but almost cookie cutter porter. I enjoyed a sixer of this and was very pleased.

12 oz bottle. From Northerntimber, I believe.  Pours a thick chocolate color.  Aroma is coffee and chocolate.  Taste is strong on the coffee, which i like, but I almost found that everything was lost on the overpowering coffee flavor.  The palate was nice and it ends on a nice hoppy note.  Not bad.
On tap @ Coles in Buffalo, NY. Quite possibly my favorite porter that I,ve had to date. Very deep dark brown color with nice tan head. Seems to be much more complex than most. Great beer

Bottle. Pours a very dark brown almost black color with a thin tan head. Aroma of coffee, chocolate and hops. This is closer to a stout than most other porters. Taste is complex and nicely balanced. Starts off with a bit of semi sweet flavor but finishes with a dry hoppy taste.

Almost black color with a thick brown shapable head. Very mild armoa, barely even noticable. Huge taste with a lot of hops and some elements of coffee and chocolate no doubt like most any other porter. But there is more. Leaves aftertaste just like the one left by dark chocolate. Leaves the palate tingling with flavor. Really good stuff over all.

Pours very dark brown with a dark crimson hue and a good sized thick brown head.  The aroma has an emphasis on chocolate that has characteristics of both milk and bitter chocolates.  There is also lots of dark roasted malts - very heavily roasted, but just this side of char.  Some vanilla traits are noticable as well.  Medium / thick body that is smooth and rich while at the same time has lots of carbonation.  Starts off with smooth roasted chocolate that is quite lush.  There is rich roasted grainy malt.  This beer balances things well that generally dont go together (grainy vs. rich and smooth vs. high carbonation).  The finish has the roast of the taste, but addes a healthy does of spicy hops.  Excellent porter.

Pours black with a thick, frothy, tan/brown head. Bitter coffee, mocha, piney hop aroma. Flavors of piney hops, mocha, bakers chocolate, and a slight nuttiness. Very balanced medium palate, with nice mocha and lasting hoppy bitterness. Great porter

UPDATED: JUN 2, 2009 12oz Bottle:  Aroma of chocolate malts and piney and floral hops.  Nice scent.  Poured black with a big, creamy, brown head that lasted.  Excellent lacing.  Flavor is of chocolate at first, but not sweet.  Then it becomes lightly bitter and hoppy, with a dryish, chalky finish.  Finish was short.  Also some pine and grass flavor.  Medium body is a bit disappointing.  Average carbonation.  Very well balanced.  Overall a very good porter.

UPDATED: MAR 2, 2007 Pours black with a small tan head.  Aroma of chocolate, Roasted malt and coffee.  Great mouthfeel.  Taste of bittersweet chocolate, Coffee, vanilla.  Lasting bitterness.  One of those beers that I have re-rated higher each time I try it.

(Bottle, Oliver Twist, Stockholm) Black colour with a brief, beige head. Roasted nose with black coffee, wild berries (blueberries, crowberries) and notes of citrussy hops. Roasted taste with coffee, dark chocolate, the same wild berries,  soy sauce, liquorice and hints of citrussy hops in the dry, fresh finish. In superb balance. Great taste despite the fairly low abv. A benchmark for porter brewers. In short, a masterpiece.

Very dark brown pour, almost black. Head starts off promising but evaporates quickly. Excellent aroma of coffee and smoke. Tastes of coffee, some chocolate and smoky. Some hops come through in the finish. Excellent porter.

Great picture on the bottle.  another near black pour with a very thin head.  smoked semi-sweet chocolates, some sharpness on the tongue and jaw and more smoke in the aftertaste.  was not quite thick enough to match the smell - not quite enough flavor, but still very good.  I just expected it to be a little more robust, no pun intended

Slight roasted malt aroma.  Coffee and bitter sweet taste.  No chocolate, no cream.  Felt watery and underwhelming after the anderson valley deep enders I just had.  Slightly bitter aftertaste was unexpected especially for this style.

Bottle~Looks a bit watery, not in this case. Pours a dark black coffe look I guess robust is the word for it. Head is not present in this case. Taste very roasty, bitter and malty. I never had coffee but this is what Im sure this compares to it. Great dessert beer I would make a beer float with this one. As this beer gets warmer the taste of caramel, and walnuts  comes out.

Poured from bottle (yep, thats a porter).  Has that nutty, unsweetened syrup smell to it. Runs the flavor gamut - nutty, smoky, oaky, coffee, hint of cocoa too.  Hops kick in big in the aftertaste.  Has superior feel to it - as drinkable a porter as Ive ever tried.  Finished as nicely as it started.  Wonderful porter.
user_location: York, SC via NJ, South Carolina, USA

text: 12 oz bottle shared with StompBrockmore - very dark brown, near black, smallish mocha head.  Aroma mainly dark chocolate, lots and lots o those roasted malt thingys, and.....COFFEE!  WHYYYYYYY??!?!?!!  I just dont like coffee, and I realize that that is a huge draw to these types of beers, and I can objectively appreciate the complexity of whats going on, but since drinking beer is primarily a subjective thing, meaning you like it or you dont, wellllll.....this ones no fo me.  Anyhow, taste much the same as the aroma, and yes, it IS robust - chocolate, coffee, roasted malt, blahblahblah, does anyone even read these?

UPDATED: NOV 27, 2006 12oz bottle, shared with VeloVampire - pours very dark brown, almost black. Aroma is strong roasted malt and coffee., with some dark chocolate. The aroma gave away what the taste would be, but I was still surprised by how stout-like this porter was. Very strong, full bodied flavour - really nice actually. Lots of coffee, roasted, nutty malt, more chocolate, with a lighty bitter finish. This is a very fine porter, and "robust" indeed. Like I said before, its almost like a stout. Either way though, I could drink a lot of this brew. Flavourful and rich! Fantastic!

Bottle shared with after4ever. Is this beer a porter or a stout? Maybe a stout porter? :) Either way, its a tasty beer. Pours a blackish brown with a lacy tan head. Medium body. Coffee in the nose and taste with roasty nutty malt behind it, and a touch of citrus hops in there somewhere. Bitter finish. Not the refreshing, almost sessionable porter style I expected, but not bad at all!

UPDATED: FEB 8, 2007 12-oz. Thanks, 46er3498! Jet black. A little tan moussy head for a while. Highly vinous nose--kind of a surprise there. Huge roast and coffee attack that carries through to the mid-palate. High-medium body, almost oily, but not quite. Light c-hop finish. Stout-like; easily the roastiest and most bitter porter Ive tried. Great stuff.

12oz bottle from trade, poured super dark brown with a nice brown head. The aromas were chocolate, roast, caramel and some hops. The taste was bittersweet chocolate, coffee and roasted malt with the hop profile barely standing out. A good example of the Robust Porter style.

UPDATED: JUL 14, 2007 12 oz bottle via kramer17801 (thanks!). Pours a midnight black with a small tan head. nose is mostly roasty chocolate,espresso, plum, and vanilla. mmm, this is an exquisite porter. The robust in the name fits this perfectly. Very tastey bittersweet roasted cocoa and coffee are the predomant flavors. This is REALLY ghood stuff. Gotta find some more.
Bottle. Dark brown pour with tan head woth decent lacing. Aroma of roasted malts and coffee. Taste is of the same. It goes down smooth a real good porter.

Bouteille de 12 oz achetée chez Beverage Warehouse (Winooski, VT). Arôme: Odeur de café et de chocolat. Apparence: La couleur est noire opaque. Présence dun moyen col beige mousseux et dune large dentelle sur le verre. Saveur: Goût de café et de chocolat. Durée moyenne de larrière goût. Palette: Le corps est moyen avec une texture légèrement crémeuse. Moyenne effervescence en bouche. Présence de café en arrière goût. (Rating #728)

Bottle. Pours a deep black body with a medium-sized creamy brown/mocha head and lacing. Killer aroma- oily hops, thick chocolate, oats, and vanilla notes. Tastes quite rich and full for the strength. Very oily and inky with plenty of bitter chocolate creaminess and roast. Finishes green and leafy. Superb complexity.

WOW, this is a sweet beer.  This is huge smoky chocolate malts.  Big bitterness.  I dont think there is a difference between stouts and porters but this is hugely flavorful, and I think thats what the difference is.  Porters are more bold.  This is an imperial stout without the alcohol.  Other than Alpha King, I cant think of another higher rated beer of normal alcohol %.  I think this beer is super fresh too.

[bottle] Pours a deep reddish black color, with a thick coffee colored head. Dark, roasted malts with some bitter coffee/chocolate flavors. Nice woody flavors emerge towards the end. A very complex, drinkable beer.
on tap-pours a tan head.  Color is black with red tint.  Aroma is dark malt-chocolate/licorice.  Taste is coffee, dark malt-chocolate/licorice, secondary hops bitterness.  OK carbonation.

UPDATED: OCT 13, 2006 Pours a beautifully opaque near-black with a two-finger tan to light brown head.
