There is an immediate chocolate and, surprisingly, raspberry nose which relaxes after about half a minute to a nutty, coffee aroma.  Definite hop presence.  As it warms, burnt toffee prevails.  Taste is upfront molasses and coffee with a nice hoppy bitterness.  Sweet malt is always present but never shouts.  A solid mouthfeel and soft carbonation.  The long finish favors bitter over sweet.  The head dimishes to a fine layer but never leaves.  Smuttynose has nailed a porter with a lot of character that could easily be a session beer.  Very well-balanced and thoroughly enjoyable.

dark black pour w/ a thick cream of wheat looking brown head.  Well roasted notes, tons of semi sweet chocolate chips lots of malts some light bitter coccoa powders.  Palate is well coated, lightly oily and chewy.  Flavor is lots of bitter chocolates a good roasty malt flavor and a dry finish.  A very nice porter.
Everything you expect in a porter: roasted chocolate and coffee, big on the malt, a little bit of bitterness. Except here its all balanced beautifully. Excellent.

Beautiful fall night, just got back from a walk with Wally. Pours a thick black with medium head, very nice lacing. You picked a pretty one OG. Or maybe I just poured it right. Strong roasted malt aroma, chocolate as well. Heavy maltiness, some bitterness. Nice thick palate.
Very brownish and dark color, nearly black.  Roasted aroma, with a malty, coffee and chocolate flavor.

Wow, this looks like a robust porter.  Half an inch of light brown head, with a black completely opaque body.  Smells roasty and malty with a hint of hop.  Tastes roasty and malty, coffee-like with a hint of hop.  This is an excellent porter.  Medium to full in body and extremely tasty.  One of the best porters Ive ever had.

Pours deep black into a snifter.  Mocha micro head leaves lacing as it recedes.  Deep espresso and chocolate aromas. Upfront crispness with a cream chocolate middle and a lasting coffee hop finish.  Very nice.

Bottle (courtesy of NachlamSie). This looks remarkably like maple syrup when pouring, with a small brown head. The aroma is sweet and chocolatey with hints of vanilla and roasted barley. The flavor is much roastier than I was expecting, reminding me a bit of a stout. But theres some dark chocolate, vanilla, and some noble hops to counter it. It mixes into a taste not unlike a cappuccino, but more bitter. The finish is woody and pleasant. I enjoy this beer.

12 oz bottle into an English Pint (thanks to acertain!!!).  The Smuttyness pours a rich and silkly looking dark blackish color with an extremely thin amberish tan head that quickly retreats.  The aroma brings out a hugely dark and robust roasted cocoay coffee (more on the cocoa side) nose.  Amazing aroma!!  The flavor is also very toasted bringing out a silky texture on the tongue at first with the tastes of roasted chocolate and malts.  It progresses slowly into a more coffee hopped finish, where the roasted coffee lingers on the palate for a bit.  Has a small lean towards a stout.  A seriously solid porter.  Would drink this over and over again!!

This one really hit the spot. Dark, dark brown with a respectable head. The aroma is rich cocoa maltiness and slightly overdone toast. The flavor is satisfying chocolatey with a nice hoppy finish. A touch of cappuccino in there as well. I really dug this one.

via trade with Ty5592 - Pours a black color with a good size tan head.  Lots of nice lacing as the head settles.  Has a sweet chocolate, coffee aroma.  Flavor is also chocolate and coffee.  The bitterness really comes through.  Has a thin palate, otherwise this beer would make a nice Imp stout.  Leaves a roasted aftertaste.  Thin to medium body.  A very good beer.  Thanks TY.

Very dark in the glass -- very porter-looking.  Generous aromas of chocolate, malt and robust grains.  Rich malt and very chocolaty without giving too much away.  Medium body is a bit thin for the substantial flavors.  Long finish is a nice reminder of the great beer you just sipped! (Didnt get the alcohol or bitterness of other tasters.)

Unusual mineral taste, high carbonation, light body, mocha, cocoa, dry for porter. High carbonation porters even with a light body are a bit unsettling after even a small meal. Nice for the right moment though. Why is this ranked so high?

12 oz bottle, poured into a pint glass. Tall tan head, nice lacing, and a strong roasted coffee aroma. Tastes similarless potent than a stout and smoother mouthfeel, low bitterness, roasted and malty, almost like coffee, smoky. Pretty decent, couldnt have many.

i must say, this beer smells better than it tastes. pours black with small tan head that quickly disapeared. light carbonation.  very roasted flavor, almost too much so. i think i would have liked this beer better if i enjoyed dark chocolate, because its very prominent in the taste. the finish is an unpleasant bitterness with a little alcohol bite.

sort of a promising nose...Riesen candy...coffee, dark chocolate...interesting flavors, bitterness that I can no longer call cocoa at this point and the finish is reminiscent of having chewed a pack of Marlboros

Bottle courtesy of Rudolf: Poured dark brown with runy highlights and a tan head. Coffee and chocolate with a roasted flavor that paired perfectly with a steak on the grill. One of the best of the style.

Bottle. Pours a very dark brown, almost black, with an average size diminishing light-brown head. Aroma of dark chocolate, coffee, lightly roasted malt and thats pretty much it -- simple but pleasant. Flavour of coffee, roasted malt, chocolate and a roasty slighty bitter finish. Medium bodied, creamy mouthfeel. Nothing outstanding but still a pretty good, solid Porter.

UPDATED: MAR 7, 2007 (Bottle, thanks to Thaichile) Pours brown to black with a small, light brown head. Rum raisin aroma with cocoa and  coffeebeans. Robust smell. A bit of liquorice. Dark breadsyrup. Flavour brings dry coffee bitterness and cocoa. Dry with a rather small body. A bit roasted. Notes of minerals in the lack of body.
Pours black with a brwon head. Bready, chocolate roasted aroma. Lots of roasted malt in the flavor. Some bitterness from the hops in the backend but not much flavor from them. A solid porter.

Enters the glass a viscous inky jet black. Produces a one inch thick and dense mocha colored head which sustains itself nicely throughout. Rich assertive aromas of dark semi-sweet chocolate, french roast coffee, roasted malts, fresh vanilla bean and faint charcoal. Mouthfeel is moderately full and creamy. Just the right level of carbonation. Fantastic flavors of dark chocolate, espresso, charred wood, anise, and vanilla cream are noted. Some mildly bitter hop contribution in the finish to balance it all out. A hearty, well done Porter.
Dark pour little head, great aroma, aftertaste not to my liking. Great to have one but couldnt do a 6 pack. Not a big porter fan but like this one.

Thanks to St. Nick for this one. Black with brown edges and a small, dense, tan head. Nose of roasty, burnt malt, bittersweet mocha, graham cracker, subtle hops. Same flavor with the hops stepping it up in the finish. Medium/full, balanced palate. Solid porter.
UPDATED: JUN 13, 2007 WOW!, dark inky body with a deep chocolate head, rich malty, complex - slightly bitter and very malty.  finish rich and with a grainy mouthfeel.  great sipping beer.

Pours an opaque dark brown color with a large creamy brown head. Fantastic lacing. Rich roasted coffee aroma along with hints of dark chocolate. Incredibly mouth-watering. Absolutely delicious. Creamy chocolate flavors on top of a bitter dark roast coffee taste. Incredibly smooth and creamy mouthfeel. A truly elite porter.
Thanks to Walt for this. Now I really like their brews and this is no exception to the rule.Hearty smokey coffee flavor with some roasty bitterness on the tongue.

Rich mahogany under a thick light brown head with good lacing.  Lots of coffee and chocolate on the nose.  Very nice balance of roasted malt, caramel, coffee and bittersweet chocolate with a pleasant and aggressive - for a porter - hop presence.  Moderately creamy mouthfeel with just the right amount of carbonation and a flavorful, crisp finish.  This porter reminded me of Averys New World Porter but with a somewhat more restrained hop profile.  Nice brew.

UPDATED: OCT 28, 2012 First rating, entered on RB on 7/14/2006Sampled from 12 fl oz bottle courtesy of Marsiblursi. Very dark brown color, beige-brown head. Chocolate sweet and raissin scent. Dry mouthfeel with initial "too strong instant coffee" taste. Sweet turning to dark chocolate aftertaste. A bit thin body.8/3/7/4/13=3.5RerateDraught at Rattle N Hum, NYC, on January 30, 2012Clear very deep dark red color, light brown head. sweet, coffee, roasted taste. Dry, coffee aftertaste. Spritzy (used to say "Moussy") mouthfeel, medium high bitterness. Dry coffee scent.7/4/8/3/15=3.7Rerate12 fl oz bottle at Rotary Pub, Göteborg, sampled on October 26, 2012.Black color, light brown head. Sweet, cocoa, chocolate scent. Hoppy, bitter, cocoa taste. Medium mouthfeel, medium high bitterness.7/4/7/3/13=3.4

[Bottled] 
Almost black colour. Brown head. A sharp licorice aroma is tucked in a tone of dark chocolate. Very robust. Thin-ish mouthfeel. Initially there is instant coffee in flavour, then all leads to a yummy dry cocoa ending. Not all complex but very tasty.
(Bottle)  Pours a dark brown body with a medium creamy tan head.  Aroma of roasted malt and dark chocolate. Flavor of toasted malt, chocolate, and light coffee with a smooth, creamy mouthfeel.

UPDATED: DEC 3, 2006 Really fantastic porter, its a brew that is complex in its taste and easy to drink. Excellent smell of malt, caramel and chocolate. Nice smooth finish and a wonderful beer to drink, even when its not cool outside.

Poured a dark black with ruby highlights.  Creamy, frothy head which dissapated fairly rapidly but left behind some gentle lacing on the glass and on the surface of the brew.  Deep malty, roasted grain aroma.  Flavors similar to aroma:  roasted grains, malt, wheat, a hint of nuttiness, and a mild hoppiness.  A real "serious" porter...Smuttynose always pulls through with excellent brews.

Wonderful brew. Dark black body with a small tan-colored head.  Aroma was not complex, but gave hints of a wonderfully roasty and malty experience.  Taste was very malty and rich. Burnt notes, strong flavoring and a small hoppy twang in the finish.  As it warmed, there were some earthy notes to it. Very unique, and definitely the break-out porter that I was looking for on the particular day.  This one will stay in regular rotation in my refrigerator, especially in the winter.

Tap at Hop Devil Grill.  Black beer with a thin off-white head.  Aroma is quite simple, black malt, herbal hoppiness as well as some dark caramel.  Low chocolate character, but a very prominent anise/licorice aroma.  Flavour is very herbal, licorice, toast and a lingering earthy hoppiness.  Light roast, but the earthy and herbal notes drive the show here.  Tasty and quite distinctive.
Black color small white head.  Aroma is smokey, roasted w/ some chocolate.  Flavor is roasted coffee w/ some chocolate and caramel help to lend a bit of depth.

dark brown/black pour w/ slighty tan head and lacing. coffee and chocolate notes all over the place, hop notes come though nicely, and balanced through and through. one of the best all around porters ive had, and would be a classic example of the breed.

pours dark brown with a tan head. fantastic aroma. rich mocha with some vanilla and cherry. beautifully balanced flavor. bittersweet mocha and hops. medium body. finish smooth bittersweet slightly acidic mocha. fantastic drinkable porter. everything a porter should be. this might just be a new favorite.

UPDATED: JUN 12, 2006 12 Oz Bottle. Aroma is unique, with flowering bouquets of heavily roasted caramel, expertly blending with Lindt Hazlenut chocolate and a shot of Kahlua. A delicate sea breeze salt and great roasted character. Deep black pool of liquid, with a rosy glint of North Carolina star sapphire, topped with a frothy swirling tempest of tan Stellwagen sea foam. Flavor continues along the lines of the aroma, but is a major dissapointment. The rich creamy malts soon fade into a watered down love. An alacrity of sewage pond vapors and angry bees cacophonates a incestuous steam train of weak coffee grounds, drippings from a melted Hershey bar, and a Margarita glass edged in Kosher salt. The oaky hull of a sloop fades into the distance of this beer, with biting cinnamon and lacksidasical roasted beet sugars. Palate maintains oak dryness. A slow let down.

Well, if you like porters, this is a fine example. Poured the dark brown to black color with some mahoganey edges. Two finger head and pretty good lacing. The aroma was mostly roasted coffee. This wasnt that complex and I didnt pick up on all the nuances that some others have: pretty much roasted (not smoked) coffee was the feature, and there were some citrus hops in the somewhat bitter finish (but certainly not assertive). Mouthfeel was moderate to heavy within style and somewhat carbonated.

Superbly chocolately and rich porter. On tap at Hop Devil in NYC. Clean roasty nose with a slight bitter edge. The bitterness works well in the flavor to complement the smooth chocolate. A wonderful porter.

From a 12 oz. long neck brown bottle with a bottled/freshness date along the left side of label.

Made a good appearance, poured a thickish dark brown with foamy tan head that settled into a thin lacing, small amount of ringed sticking, moderate carbonation.

Had a delicious roasted malty nose, chocolate, caramel and hints of coffee and dark fruits.

A crisp, slick and creamy smooth medium bodied mouth feel, good drinkability.

Roasted fresh dark coffee with a dose of sweeten chocolate, a burnt malt bitterness, followed by lightening fruitiness and a dry roasted malty finish.

A great tasting porter, highly quaffable, well worth trying.

Popped this bottle that I received from ilinismitty while cooking lasagna and listening to a song that reminds me of a woman from my past. This poured black with a thick coffee with cream head. Wonderful rich mocha and grass hop nose. A nice vanilla cream note to the aroma, I really like this aroma, some nuttiness mixes with the spicy hop I keep going back to coffee when I stick my nose in the glass, but it is not due to a roast note, although there is a bit of that, it is just that kind of rich sweetness that a chocolate coffee drink has, or one with a nice dose of Irish cream or somesuch. Thick cocoa biscuit flavor. Then a wet coffee ground flavor and a mocha finish. Christwagons, this is good. Nice finish of hops, grass mainly, but a bit of herbal flavor too that accents the cocoa and chocolate with a fine touch. Thanks for this bottle Sean, I will get more. As for the food in the oven, it smells fine, and the woman is still living back beyond a bridge I burned to the ground. The future looks better with beer this good.
Ap-5 ar-8 tas-8 pal-5 ov-18
The color of dark chocolate with the smell of fresh coffee. The body was smooth and firm with the taste of freshly roasted coffee and chocolate. Creamy aftertaste. Highly recommended.

Pours a leathery brown, settles nearly black, but is very deep and super dark brown with a thin tan head that fades fast, some intricate webby lacing sticks at first but then begins to disappear. Smell is nice and chocolatey, thick, full, lush, sweet, a bit roasty with a chocolate cake aroma thats very fresh and a pleasure to wiff in. Taste is somewhat subdued with mostly chocolate malts leading the way, good flavor that last for a time but is kinda mild til some roastyness settles across the palate with a duller sweetness and small dry hop bitterness and then drys out nicely later in the finish with a fluffy cocoa powder-like coating the mouth and cheeks. Feel is medium bodied, pretty solid from start to finish and a nice drying finish that really did the trick for me. A good porter, would enjoy again again if I could.

Bottle (12oz).  Poured pretty much opaque black with a large foamy-fluffy-creamy medium brown head.  Really, really appealing aroma of almost equal parts deep roast coffee/cocoa malt and rich piney hops, with some leafy and yeasty notes as well.  Pretty on-style porter taste, creamy bitter and milk chocolate, light coffee bean and nutshell roast malt, quite a bit of lightly acidic resiny hops and some yeast and spice tang as well - and no cola!  Mouthfeel is creamy, lightly acidic and carbonated, quite complex and a solid porter body to boot.  Really good bitter dark roast porter, on of the best Ive had - I want more.

Pours black with a thick, creamy, tan head. The aroma is rich chocolate, molases with some dark fruits. The flavor is loaded with molases, chocolates, caramel, plums and coffee. Medium body with light acidity and a bitter finish. World class porter.

Damn this is pretty good...thanks slob.  Pours a dark black amber witha pretty huge head.  Aroma is monster coffee, chocolate, anise, dry red fruits, and burnt malt.  Taste is huge...more like a stout.  Fruity malt, alcohol, acidic coffee, bitter chocolate.,,dry hoppy finish. Mouthfeel is really heavy and pretty carbonated.  This stuff is great.

Glad i bought the whole sixxer of these instead of just one.  Pours a dark brown with a hint of red.  Nice soft foamy head with wonderful notes of fuits, nuts, and chocolate.  Mostly domoinated by malt and hops though.  Taste is fantastic.  Nice roasted malt flavors with hints of coffee and chocolate.  Nice clean hoppy finish.

(let this one warm up) dark, with medium tan head. aroma is powerfull, a very nicely balanced, floral hops and roasted malts. taste is certainly robust. roasted malts, toffee, mocha, bitter chocolate, and currant berrys. this was really good. packs a punch in the flavor and aroma department. definatly lives up to its name.

12oz. bottle.  Nearly opaque ruby-brown with a thin film of dark brown head.  Muted roastiness and a sweet chocolate aroma.  Faint roast complements bittersweet chocolate flavors.  Finish has residual chocolate and some astringent hoppiness.  Mouthfeel is light medium, somewhat dry.
UPDATED: APR 27, 2006 Bottle sampled beer night at my house with Stegosaurus. Pours dark colored. aroma of roast, caramel, and coffee. Flavor is smooth, roast, coffee.

(Bottle (brewed 2/06) from <A HREF=http://www.ratebeer.com/Place/massachusetts/w target=blank>Julios Liquors) Pours thick and very, very dark brown. About 3 in. of tan head. Aroma actually pretty light: quite a bit of hops, some coffee, tiny bit of chocolate. Some spotty, weepy lacing. Has a rich, thick mouthfeel. Flavor is fairly dominated by the hops, but not the bittering hops, more of the aromatic hops contributing to the taste. This also gives it a grassiness which carries through the finish. Otherwise there is mostly bitter coffee. This seems like a quality beer in every aspect except somehow got overloaded with the wrong kind of hop contributing to an off-flavor.

(03.26.06) Stout/porter sampling with Scott, Tony and Walt at DiCarlos, Mundelein, IL. 12 oz brown bottle as gift from Thaichile. 5.7% ABV. Poured black with large long-lasting tan head. No discernable carbonation. Roasted malt in the nose.  Medium bodied porter that starts with light malt sweetness and coffee/roasted malt flavors. Finishes dry with light roasted malt and bitterness fade.  Flavorful and well-balanced, this is a very enjoyable porter that wins best of show in our six porter/stout sampling. Thanks Thaichile!

12oz bottle.  This one is smokey, nutty, and bitter.  The tan head is clinging to the sides of the pint glass till the end.  The finish is dry and nutty.  This my favorite New England brewery... I should check out the brewery sometime.

Thanks Hairofthedog!  Pours a clear, blackish color with a very small head and just a little bit of lacing.  Aroma is rich and smoky with hints of roastiness.  Flavor is roasty and smoky with a slight nut hint at the end.  Slight bubbly and very light on the palate.  Very enjoyable porter IMO.

Pours a black with some hints of red when held to the light.  Head is average size, foamy and tan.  Left some great lacing on the glass and sustained.  Aroma of cocoa, coffee, caramel with a nice roasted malty sweetness.  Flavors were very similar with some light bitterness as I would expect from a good porter.  Flavor slightly more complex than aroma, but both were very solid.

Bottle. Pours black with brown head. Rich aroma of roast coffee and cocoa. Fairly balanced blend bitter chocolate, coffee, oats, with emphasis on roastiness. Pleasant and full lingering bitter finish. I usually do not like too much roasted flavors in my porters, but this one was nice.

Fantastic grape malt, cherry chocolate aroma, wonderful, chocolately fruity, and roasted coffee bitterness,body was a touch thin,but this is one of the best porters I have had in a while really rivals my favorite E. Fitzgerald

Bottle.  Dark chocolately color with nice hop nose and bite.  Very well balanced beer with good alcohol level often lacking in some porters.  Not sure about the label -- a bit too corny for my tastes; seems a beer of this caliber should rate a more stylish label.

Pours dark brown with moderate brown head.  Suprisingly hoppy aroma with hints of citrus and backed by chocolate and coffee malts.  Flavor is rich and deep: hop bitterness, oatmeal, chocolate, coffee and a touch of toffee sweetness.  Medium body with light carbonation.  Really nice porter.

Black Coloring with Espresso Head.  Robust Coffee and Chocolate Aroma...Already Aptly Named... Light Mouthfeel...Not Thickly Malted...Instead Nice Light Chocolate Notes with Wonderfully Freshly Roasted Coffee Notes Abound in Every Taste...Light Lactose Taste...Dry Aftertaste.. Quite Nice.

Black color with a tall, towering head.  Odd to see that on a porter.  Strong aroma of chocolate and coffee.  The chocolate takes a turn for the dry cocoa in the taste.  Solid dry malt base.  Barely any bitterness, just dry.  Excellent!

Pours black with a frothy and fading choco colored head.  Smells of rich smokey coffee.  Taste is very much the same.  It is strong but not overdone, just the right amount to get what you want out of it without spoiling the flavor.  Goes down smooth and is finished with a soft sweetness.  Very good porter!

Bottle.  Right good roast coffee bean aroma on thick india ink beer.  Modest, fading beige head.  Zingy roast malt earthen flavor with nice little hop touch of bite to it.  A little chalky.  Licorice flavor emerges.  Overall quite nice.

UPDATED: APR 13, 2006 Pours black with a thick light brown head. Roasty chocolate, mocha and hops in the nose. Flavor has notes of dark roasted malt, dark chocolate, plant soil, coffee, a solid dose of hops and caramel sweetness. Has a pleasant burnt/bitter aftertaste; a little charcoal. Medium bodied with a smooth texture and moderate carbonation - seems on target for a porter. Spider-web lacework on the glass with good head retention. Good stuff.

Bottled in January.  Poured a slightly hazy, deep garnet with a long-lived creamy caramel head.  Nose picked up almost burnt chocolate, coffee, soap, and pine forest notes... hoppage became more pronounced as it warmed.  Flavor began with a pine tinge on the the tip of the tongue.. followed by roasted chocolate and coffee.  Coffee and pine bitterness surrounded the tongue and carried through the roasty finish.  Medium-bodied.  Solid porter.

12oz bottle from Lou18. Pours a dark brown color with a frothy tan head. Nose is smokey, peaty, chocolate, coffee, earthy, roast malt. Big flavor of chocolate in the back of my throat right off the bat. Notes of coffee, roasted malt, semi sweet chocolate. Palate is veryfoamy, lightly fluffy but full. Finishes very sticky and with a thick layer of film on the teeth, gums and tongue.

12 oz. bottle.  originally had  on tap at Red Bones, but should have gotten as a dessert beer, not an appetizer. 
Pours a near black, with a great light brown/tan head. good lacing. carbonation light. Aroma is of coffee, roasted and chocolate malts/dry chocolate. Taste is of semi sweet chocolate, roasted malt, slight butter taste, with a long, roasty bitter finish. A great Porter in my opinion.

Bottle:  Pours to a near-black brown, opaque when held to the light though it doesnt appear to be very murky or hazy.  A medium light brown head quickly forms and just as quickly dies, though it does hold a nice large ring around the glass.  The aroma is full roasted malt, roast coffee, mild chocolate, and a bit of fruit - plums, grapes, strawberry, and hints of smoke.  The taste is roasted malt and roasted coffee, but the roast flavors are not over the top.  There are also some notes of chocolate, dry spices, and a bit of charred wood.  Finishes with some charred wood and big roast flavors.  Medium bodied, full at times, kept nice and crisp in the mouth by fine carbonation.

(12 oz bottle: Chevy Chase Liquors in Washington, DC) This is a fairly old bottle, so aging has surely had an impact on this beer.  Very bubbly in structure, but with a creamy top, the tan head rises to nearly two inches on the pour before slowly ebbing to a quarter inch layer.  Jet black in color through every angle of the glass except at the extreme bottom edge where a bit of ruddiness sneaks out.  Ample flavors of yeast, chocolate, ash, charcoal, and bitter roastiness define this self-proclaimed "robust" porter, an apt description to be sure.  Slight peppery flavor accompanies a modest sourness that acts as a counterpoint to the light sweetness and its this spicy and sour traits that are somewhat of a distraction for me.  Ashy, bitter, roasty finish doesnt give the chocolate adequate room to breath.  Robust also describes the body, which while not thick and heavy, is still medium-full bodied, not bad for a porter.  The nose, however, is less aromatic than I expected, projecting a modest roastiness, so this is the one aspect where robustness is lacking.  Overall head retention is about as good as it gets, as an hour has passed and yet that quarter-inch head is still proudly on display.  Unfortunately, lacing is minimal with just a small slash across part of the glass.  Quite a nice porter overall.

Poured this beautiful brew from a bottle, black as night with a foamy head that sticks to my glass all the way down. Flavor is immediatly roasty, complex with chocolate, coffee, a bit of smoke and a nice dry hop bitterness. A very nice porter. Like the name says, robust... Well done.

Pours to a deep dark brown body that looks black.  The beer has a nice creamy beige head.  Awesome lacing.  The aroma is coffee, light chocolate, strawberry seeds, smoked wood and meat.  The flavor is an intensely roasted coffee malt with notes of roasted and smoked charred wood and chocolate.  Citrus hops are noticed in the belch.  The palate is medium-full bodied with an oily feel and dry roastiness.

12 oz bottle.  Pours a very dark brown with chestnut highlights, with a thick creamy one finger light brown head above.  This is as good as a Porter can look.  Great aroma of chocolate malt and roast with a drying yeast character.  Big full flavor balanced between the chocolate, roasted, and burnt malts.  Finish is very dry and moderately bitter with a bit of charred wood.  Mouthfeel is full bodied and oily in texture with a dry and slightly astringent finish.  A very flavorful and well made Porter.  Big and bold, just the way I like em.

12oz. bottle. Dark brown almost black pour with a rocky tan head. Hops, smoke, and chocolate erupt from the glass. The flavour is rich and complex with notes of dark brown sugar, caramelized walnuts, and espresso. Im not so sure this is still a porter... seems more like a stout. Well, call it what they will this beer is fantastic.

Bottle:  Courtesy of Eyedrinkale via trade.  Very roasty aroma with lots of grain and coffee mixed with chocolate and light pine.  Pours a dark brown with some light red hilights along the bottom of the glass.  Nice tan head with very good retention and okay lacing.  Moderate chocolate throughout mixes with a light fruitiness in the middle.  Finish is very roasty with grain, coffee, and some piney hops.  Mouthfeel is a little thin but still creamy.  A very nice porter.

This porter pours a dark brown color with a light-brown head. Aroma is of moderate malts with roasted, burnt, and nutty notes. Also vanilla. Initial taste is light bitter that continues through to the finish. Creamy on the palate with no carbonation.

Thanks to Lou18 for this one. Poured dark black with a light brown head. The aroma was HUGE coffee, bread, chocolate, carmel, and malts. Unbelievable coffee smell, add in the other aromas and combine and you have a beer orgasm. Flavor is coffee, nuts, and chocolate. Lush malt body with the perfect balance. The flavor and aroma are superb. What a joy this one is.
Coffee, smoke, espresso, and gas in the aroma.  Heavy coffee with cream, caramel, and mettalic.

12 oz. brown, longneck bottle. No freshness date seen anywhere. Poured out a deep chocolate brown, with a faint, tan colored head. Aromas are subdued. Malts, coffee & chocolate come thru somewhat. Flavors are of too much coffee, way too much chocolate malt too. Medium mouthfeel. Needs work, & needs to be better balanced.

12oz bottle poured a dark brown (almost black) with a very good tan head. Good lacing on the sides of the glass. Aroma was roasted malts and dark fruit (dates or raisins). Flavor was a very good roasted malt and coffee flavor with a bit of a hop finish.

12oz bottle via trade with Lou18 - Thanks Lou! - Pours black with a nice big creamy tan head that stays well and laces the sides of the glass in patterns.  Aroma is roasted malt, big coffee, and some nice milk chocolate as well.  Flavor is nice and roasty as well.  Definitely some smoke in this one.  Coffee, lots of coffee, and some sweet milk chocolate shows through in the middle then gives way to the coffee flavor again and a slight bitter dry finish.  Creamy and mouthcoating on the palate and very smooth to drink.  Very well done..  Just my style of porter..

Fantastic milieu of colors in the head, a sheen of rich coffee w/ a dark black hued body.   Taste is of a prevalent roasted malt barley w/ some sweetness & obvious coffee.  Solid medium body, enjoayble on the palate, smooth w/ a touch of crisp btterness on the finish.

02.05.06  12oz bottle.  Not only have I missed rating this until now, Im pretty sure Ive never even tasted it before this six pack.  I wish I had.  Pours nearly black with glowing ruby highlights, hefty and rich looking, and with a thick and lasting brown head.  Lovely hoppy aroma is floral and resinous over top of deep and rich chocolate and (mostly) coffe malts.  As the beer warms, the coffee becomes the major player, pungent yet pleasant.  A smoky, grilled meat flavor emerges, sweet and caramelized, which compliments the persistent resinous hops.  I only wish it had a drier feel.  Finishes long with lingering roastiness and smoke, coffee, and sticky bitterness.  Excellent.

Quickly diminishing brown-orange head that is of medium body before diminishing.  Very dark body, black as far as can be determined, slightly too dark in my opinion for a porter but better than most others.    Heavy coffee tastes combined with a very sweet malt make for an interesting effect on the balate.  Bitter sweet like dark chocolate in the ending.  Very enjoyable.
a very dark robust porter.  has a richness thats somewhere between chocolate and coffee hinted.  very slight head when poured. lovely beer I dont have regular access to.

Smuttynose Robust Porter pours to a deep, deep brown to black color with a creamy tan head that fades and a moderate to soft amount of carbonation. The nose is packed with lots of big citric hop aromas paired with lots of roasty and dark chocolate malt aroma. The palate is firm, with a big body of dark chocolate, coffee, roast, and some burnt currant fruitiness that coats the tongue. Smuttynose Robust Porter finishes with more chocolate and roast up front, then ends with a burst of piney/citric hop bitterness. 

This is a very impressive beer with intense flavors, and lives up to the name robust. I love this beer, and this beer style, you really get lots of big flavors, and you can really work on this beer.
Smells like a porter and looks like a porter.  Tasts like a porter, except with a sour aftertaste.  That doesnt make me happy at all.

On tap. ark, dark brown with a thin off white head. Chocolate malt smell. coffee and vinegar taste. bitter at the end. Not my favorite style of beer but I can appreciate the complex effect on all my senses.

Wow, one of the best selections Ive tried from smuttynose. Recommended from my man at Colonial Spirits in Acton. Lets get to the beer. This beer pours a magnificent dark chocolate brown, and leaves a very thin tan lace that continues with the beer as you drink it. The smell is chocolate, caramel, coffee, dark fruit, and a piney leafy essence. As this beer hits the palate it hits you with a kick of espresso hopped chocolate bitterness and finishes with a smooth caramel fruit blast. This is one the best and most complex beers Ive had from Smuttynose it is great and def recommended.

UPDATED: JUL 4, 2008 When I first rated this beer, I felt that the hop bitterness overcompensated for the malt sweetness/body.  I know my palate has changed, and maybe the beer has as well, but I can’t find fault with this beer as it currently stands.  If I were to be executed, my last meal would be an appetizer of raw oysters, an entree of spicy hickory barbecued ribs, and dessert of some kind of dark chocolate.  Each course would be served with this beer, or something damn similar!
Pours with a large tan head on a dark brown body. Strong aroma of roasted malts, coffee and chocolate. Coffee flavor with an intense licorice bitterness at the end. Good body.

UPDATED: MAR 21, 2011 Bottle on 03/21/2011. Dark black body with a medium creamy tan head. Sweet roast, chocolate and dry caramel aroma. Sweet roast, chocolate, coffee and dry caramel flavor with a firm bitter finish. Medium body with moderate carbonation. - 7/5/7/4/15 - 3.8

01/21/2006: Pours a thick dark black color with a large creamy brown head that lasts a while. Roasted malt and chocolate aroma. Rich coffee flavor with chocolate and nutty tones. 7/5/8/3/16 - 3.9

Deep dark black porter with a thin moka head. Sweet chocoalte malts and light hops in aroma. Sharp crisp chocolate malts with coffee notes, roasted and pleasant. Rich nuts and nice hops in finale. Rich and sharp. On tap at Clarks Ale House, Summer 2005.
Great! Ive heard some have had bad bottles of this. Ive never had a bad one, so it remains a top of the line porter for me.

Looks beautiful in the glass with a big brown head and rich brown body.  Tastes like peanut butter and malt.  Creamy texture.  A bit sweet, but not too much.  Nice dry roasty bitterness in the finish.  A slight touch of alcohol.  Really nice beer for the fall or winter.  Just feels goo to drink.
Bottled. Pours black with a soft tan head. Aroma is roasted, malty, spicy. Taste is roasted dark malts and coffee

Very dark black pour, large dark tan frothy head.
Lactic cocoa and pine
Earthy sweet coffee taste. 
Very good qualities, though, a lot of the forefront had a piney quality that didnt seem to fit.

Bottle from dirtymike.  Thanks!  Pours a rich, dark brown with a healthy head and nice lacing.  Aroma is coffee, chocolate and roasted malt.  Flavor is a bit of sour malt with a fusion of coffee and a hint of cherry in the finish.  Palate is thin, but satisfactory.  A good porter.
user_location: Ugly, Hot, and Humid Spring, Texas, USA

text: for someone who doesnt like too many porters i loved this beer.  caramel strong head. wondeful roasted coffe toffe flavor and smell. this was so good i dropped a scoop of vanilla ice cream in the second one i had.  better than a rootbeer float any day.

(on tap at Portsmouth Brewing) Deep black with small tan head. Nice lace. Roast coffee aroma. Roast coffee flavors with balanced hops and malt. Full bodied. Not a lot of smokiness. They could have called it a stout. Really excellent porter.

Liquid Smoke !!!  Pours a dark black color with a creamy beige head.  Smells very smokey, very coffeish, with a hint of roasted malts.  Tastes like a stout at first sip.  Coffee flavor spiced with smoked wood chips best describes the taste.  One of the best porters ive ever had, if not the best.  Excellent.

Sample at the VTBrewfest - Poured a dark brown/black with a dense tan head.  Aroma was malty with hints of roasted malt, coffee and chocolate.  Excellent mouth feel.  Flavor was of roasted malt, coffee astringency and  a nice balance of malty sweetness.  Finishes off with a smooth, lingering hop bitterness.  Really good...

Draft. Baja Bean Staunton VA. Thick, blackish brown color, coffee colored head. Aroma of dark coffee, roasted flavored coffee, toasted malt, chocolate, etc. Mouth filling-- starts like a good draft stout, the sweetness of the porter style comes across in the middle, and it finishes more like a milk or oatmeal stout than a porter. Fantastic on tap.

Dark brown pour with tan head. Roasted malt, chocolate and nut aroma. Strong malt taste, quick bitter hop hit, smooths out with some coffee flavor and a final chocolate finish. Nice display of fireworks! And thank-you for the lesson in tasting.

<font face="times new roman">
Bold and unforgiving black hue with a sadly shortlived creamy, tan head.  Im truly at a loss for a clever story here...instead, Im going to give you a recipe for excellent brownies, because thats what this beer brings to mind.  Youll need: 2 squares unsweetened chocolate, 1 stick unsalted butter, 1 c. sugar, 1/2 c. all-purpose flour, 2 eggs, 1 tsp. vanilla, and 1 c. chopped nuts (optional).  Melt chocolate and butter.  Remove from heat and stir in sugar.  Add eggs, one at a time.  Stir in flour, vanilla, and nuts.  Pour into a greased 10x6" pan.  Cook at 350° for 30 minutes.  To bring it inline with this beer, consider grinding a handfull of espresso beans into a powder and sprinkling them on top.  Wonderful balance of rich chocolate sweetness and roasty coffee bitterness.  Hops could stand to be, well, nonexistent, but I can deal with them.  Significant body with an oily smoothness, broken only slightly by the carbonation.  Wie is de kleine krokodil? 

12 oz bottle, snifter.
</font>

Ahh, the robust porter, one of my favorite beers.

It has a bold black appearance, with a milk chocolate colored head which stays around and clings to the glass. So dark in color, that it is almost impenetrable to light.

This beer has a semi-sweet malt aroma, with hints of roastiness that lets you know that you are in for a treat.  The flavor is a roasty malt, with a nice balance of hops. The after taste includes hints of chocolate and coffee.

5.7% ABV and delicious.

Bottled.  Pours a dark browish black with a small well lacing brown head.  Looking thicker from the pour than a porter usually is.  Aroma is of roasted barley malt and chocolate with obvious yet subtle coffee and caramel notes.  Flavor is rich, sweet and chocolately upfront with roasty bitterness to complement.  Some slight smoke comes through as well.  Surprisingly a fair amount of hops come through in the flavor: citrussy and fruity.  Body is very full for a porter with great carbonation.  Great porter, though I hear it is being discontinued unfortunately.

Ok so I have a weakness for porters, but I REALLY liked this beer. Dark black-brown color with a coffee-colored head and decent strong roasted malty nose. Strong initial flavor of roasted something, giving way to a nice hoppy bite and mellowing to a lengthy aftertaste of bittersweet coffee. Just like a porter should.
on tap.  poured a dark black with a thin head.  Smoky malty aroma.  Flavor was toffee and coffee.  Decent beer

Pours a deep black color with a thick light brown head. Aroma of roasted malt and chocolate. Flavor of roasted and smoked malt with chocolate. Light to medium body, dry mouthfeel, moderate carbonation.

UPDATED: NOV 2, 2006 Pours dark with a brown head. Aroma of roasted malts and hops. The flavor is maimly roasted malts. Flavor also has a coffee-like quality, and a fair amount of hoppiness. GOOD BODY, GOOD BREW.

I have had this beer many, many times and is a recurrent occupant in my fridge. Robust it is, and leans more towards a stout in character. No problem, frankly I find the stylistic differences to be rather fuzzy anyway. Anway, this beer is dark, hoppy adn roasted, with a full moutfeel and a sweetish but roasty finish.

Bottle.  Brewed and bottled:  02/05.  Opaque jet-black pour with a medium-sized light-brown head that leaves tons of lace.  Aroma of creamy coffee, chocolate, cocoa and some bitter hops.  Lots of roasty malts and tons of bitter hops in the flavor.  A bit hoppier than most porters.  Creamy and dark chocolatey.  The aftertaste is all bitter hops and cocoa powder.  A great porter.

Beautiful solid black in color with a 1/2", frothy, tan head.  Really a beauty to behold.  Aroma is coffee, chocolate, cocoa butter and bitter.  Flavor is dry oats and dark chocolate overridden by deep roasted coffee.  Not pulling any surprises but pulls everything together oh so well.  Creamy at first, then transitions to a waxy resonance on the palate.  Heavy hopping leads strongly to bitterness, but heaps of roasted and chocolate malts help to balance it.  Bitter chocolate carries over to the finish, and then the beer just slips away, thinly diffusing.  Solid.  Thanks tpkenned!

UPDATED: FEB 10, 2006 Bottle, both Aug. and Oct. are marked.  August has a bigger snip so lets pretent its from that mont.  A huge head on this guy, but I did pour it kind of fast.  Earthy, malty aroma: raisins, potting soil, cigar wrappers, and a touch of sour, the mixer stuff.  The flavor has the same dry earthy notes but with dark fruity malt under it and coffee on top.  Target-y hops are in the finish, but they take a far backseat to the earthy malt.  Full-bodied mouthfeel with low carbonation; fits the beer very well.  If I had this stuff at a festival I bet itd score in the low 3s.  This really is a sipping/savoring beer, the chocolatey / earthy malts linger on the palate making for a small malt nirvana.

Pours dark dark brown with a big rich creamy chocolate brown lacy head. Smells of big malt and milk chocolate.

Taste is very smoky. Strong coffee flavors with biter chocolate lurking beneath the surface. Dry bitter finish. Big bodied witha strong bitter aftertaste. Lots of big flavors in this brew but it is really smooth and extremely drinkable. This is my kind of beer. Could put down a six of this without thinking about it. Chocolate silk.

12 oz bottle with a bottled date of March 04. This poured out with a black body and a large light brown head that I had to quickly sip before it went overboard. Roasted malts and coffee were strong in the aroma with a good bit of bittersweet dark chocolate present as well. Overall the smell was pretty darn strong and good. The taste followed suite with strong coffee and roasted flavors stirring about and a nice chocolate staying in the background. The after taste was a lingering roasted one. About medium in body with a bit of a sticky mouthfeel. Very drinkable porter overall that goes down very easy and is flavorful enough to keep from getting boring. A great one for any one to try.
Bottled. Black color with a beige head. The taste is sweet with light coffee flavors. Hops dominate the palate with a slight dryness.

a bottle from RichlikeBeer.  dark brown with a quickly fading tan head.  a medium bodied porter with a bittersweet chocolate flavor.  on the finish, the hops are mild and there is a hint of a coffee flavor.  there seems to be an underlying acidic taste that just doesnt sit right on my palate.  not bad by any means, just not right for me.

Bottled. Black colour with a beige head.
Extremely complex aroma of coffee, grass, hops and chocolate.
Flavour of chocolate, coffee and grass.
Thanks Ivan for sharing.

This beer poured a beautiful ebony in the glass and you did not have to put your nose to the glass to smell the roasted coffeee and dark cocoa. 

A small, but thick tan head, that quickly dissapates to a dirty ring that clings to the glass all the way down.

The beer has a medium texture with a taste transition from sweet to hoppy and bitter. Somewhat syrupy on the palate, with a hoppy bitter finish. 

One great Porter and triumph from Smuttynose.
Dark brown body with a dense light brown head. Very nice aroma with roasted malts, coffee notes and a nice sweet touch. Roasted malty flavor, but really not that complex.
Bottle. Black colour with a medium baige head. Roasted coffee chocolat aroma and a soft roasted malty hoppy coffee taste. Medium body and a roasted dry finish.

black body, garnet edges.  dark tan/sienna rocky head.  sweet roasted malt/graham cracker/cocoa aroma.  very dry roasted malt and coffee flavor.  medium carbonation but somehow biting.  hoppy aftertaste.

Very dark blackish color with tan head.  The head goes away quick.  Standard aroma of roasted malt, coffee and chocolate.  Sweet palate that ends with a nice hops kick.  Full - bodied well - made porter.
A nice porter. Aroma and taste of coffee, chocolate, hops and roasted malt. Black with a brown head.
Black with brown head. Aroma has notes of hops. Taste is good with notes of hops, chocolate, roasted malt and sweetness.
Nice and dark.  Lots of chocolate, coffee and malt going on.  There is a hint of hops which blends in well.  A very nice drink.

(on bottle) being this a porter, I have to argue the fact that IO thought it was a Stout: "I thought this beer to be more like a stout". That said, I liked it a lot; pitch black, witch small beige head. Comes out with a kind of soft nose, vanilla, roast, toffee and comes in with a lot of burnt caracter. becomes a little to tart after half a drink.

UPDATED: MAY 19, 2005 12 oz. bottle.  Pours black with a thin head without much staying power.  Aroma is of coffee and chocolate.  Perfect level of carbonation on the tongue.  Flavor is roasty.  Overall, pretty nice beer even though Im not a big fan of porters.

rich chocolate aroma with just a tad bit of hops.  deep brown opaque color, head was a little thin, a brown layer that evaporated quickly. medium to full bodied mouthfeel, with a burnt flavor coming in early and chocolates smoothing out into the end. almost no bitterness on the tail, making the end very smooth and clean tasting.

UPDATED: DEC 6, 2006 Bottle from Lou18. Very nice! Pours with a deep black color and a beautiful brown head. Great lacing. Aroma is full of chocolate and coffee. Medium bodied and smooth. Pleasant chocolate flavors and a nice hoppy finish. Well done!8/4/8/4/16

Bottle from Santa consumed Dec. 06. Black colored with a light brown/beige head. Nice lacing. Aroma is roasty and chocolatey, fairly pleasing. Medium bodied, smooth carbonation. Chocolate flavors with a bit of acrid roasted malt that is a bit over done. Lingering bitterness, seemingly from the malt. Really a pretty decent porter but Im knocking it down a few points from the previous rating. Irrational exuberance?
Aroma of coffee, and alcohol.  Pours black with a brow head.  Taste of chocolate and coffee.  Cannot detect the alchol in the palate.  The perfect night cap.
UPDATED: FEB 7, 2007 Definitly a Robust Porter. Roasted and toasted malt. A mouthful of flavor with a dry bitter finish. Great for dessert or on a cold night.

UPDATED: JUL 10, 2005 Dark brown pour with an off white head.  The aroma is dominated by coffee beans and also has mocha and hops.  Solid but not real complex.  The taste is kind of like the IPA but with coffee and mocha added to it.  This is very hoppy for a Porter which is interesting.  There is some roast in the flavor resembling coffee beans.  It works effectively here.  This is a fine Porter that I cant wait to try again.

Dark, translucent, reddish-brown body with a tan head. Hoppy aroma with some interesting fruitiness. Very plummy with some light roast. More roast emerges in the flavor. Tastes like burnt plums and C-hops. Nice assertive bitterness. Medium-full body. Very enjoyable and distinct. Thanks Eric.
UPDATED: JUN 14, 2005 an excellent porter.  stong on the coffee flavor and smell.  nice and thick.  not super complex though.
Solidly coffee dominant flavor.  Very good, thick mouthfeel for a porter.  Probably the best Ive had of this style.
UPDATED: JUN 27, 2005 on draft, very creamy and tasty, and free.  thanks very much to john bylander.  a great american porter.

Deep brown almost black with a deep beige head which lasts.  Aroma is of toffee and chocolate.  I didnt notice too much roastiness although there was some.  Ths is what I like about good porters.  Stouts are good with roasted barley- porters not so much.  Flavor is of slight burnt malts and some chocolate along with a good hoppy bitterness to balance out the thick malty body.  Medium to big body and mouthfeel, with a good smooth silky finish.  A very rich and complex porter deserving of its high overall score.
Bottle: Pours almost black with a nice medium sized brown head. Aroma of dark roasted malt, a bit of coffee. Flavor is rich, loads of roasted malt and a bitter coffee finish. Full bodied. Very nice.

UPDATED: DEC 6, 2008 [12 oz. bottle] Dark black with red highlights and a very slight tan head. Very rich and tasty coffee, chocolate and burnt malt aroma. The flavor is extremely full of toasted malts, coffee and has a nice chocolate finish to it. Extremely smooth, easy to drink and quite delicious. Very nice sweet malt aftertaste. Am definitely going to buy this one again.

Delicious dark chocolate aroma.  No head/no lacing.  Pours a thin, dark brown.  Heavy malt, chocolate, and coffee notes with the perfect touch of bitterness.  Body is medium with a bitter coffee and cocoa aftertaste that lingers perhaps a bit too long.  Quite good overall though - would buy again.
Bottled. Maybe a bad bottle! Very nice aroma and appearance, however the after taste of this beer made me feel I just licked the ash tray!!!

thanks to doclock for this very good porter.poured a black body with with a nice chocolaty head.the aroma was a mix of coffee, chocolate,some metal,and a hine of sourness.the flavor was much of the same with a little smoke thrown in for good measure.the mouth feel was nice and thick and it coated my mouth even after sipping it.this is a very nice robust porter.

dark brown, thich brown cookie-like head. Robust aroma! Loads of dark and bitter chocolate, cocoa, nuts and hops. Full chocolate flavour with hints of cocoa, black coffee, almunds and raw bitter hops. Long aftertaste of bitter chocolate and hops. Decadent!

Ah, the sweet dry chocolate amlt greets my nose even as it pors.Thick creany tan head, the is not moving. mmmmm, the taste is roasted almost burnt coffe, with some bittering at the end. And the carbination is good, and the hops wisp up to the nose as the taste lingers long. This is an excellent porter.

Ah, the lovely expresso-flourless chocolate cake dry aroma greets me.  This bodes well.  A tight, tan, long lasting head.  Ich bin Schnappi, das kleine Krokodil.  Gobs of roasted malt and chocolate flavor in a great body with fine carbonation.  Finishes dry and leaves the dusty roast of dry coffee grounds behind.  I would have liked a little chocolate milk flavor thrown in there, but this is very nice.

2005 Bottle.  Aroma of chocolate and coffee with hints of vanilla and oaky bitterness.  Smooth beginning with a nice flavors roasted caramel malts and coffee undertones.  This slightly sweet smoothness is complimented with a bitter-hoppy finish.  Definiterly still tasting vanilla.  The base is alittle watery for my liking...would be amazing if it was unfiltered.

Pours jet black with a thin tan head that mostly dissipates.  Aroma is sweet roasted caramel malt and black coffee with a nose that is tart and fruity hop that makes you salivate just thinking about the tartness.  Plums and honey also come through in the aroma.  The flavor is bitterly sweet dark roasted coffee with a hoppiness on the end.  The palate is dark and dry with a fizzy and tingling mouthfeel.  Some thick lacing.

Aroma:Cofee and light chocolate
Appearance:Black with a good head
Flavor:Chocolate and small cofee torefaction.

Large thick tan head. Very dark brown almost black body. Aroma is a nice roasted malt and some nuts. Hints of good coffee. I love a roasty porter. Taste is a very full bodied toast and coffee. Hints of dark chocolate and even raspberries. This also has a little vanilla. A slick almost creamy mouthfeel. This is very nice. Everything a porter should be.

Aroma:  chocolate, coffee, cream, and sugar

Appearance:  dark brown, tan head, lacing

Flavor:  bakers chocolate, coffee, cream, brown sugar

Palate:  smooth, creamy, a bit of bitter bakers chocolate and cream aftertaste

Poured black with a tan head that left thick lacing on the glass.  Fruity malt aroma with a slight hint of chocolate.  Taste is bitter roasted chocolate with very little sweetness.  I found the bitterness to be somewhat unbalanced and unpleasant, but still a good porter.
I loved this beer! The chocolate aroma and its nutty after swallow was a treat for my palate. I found my favorite porter.

Brown frothy head atop a black beer. Does not pass the flashlight test but is definitely darker than the style nazis would like. Huge caramel and chocolate aromas with a small hint of grassy hops. Some figiness too. Very full mouthfeel with a lot of sweet dextrins. A big burnt character with enough malty backbone to balance out the dryness of all the black patent. This is a great porter.

Black w/tan head. Aroma of roasted malts, smoke, soy.  Palate is dry and a bit chalky,,lots of great roasted malt flavor. A little sour note, but absolutely nothing unpleasant about this porter..Alot of good flavor. Great.
Extremely flavorful porter, with no detectable flaw. Very drinkable; like it better than Anchors, or Sierras, which were my previous choices for bottled porters...

BottleBlack or dark brown. Big and thick creamy head of tan. Nice lacing. It looks awesome. Aromas of dark malts such as chocolate and roast. Coffee comes out with some bittering hops. Theres some lactose. Flavor is pretty strong on the bitter coffee. It effectively mutes the chocolate presented in the nose. There is a lot more roast present as well. Slightly milky flavors. Creamy mouthfeel. Stickhy and lingering palate with a bitter and roasty finish. This beer surprised me. I had not thought it would be so good. Thanks DYC!

On tap. Dark black with a medium size tan head. Rich, roasted malt aroma with
hints of coffee and hops. Roasted malt flavor with lots of coffee, chocolate
and a dry, hoppy finish.

Rich black color with a crimson blood pour, light smoke colored head & lacing. Nose of bittersweet milk chocolate, vanilla beans, tobacco and Worcestershire sauce (minus the salt). The roast level is present but not too astringent. It tastes bitter with the typical roast levels, nothing too unexpected. Has an astringent finish that ends dry. This is a fairly full bodied & complex porter.

Robust?  Id say.  Bottle.  Black.  Very black.  I poured it and the room got dark.  Virtually no head to speak of, just a collection of tan bubbles.  Lots of coffee and chocolate in the nose.  Very sweet aroma.  Some soap (?!) too.  First sip ... very roasty.  Also, very chocolatey and coffee-y.  It finishes a little hoppy and bitter, and dry.  Overall, its not too bad
Pours black with a small beige head. Aroma of charcoal, coffee, and chocolate. Very nice roasted flavor, with some of that chocolate in the aftertaste. Good stuff.
Smells and tastes of chocolately coffee, but mostly coffee. Roasted, tasty malts all throughout. Finishes dry. Very nice.

A black beer with a chocolate brown head. The aroma is of chocolate and coffee. While the flavor is sour with notes of coffee leading up to a dry end. But the body is unfortunately thin. Thanks Mike for trading this one with Jeppe.
Awesome looking porter.  Dark, dark brown body topped with a thick, foamy, beige head.  Roasted malt aroma.  Mostly coffee in the flavor.  A little bit of chocolate, a little burnt.  Great porter!

Dark brown body, thick brown head. Coffee, lots of it, in the aroma with a roasted tone. Dark roasted almost burned flavor, again with plenty of coffee, Little thin in the finish. Another good one from Mike (Eyedrinkale)!

Bottle - thanks to slob!  Pours ebony brown with a large foamy tan head that diminished mostly.  Lovely aroma, rich roasty chocolatey malts and floral, earthy hops.  Sweet, sweet malt flavor, hints of chocolate with a coffee bitterness and tart and dry, hop finish.  Full body and tingly carbonation.  Very enjoyable beer.  Yea Bert!

Bottled: Pitch black coloured. Light brown dense head. Coffee, roast, malt and light fruit notes in the aroma. Flavour is cholatish and roasty and somewhat watery. Thin bodied and light roasty in the end.
Loads of coffee in the nose, very intense. Black body, with a ruby tint, small tan head. Coffee and roasty flavor. A bit thin in the flavor.

Black with a large tan head. Aroma is rather sweet, with chocolate, caramel and raisins, but roasted as well. Flavor starts sweet (chocolate, brown sugar) and quickly turns into a bitter espresso-like taste, with smoke and burnt at the end. Light carbonation and oily texture. This ends up so bitter it is almost salty...

Beautiful thick khaki head that is huge at first but will minimize to a thin frothy head.  Lacing leaves a bit of a smeared tan residue on the glass.  Aroma is sweet caramel and smells just like mocha ice cream.  Strong in its taste compared to other porters but then again thats why its called robust porter.  A rich flavor of cocoa bean and caramel syrup.  Light chocolate added but is barely noticeable. Thanx Eyedrinkale

UPDATED: JAN 20, 2006 Trade from Eyedrinkale. Thanks.

Smelled like warm just baked chocolate cookies and fresh brewed coffee. Poured like a stout. Dark black with a pinky thickness head that stuck around. Looked like a perfect stout pour instead of a light frothy porter. Flavor was creamy chocolate malts, but still roasty and full in the middle with a slightly bitter black chocolate and coffee finish.


The taste of a stout too just thinned down a little. Bitter end, but more of the chocolate and coffe and even some very mild sweetness. Appropriate porter mouthfeel. 

Good stuff.
Rating #300 and glad I picked this to be it.  Very dark, very roasted aroma.  Amazing coffee taste with a hint of chocolate.  All roasty and toasty.  Cmon cowboy light your fire!

Pours a dark black with a large brown head.  Aroma is bitter sweet chocolate, coffee, and roasted malts.  Flavor is more coffee than chocolate but both are dominant.  Lightly bitter finish.  a little thin, light body.  Medium length finish of bitterness and coffee.
Poured a dark black with a large (3 finger) brown head. Strong chocoalte aroma with roasted malts. Coffee comes out in the taste. Lightly bitter finish. Solid porter.

Poured black with nice lasting brown head...roasty aroma with hints of sweet chocolate and coffee...taste was rich and roasty...mild chocolate but a lot of coffee for a porter...still a little thin for me...finish was coffee hop bitter...great porter though!!

This beer poured a thick, viscous, black vile color with a massive orangey head which provided plenty of lacing on my glass. The aroma was strong then whafted away very quickly with chocolate, heavy hops, grass and coffee/mocha notes being present. The carbonation level is light even though it look menacing on the initial pour. The flavor is thick and syrupy, very west coast in its porter approach..one helluva hop bitterness in the finish. Chocolate grainyness, dry, smokey, a hint of pork its so smokey...malty but IBUeeeeeeyyyy bitterness in the finish. Thick and viscous in taste...medium to full bodied..leaning more toward the latter.

UPDATED: OCT 16, 2004 2004 bottle.  From my oversized snifter this thing is just pitch black. I held it to a bunch of different lights and looked at it from all angles.  Black.  Huge creamy mocha head and a small amount of fine sediment at the bottom of the bottle.  Im going to start off by talking about the flavor because this beer is about one thing, black malt.  Wow.  It dosent come on heavy at first, but its definitely dominant even from the start.  Bitter, black roast coffee. Im thinking, "Ive never done it, but I bet sucking on coffee rinds kinda tastes like this."  Its not all coffee, roast and bitterness though, there is some lingering sweetness that peeks in, probably some light chocolate malt.  Rich and bitter it remains, with some black licorice notes as well.  On the finish, I detect some alcohol mixed in with the extreme bitterness.  Hops are done right, in its defense, making a big but not ridiculous appearance (or is it the bitterness from the roasted malt? the bitterness comes at you from every angle).  Towards the end of the bottle and after the beer has warmed fully, the black malt takes over completely and it just gets out of control.  My last few sips as I polish this off are all black, bitter, burnt notes.  The mouthfeel really saves this one though, adding a smooth, creamy, medium-full body, with only minimal carbonation.  It naturally follows that the aroma would be quite weak, as black malt does not tend to be a friend of powerfully full aromas.  Its a good roasty, lightly chocolatey aroma, but not what it should be for the force of this beer.
Pours black with a minimal tan head.  Sweet aroma. Rich, coffee taste with a bitter chocolate aftertaste. A very well done porter. More on the bitter side than others.

Pours deep brown/black with a rocky tan malted mild head. Heavily roasted aroma of chocolate and coffee. Plenty of hop. Rich, full bodied and oily. Brown sugar. A little wood and smoke. Some late citrus. Salt in the long roasted finish. Great porter.

Fully black color, below a rich, tan, though woefully brief, head. Aroma is strong and powerful, rich with notes of cocoa, coffee, and butternut. Slightly oily texture, but with plenty of grit. Full body, sweet, strong, substantial, with a tasty acidity and tang. Small bitterness, and solid malt. Sweet and bitter at once. Roasty, toasty, and above all, tasty. A little syrupy toward the end, but that didnt spoil my enjoyment of this fine porter.

UPDATED: FEB 8, 2006 Near black with a glimpse of ruby when held to the light. Moderate light tan head. Roasted malts and coffee, along with a hint of dark cocoa in the aroma. Thicker, near oily feel. Sweet malt flavor start, intermixed with roasted malts, dark chocolate and coffee. Like a fresh, rich chocolate chip cookie. When it warms the hops do come out a bit heavy, but the malts are still in play and help hold it together to the end. Thanks for the brew DocLock.  Spell correct rerate.
OBF 2004.  Rich coffee nose, some milk, creamy cherries and a little scotch.  Rich roasted malts and some burnt cherries in the flavor, lots of wood with some charred wood in the finish.
Full bodied and full of flavor- top notch porter. Toss up between this beer and the Scotch Ale from Smuttynose as to which is my favorite.

Eclipse brown color. Medium sized white head. Aroma is chocolate, roasted malts and vanilla. A medium to full bodied porter. Malts are roasted, chocolate, coffee and vanilla. Hops are fairly aggressive and grapefruity. A big, bold, hoppy porter. There are also flavors of bittersweet chocolate and raisins as well. Mouthfeel is full and round. Finish is clean and smooth. Aftertaste is slightly bitter.

Visually appealing with a black body and foamy tan head.  Aroma was subdued.  Some chocolate, prunes, toffee, roasted coffee.  Medium body, on the watery side, slight carbonation.  Flavor was bitter chocolate and coffee with some prune/raisin/plum notes.  Thanks, Jeff, for the trade.
dark brown with a big tan head, this porter has a nice body. good roastiness with a rich flavor. Complex, yet drinkable. This is a well done beer.

Dark brown with a big tan head. Aroma is dominated my roast and coffee. Taste is agian roasty, chocolatey, smokey, and bitter. Lots of complexity going on here. Finishes malty and bitter. A little too roasty for me for a porter, but still a very drinkable beer.
Dark brown and full-bodied. Richly flavored with coffee, chocolate and very smokey. A very nice beer.
Dark brown and thick.  Lots of malty flavors with some wood-smoke, chocolate and others.  Finishes clean and dry.  Very nice.
thick small head. one of of the top porters ive had. it was smoother than others. and had good amount of flavoring. malty.

This is a damn good porter. Well crafted with a nice smoked flavor malt which is complemented with crisp hops. Head is tawny and well maintained.  The flavor harbors such treats as chocolate, anise and coffee while the palate is clean, crisp and fresh.  It could use a tad more carbonation for my liking.  Overall, quite stout-like but still very much a porter.
