[email protected]/* <![CDATA[ */!function(t,e,r,n,c,a,p){try{t=document.currentScript||function(){for(t=document.getElementsByTagName('script'),e=t.length;e--;)if(t[e].getAttribute('data-cfhash'))return t[e]}();if(t&&(c=t.previousSibling)){p=t.parentNode;if(a=c.getAttribute('data-cfemail')){for(e='',r='0x'+a.substr(0,2)|0,n=2;a.length-n;n+=2)e+='%'+('0'+('0x'+a.substr(n,2)^r).toString(16)).slice(-2);p.replaceChild(document.createTextNode(decodeURIComponent(e)),c)}p.removeChild(t)}}catch(u){}}()/* ]]> */ One of the beers i bought back from the US. Such a tasty porter, really smoky roasted malt flavour, bitter chocolate to finish, burnt, roasted, some espresso. Nice dry finish, well made, very tasty indeed.

Well, this isnt exactly the most robust-bodied porter, but it is flavorful.  The oily, rather thin body pours chestnut brown, topped by a thin light tan head.  Licorice, molasses, and plenty of roasted, burnt malt in the aroma.  Chalky notes complement brown sugar and raisin as well.  The flavor is dominated by roasted malt, molasses, a hint of vanilla, woodiness, and a surprisingly bitter hops aftertaste.  A bit dry with a touch of soy.  Good porter.

Beer #12 at Spiesys. Deep reddish/black colour. This one screams out "coffee" at every turn. Chocolate too and very opulent and sumptuous in feel. Silk might be right in describing it as one-dimensional, but I like it. Perhaps Im just a simple guy. The only let down was that, in common with a number of the other US beers we sampled, the flavour was nowhere near as intense as the aroma. But perhaps it might have got a bit overwhelming had the aromas carried through - a bit like gorging on rich Belgian chocolates. I thought it was more like a stout too. Bottled.

Another first tonight. First New Hampshire beer. Smuttynose Robust Porter is a very powerful beer with lots of chocolate and coffee flavorings.  Very potent. Great beer!!! Dark volcanic glass liquid thats gets you attention and keeps it throughout the experience. Great beer courtesy of Ross.

Bottle @ Spiesys gaff. I cant remember who brought what, but a lot of the American stuff was supplied by Duff. This was a very decent round in which we got into some of the heavyweight darkies. Huge coffee aroma - soft, creamy yet very coffee. Decent, though it was more about impact than quality. Coffee again in the flavour - and little else. A touch of cream and a hint of vanilla. Another one-dimensional coffee stout - I had a bunch of these at the Reading Festival. Theyre nice and Ill drink this one again, but it really needs something extra to make one of these stand out. Moors Old Freddy Walker is one such exceptional beer Ive had recently.

Deep Garnet out of the bottle turning to pitch in the glass, Big oily mocha head leaving tons of lacing down the glass.  Thick firm mouthfeel full of coffee and coco powder.  Touches of anise, thick chocolat malts, and a little hoppyness.  Long malty cold coffee beans with a touch of sweetness and slight herbal, earthy hops. Wow, just wow.

Bottle pours black with dark brown hues, medium frothish tan colored head, with attractive lacing.   Heavy aroma of roasted malts and slight coffee.   Forwardly coffee like, faint taste of bittersweet chocolate, finishing with hop bitterness and roasted malts.   Slightly chalkish and dry on the  finish.   Body and mouthfeel are a tad thin, at least I was wishing it would be meatier.   Otherwise, not bad.   Thanks goes out to ross8425 for the trade!

Roasted malt and licorice in the aroma. Opaque dark brown, almost black, with line of tan head that lasts very nicely. Extremely roasty flavour with sweet malt base that never quite manage to connect. Roasty and chalky in the finish. Medium-full body but very dry. Bottle (sampled at Mondial 2004).
black as night. Roast coffee aroma and taste, with cookie chocolate smoothness. Good balanced stout, between malt, carbonation, not too bitter

UPDATED: OCT 1, 2007 a very nice example of a porter.  Smells of coffee and chocolate, and a strong roasted flavor.  Nice and malty.  Quite enjoyable.

RERATE: Black pour with a very nice head of dark cream lace. Aroma is a beautiful enticing mix of smooth roast and chocolate. The flavor is a little more bitter than the aroma would suggest. There is nice chocolate and some bitter roast; maybe a touch of hops. A simple but effective porter. This has classic written all over it.

RERATE:  Black pour with a nice creamy tan head.  Roasty chocolate aroma.  Chocolaty smooth flavor with a dry roasted finish.  Great stuff.

Deep black with a tan head.  There is a very big aroma.  Its somkey and roasted with a very faint hint of meatyness.  This is robust as advertised.  The somkey roasted malts fill the mouth and linger nicely.  There is big, big malt flavor.  Along with the roasted some coffee is noticable.  Its clean and very tasty.  Thanks to DocLock for this one.
Strong roasted flavor easily identified coffee and chocaolate. Comes off more as a stout than a porter.Strong aftertaste, long lasting head.
UPDATED: MAR 3, 2005 Very poundable porter. But with a ABV of 5.6% makes it an expensive task to measure the buzz. Make it 7+ and its a classic.

this label is odd, but none of theres are really what you would expect.  good porter- smells coffee like, pours like the usual porter would.  creamy coffee flavor with slight hints of chocolate.  this is a really good porter, but it cannot surpass fullers or alpha klause, but then again as porters go, what can?  still a great brew.  drank this one in a glass.  previously drank it from a bottle and hot, and it was still good.  nice beer.
Bizarre label. A sweet and strong porter, amazing it is only 5.7 ABV. However coffee notes and quite roasted.

Pours a nice dark brown with a great light tan head. Aroma is very roasty with a nice hint of coffee. Taste is very creamy and smooth with a great coffee taste. Very roasty and ends nice and bitter. Great porter.
Nice coffee caramel aroma. The palate is dry and roasty with a nice coffee bit. Long bitter chocolate finish. A well rounded complex porter.

Pours deep brown with a caramel head that is thick and dense.  Aromas of coffee, roasted malt, chocolate and caramel.  Coffee flavor is most prominent but also bittersweet chocolate, caramel and toffee.  Good sweetness with excellent lacing.  Smooth, creamy, thick and rich with excellent hop and malt balance.  Very little alcohol bite.  Great palate with bitter finish.  Excellent beer, a must try.
Pours a thick dark brown with a dark tan head.  Bitter and smooth with a coffee undertone.  A very nice and flavorful porter.

Nearly opaque with ruby highlights that produced a small frothy head and very good lacing. The aroma hints of smoke, caramel malts, hazelnut, floral and grassy hops, subdued mocha, plum, and dusty yeast esters. The taste starts with a heavy malt character and major tones of smoke, coffee, and toffee. Good bitter balance and nutty undertones followed by a fruity snap. Good mouthfeel, creamy and soft but still crisp around the edges of the palate. A fine porter indeed. Shows good complexity and depth. This beer is a must try.

My 50th rating:  Pours a pretty thick, lasting, dark tan head.  Virtually opaque black.  (This beer's appearance is its best characteristic.)  Sweet aroma, coffee and chocolate; some caramel.  Flavor predominantly coffee, with some chocolate and vanilla.  Feels pretty thick and rich but a bit on the sugary/syrupy side.  Smuttynose has not disappointed me yet!
Excellent roasty porter. Very malty and roasty. Chocolate aroma. Very dark brown with a nice tan head. Flavor is big.

Tap. Very dark brown with a tan head. Need a strong light to see all the way through. Roasty aroma. Flavor is big and bold, with lots of hop bitterness and a nice roasty malt flavor. This beer was on the chewey side, robust, and satisfying.
user_location: Good Beer Bar Deprived, New Jersey, USA

text: Deep black, dark brown head.  Lots of burnt coffee grounds, dark bittersweet chocolate, and a hint of caramel in the nose.  Rich flavors of earthy sumatra coffee, dark chocolate, citrus, vanilla, and a touch of wood.  Medium to full bodied, nice biting finish.  This is a very nice porter.

Bottled - bought at Happy Deli NYC.  Fantastic aroma of roasty coffee.  Big black colour, however let down by a virtually non-existant head.  The taste however is excellent.  Full, roasty, long, stronger than its ABV.  A very very good beer.

A beautiful rich looking black beer. Caramel and vanilla and coffee and molasses combine to make a slightly-too-sweet beer that lingers a touch longer than you really need it to....but it's tasty enough to get away with it. Nice.

Jet black; dark brown head, gone in seconds. Nose of coffee, bit of tobacco-ash, hints of dark-blue fruit. Kahlúa or other coffee-liqueur?
Very tobbacy-o taste - this is remarkable. The palate is quite bitter, the taste isn't. It just seems to beg to have raisins in it, or to be drunk with a smoked sausage or a good Italian salami. I want to taste some hops, but they just don't emerge. Warming up, I do get the taste of bitter chocolate, filled with the raisins and rum. And, of course, tobacco. Very full-bodied, rich, without getting oppressive. Anyway you look at it, this is an impressive beer, the more as this isn't really my style. "Kudo's" as they say. BIG thanks to D. Anderson for supplying me this row of beers, that made up my last few days of rating.

Pours opaque, with a slight reddish hue. Nice big frothy tan head. Aroma is mildy sweet. Lots of coffee and dark chocolate. Full and creamy mouthfeel. Freshly ground coffee, caramel, dark chocolate, and wood. Nice dry hop finish. A pretty damn good porter.

One of my favorite porters, but I have a hard time finding it in PA.  Very nice brownish head, with a crisp, malty flavor.  I picked up overtones of maple syrup, brown sugar, coffee, and roasted malt.  The aftertaste is pleasantly sweet and rich.  A very good, very robust porter.  As a bonus, I've had women ask me, "What is the picture on this label."
impressive frothy tan head.  very roasty and smoky nose, some coffee.  body is heavy and complex, like burnt oak and coffee.  nice and thick, with a crisp bitter finish.

Bottle: Good nose, Coffee with cream in it. Clean reddish/blackish brown color. Nice head tan/brown. Roasted bitter flavors. Coffee, chocolate, grapefruit, carmel all come to mind. Nice mouth feel Kinda syrupy, bitter finish. Another winner from Smuttynose. I can't beleive I haven't had this one sooner. I'll be having this alot more.
user_location: the Containment Area, North Carolina, USA

text: Bottled.  Deep black colour with a rich brown head. Miles of roasted malt flavours. Rich smooth chocolate flavour. Lovely roasted flavours. Rich nose and silky palate make this beer a real treat.

Deep black pour with a light tan head. Nice aroma. Slim chocolate aroma. Some roasted coffee as well. Smoked taste. Hoppy as well. Very impressive! A very well done Porter. I'm really glad I had the chance to try this beer. Bought this 12 oz bottle from Beers of the World in Rochester, NY.

Opaque dark brown with a sticky brown chocolate small head, rapidly becomes a film. Aroma of big columbian coffee beans, dark chocolate, milk blended in a rather low-profile expressiveness. Taste is also coffeeish in its malt development, but an unexpected strong piney/resinous/citrusy bitterness indicate a large hop presence and make the finish very long. Medium bodied and perhaps a tad overcarbonated, but I'm judging it against its Great Lakes rival. Good porter that wears its name with great pride, but I didn't enjoy it as much as I expected. I prefer the clean smokey/roasty to straightforward citrusy bitter finish I guess.

Good roasted malt aroma with coffee and chocolate coming through. Light brown full head with a black opaque color. Really good roasted malt flavor with a slight sweetness from the caramel malt? Rich expresso type coffee flavor but not overly bitter. An excellent example of a robust porter!
Brown-black and a thin tan head.  Smoky aroma here and coffee-smoke flavors.  Nicely bittered.  Bit thin.
Black appearance with a tan head. Aroma is chocolate and dark fruit. Roasted malt, wood, and bitter chocolate flavor. An above average porter.

I really like the label...Nice aroma, black appearance, with a tan head.  Like most porters, this tastes of roasted malts, coffee, and chocolate, with a bitter finish; however, I don't know what it is, but there is something special about this porter.  Enjoyed it.

This brew was one from my 03 Secret Santa, SLOB, Thanks for the terrific surprises buddy!  
A deep pool of black with edges of crimson….. the soft fizzy caramel head shortly stands then takes a nap. I take a whiff….. nose of coco, cappuccino, raisins and Smores; you know, marshmallow – gram crackers – chocolate – and campfire.
 The flavor is toasty and charred,   heavily kilned chocolate malts, lots of hard wood burning camp fire, rustic and heavy on the malt baby! 
 BRB, I need some water to cleanse the palate…………… Nope, it’s just that smoky & chocolaty…. Nice hops bringing up the tale end here. Silky palate, finish is a bitter/sweet dryness, Good toasty coco malty porter!  
Post Note: Hints of Maduro Cigar and black liquorish.
Opaque black body, dark tan rocky head.  Coffee and chocolate in the aroma.  Flavor dominated by bitter chocolate, with a sweetness that lingers in the back of the mouth for a while.  Nice.
Ths is a good looking Porter that really comes on as it warms. Toffee aroma with a flavor of chocolate, coffee and caramel underneath. Long smooth finish. Very nice!

This beer was almost perfect. A sweet creamy flavour with coffee and chocolate notes mixed with a mild taste of hops.  The only let down was the head was kind of small and was a little water on the tounge.  Truly a robust porter.

Delicious porter aroma, nothing bad or out of the ordinary.  Nice, deep, dark, brown colour, just what a porter should be.  Head dissipated rather quickly, but I didn't leave very large head to begin with.  Flavour is delicious, a bit bitter - but that should decrease a little as the beer warms up.  Perfect palate, not too thick like a certain Irish stout we all know, not thin at all.  Feels just right.

Deep chocolate brown. The tan head rose to great heights then subsided all at once. Smell is bitter chocolate and cinnamon; taste is bitter chocolate, coffee, cinnamon and molasses. A decent attempt to combine the porter and spiced Winter beer styles.Earlier Rating: 7/5/2003 Total Score: 3.8Black color, light brown head. Delicious aromas of coffee, chocolate and vanilla promise good things to come. The taste is espresso coffee and bittersweet dark chocolate overlaid with a peppy hoppy bite. The finish is smooth with a lingering bitterness and a touch of alcohol warmth. One I'll buy again.

12 oz: Thick, opaque darkness; Black.  Hearty aroma, thick with smoke, burnt toast, alcohol, raisins, roasted berries, and dark cocoa powder.  A bit chalky on the palate, that somehow turns milky and smooth in the finish.  Flavours are chocolately nuts, earthy fruits (plums), and alcohol.  In all the flavour was a bit one dimensional, but tasty no less.

Very dark black with ever so slight hints of ruby. A medium creamy tan head. The arom is very nice, hppy grapefruit then loads of chocolate and roasted malts. The flavor is more choclate less hops but still very nice. The body is medium-full and very smooth. A slight bit of plastic flavor develops on the palate after a bit, but it does not detract from the overall beer.

Dark brown approaching black.  Full, thick, brown head.  Super roasty aroma.  Burnt toast, coffee, bitter chocolate and a caramel or molasses sweetness.  Average body.  The flavor is strong and intensely bitter and roasted.  Burnt toast dipped in burnt coffee.  Some hops in the finish to compliment the roasted character.  A nice straight up roasty porter.
Bottle. Poured nice and dark with light coffee, malt and chocolate nose. Not much lacing to speak of. Worth trying one.

Not a bad porter, but it was mild in flavor.  There was some roastiness, some coffee and some chocolate, but all of the flavors were on the mild side.   This was just a mediocre porter, although it was very drinkable due to its mildness.

Nice porter.Smells of roasty chocolate and coffee.Nice big head yet quickly dissapating into nice brown lace.This beer is dark yet shows some mohogany around the edges in light.Nice taste.Reminds me of the Ruffian porter my dad and I used to quaff together.The hops are certainly there but only complement this fine ale.The palate is roasty/choc-coffee w/a nice little edge of bitterness given by the proper use of hops.This one hits the spot for a high quality porter.This is very much like the Rogue mocha yet gets a better responce.Gets better as it warms.Bottled on 10/11/03.
Not much of a head here.  The nose is coffee and chocolate.  Bitter at first, which is washed away by chocolate, then alcohol, then more chocolate.  Very nice palate..

Nice black color,medium sized tan head that lasted for a decent amount of time and then faded leaving little behind.Roasted malt aroma,chocolate and a coffeeish tone to it.Very nice roasted malt taste,bitter sweet chocolate and coffee with the hops showing up nicely towards the end of the tasting.Meium heavy feel to it with an after taste that comes off as coffee and chocolate with a nice presence of hops.I can't believe this is my first Smutty,The liquor store here is loaded with them and i figured i had tried them already,well i did mostly at Old Chicago but looks like never rated any until now.makes me wish i had bought the others when i went to Grand Forks,oh well next time.This is a very good brew and worth having a few more around for later.

Pours out pitch black with a full brown head.  Aroma of rich roasted malt with a strong floral hoppiness(kind of like an espresso).  Big flavor of roasted malt and of coffee. Aftertaste is dry and bittersweet.  This porter is much more harsh than Anchor and Fullers, but it is nearly as enjoyable.

UPDATED: JAN 7, 2004 This my friends, is a top-shelf porter.  Rich, black pour with a caramel head that vanishes quickly.  Huge roasted malt flavor with hints of espresso balanced with a nice hop presence.  Roasted finish that hangs around.  Very nice and highly recommended.  Next to Anchor, one of the top porters.

This is one dark porter with a small head that died quickly. Aroma of espresso and chocolate with dark roasted malt and hops. Has a light yet creamy mouthfeel with a dry finish. Flavor is light, dry and bitter with roasted malt and bitter hops. Decent porter.
user_location: Cape Coral Waterfront Wonderland, Florida, USA

text: Thick, coffee color with a large-bubbled tan head.  Very pronounced aromas of dark roast coffee, bitter chocolate and earthy hops.  Intense coffee and chocolate flavors with a substancial hop backbone.  Not at all silky smooth like Anchor Porter, this is more harsh and aggressive.  Medium bodied with a moderately strong finish.  Nice.
A lightweight imperial stout or robust porter? significant hops, roast, color and full aroma of all that and some dark fruit --hmm raisins and a touch of fruit sour. Body is heavy medium.
Dark, opaque body, with a dark brown head. Aroma is roasty and chocolate. Roasty and bitter-sweet flavors. Full bodied. Pretty good porter.
Very dark beer with a short lived brown head.  Flavors of charcol, tar, licorice and bitter chocolate.  The finish is a long lasting bitter coffee.  Okay I guess.
Nice dark brown, almost opaque, dingy brown head faded quickly.  Fantastic aroma of espresso, chocolate.  Nice mouthfeel.  Flavors of chocolate malts, chocolate liquer.  A tasty surprise.
This is a rather pleasant porter, the nose is very coffe and the taste a little on the sweet side. Nice malty finish.
Very dark and murky porter. Huge taste of alcohol, but it seemed to be appropriate. Slight hop bitterness. I don't know what's up with this picture, but the beer was good.

Heavy sweet roasted aroma hovers above the richly opaque body coated in a thick tan head.  Body is sweet with lots of dark malts and as the name says, is very robust.  Very smooth and flavorful with a sticky chocolatey finish.  One of the best porters I've had.
Bottle:  Roasty, chocolate nose and flavor.  Big.  Very stout-like and a very nice brew.
Very dark, brown head. Thick-looking pour but not as thick as it seems. Roasty, malty and chocolaty aroma and flavor. Bitter finish. A very good porter on all fronts.

Pours a dark black...Nice strong roasted aroma. First sip you get a bitter coffee chocolate mocha taste.  The bitterness wears off as you drink and turns almost sweeter. To me it is a little watered down, could be a little thicker.  Overall not bad at all

A black brew, thick in appearance, but not on the palate.  Thin tan head, with decent lacing.  Aroma is that of roasted grains, with hints of alcohol.  I taste bittersweet chocolate, maybe some coffee in the background.  It finishes with a nice bitterness, that is clean and refreshing.  I like this brewery, at least from my experience with the Brown Ale and this Porter.

Pours a dark opaque black with a dark tan head that's about 1-2 cm.  There is moderate lacing.  Aroma is typical of a porter.  Start is a little bitter and maybe a tad watery, but it ends with the typical roasted coffee flavor.  This is a very good porter, and after just drinking Fuller's London, this is not much of a step down at all.  A solid brew.  From my experience so far, the Smuttynose guys have this stuff figured out.

UPDATED: FEB 5, 2008 Very dark; almost pitch black, with a very small tan head. Nice malty aroma. The flavor is very complex. Theres some coffee and chocolate in there, along with an almost candylike sweetness. Theres also a nice hop finish to it-more bitterness than I expected. A very good porter.
Bottle - think and dark.  Very creamy.  Dark malt and chocolate flavors.  Excellent hop finish to cleanse the palate.

Bottle, dark brown black with tan head. Aroma of malt with plenty of hops, spice, and I caught a whiff of cigarette smoke (?). Nice roasted malt, dark chocolate, medium to full body. Dark bitter finish, with some coffee and chocolate hanging around. A solid and delicious porter that might comments cannot do justice to. Whatcha think, August, a good time to get into porters? Do I need to be warmed up any more than I already am? Great beer.

Dark brown, almost black, and almost opaque like a porter or stout should be.  Taste of bitter chocolate and coffee, more complexity than I expect from a porter, but I would have preferred more dark malt taste.  Good hoppy finish.

Dark dark brown colour with a nice light brown head. Roasted malt smell with a slight aroma of grapes. Flat taste, even with noticable head. Bittering tastes of coffee and bittersweet chocolate. The aftertaste is very bittering and a bit hoppy. A good porter, but I don't think it ranks up there with the best. I bought this 12 ounce bottle from Beers of the World in Rochester, New York.
very deep garnet-red ochre color.  Beautiful balance, complex and crisp, dry, hoppy finish

Decent brown head with dissipates into soe very nice lacing.  Aroma of predominently roasted coffee with a bit of dark chocolate.  Color is basically black with some black cherry red around the edges.  Flavor is smooth with more coffee and malts.  Finish is smooth and a little bitter (nice) from the hops and leaves a lingering bittersweet chocolate and coffe taste.  A good porter and as with all porters, not a beer for the feint of heart.
Thin but foamy head. Taste is malty and chocolaty with hints of coffee. Mild bitter finish. Nice.

Brown/black, nearly opaque. Roasty nose with coffee, licorice, motor oil. Super blast of flavor--licorice and chocolate, medium sweet, with a good bitter hop kick at the end. Like a liquified rich chocolate torte.

Deep brown, almost black, decent head and lace. Nose of seared, roasted barley, coffee, hints of chocolate and more. Medium bodied, lots of black malt character, somewhat burnt flavors, coffee bitterness, an underlying sweetness to balance things out. Dryish finish to round out a very good porter, wish I had taken better notes. Will try again for sure.

UPDATED: DEC 8, 2004 bottle-RBSG-6/28/03.  Definately one of the suprises of the night.  This porter is one of the best around!  Roasted, peat and choclolate aroma.  Very black/dark for a porter-just a hint off of stout-like.  palate was full of roasted notes(malt), some chocolate and a good hop bite on the finish.  maybe Volgon can hook me up with some more of this :)

ReRate-bottle-Its been a long week and I havent had a beer in about a week.  I have been stressed with finals.  I decided to crack this one open from my secret santa box.  Like in the previous rating, it pours very dark for a poerter-about 92% black i would say.  Tan head that leaves a rim around the glass.  Its more viscus than many of the ilk.  Big chocolate aroma followed with hits of burnt char, earthy tones, chocolate chip cookies, and dark malt husks-wonderful!  This beer has a great mouthfeal.  the finish is long with lots of char, chocolate and those malt husks.  This is one under-rated porter. As the beer warmed, the aroma became even better, showing maple surup and a slight butterscotch note (and it wasnt diacytl) it has awesome balance and is a big beer for its style and abv.  I need more smuttynose beers!

Wow is this beer black! Smokey vanilla nose with hints of gourmet coffee and chocolate drink powder.  Bitter chocolate at first sip, incredible body carries waves of flavor. As it dries at the end a wonderful hoppy flavor, an almost IPA like grapefruitty hoppiness, comes through. Awesome porter with one of the sharpest labels I've seen in a long time.

This brew pours a small head of large brown bubbles and an opaque black body.  It has a mild malt coffee aroma.  Initially it is smooth and mild but comes through in the end with a tingly coffee flavored mouthfeel.
Nice thick dark brown liquid that is opaque.  Good rich roasted aroma with hints of happiness.  Rich coffee taste with nice bitters and smooth full mouthfeel.  Lovely finish.  A wonderful beer.

This stuff is primo, absolutley great. Thick heady aroma of chocolate, coffee and blackberries. Liqueur coffee taste comes in thick and strong surrounded by more roasty flavours, magnificently balanced bitterness and a superb body for something of such modest abv.

Good pour, comes out thick like used motor oil. Looks similar too, until hit by light and then you can see reddish/copper hues. Smells of chocolate, coffee, slight hops and faint sweet spices tickle the inside of my nose. The creamy bone white head is appealing, though it dissipates rather quickly. First sip is a pointed attack of the hops on the tip of my tongue. I can then feel the limited bubbles wash over and off of my tongue and leave behind chocolate, toffee and coffee flavors. The aftertaste is dominated by espresso and chocolate, however smoky oak and toasted coconut make their presence known. The aftertaste lingers on until you lift your glass again, seemingly no matter how long you take; this is pleasurable. All in all, the Smuttynose is one of my favourite porters.  I will definitely purchase it again.

(12 oz. bottle) Hmm. Liked this better last time, perhaps I'm spoiled. Or perhaps it's too late in the night for coffee. No matter, this is not a bad beer. Dark and rather biting with a definitely respectable toffee-colored head. Leaves your mouth feeling like the better end of a chocolate mocha.

Significantly bitter, such that you recoil from it initially thinking you're drinking a mislabeled stout/IPA.  Then you just realize that Smuttynose has burned you again.  Although there are some burnt herbal notes, it's all hidden behind the overwhelming hops that play first-team to the malt's JV squad.

This beer rocks!
Pours very dark and thick. Small, creamy, well-tanned head. Not completely diminishing. Decent lacing. Only when held up to very brightl light can one see the lovely, clear ruby hue.
The nose is full of milk chocolate and coffee, vanilla, toasted cashews and allspice. Burnt flowers as well. Very nice!
The flavor is of espresso and bittersweet dark chocolate up front. Moderately bitter on the backside with hints of buttermilk and warm alcohol.
Full-bodied with a silky mouthfeel and soft carbonation. Medium-length, dry, bitter finish with a hint of capuccino and freshly mown grass at the conclusion. A very hearty, well-hopped porter! World Class!
A great porter.  Very rich malty body.  Taste is sweet - chocolate - with a dry finish.

Aroma is roasty liquorice, alcohol.  Like a tropical stout, but a bit dryer.  Colour's alright ... great mouthfeel, wafts about the nose.  Very sweet.  I have an old bottle (December) but still quite good.  Reminds me very much of a tropical stout.
A very good porter. Looks great and tastes great. I'd definitely drink this again...and again...and again... Highly recommended.

I've had several porters so far, and this one was another excellent one.  It's defining characteristic is it's abundance of hops flavor and roasted flavor, with the typical hints of coffee and chocolate.  A winner!

this beer looks absolutely gorgeous in the glass, deep, dark amber-black with a light brown head. aroma is fantastic as well, roasted coffee and chocolate as well as something else i can't place, something sweet. perfectly hopped with a bitter finish. this is an intensely great beer and i applaud the brewers at smuttynose for putting this one together.
A very dark beer in appearance.  but it's wicked creamy and tasted so dam good.  I say, "Yum!"
A little Hoppier than I would prefer,but not too bad.  Nice malts - the smokiness was a little too burnt tasting for my taste.  The beer is better than I make it sound - Robust indeed

Good heavens, this is excellent.  Dry and bitter, this is nearly black, with ruby highlights.  This has every dark ale flavor--fruit, bitterness, chocolate, espresso, toastiness, sweetness--put together wonderfully.  Excellent hop aroma.  Less hop flavor, and more bitterness, than Avery Porter.  One of the best I've had.

Very nicely done.  Dark brown with an antique white head.  Fairly light bodied.  Not thin, but light.  Heavily roasted with a good hop bitterness within.  Hints of chocolate, black coffee, and a touch of fruitiness.  Wonderful stuff.

Pours with an opaque dark brown to black body topped by a thick lasting tan head with lots of lace left on the glass.  Slightly sweet and roasty malt aroma with smokey notes.  Roasty, smokey malt flavor with a slight sweetness and a smokey malt finish. Full bodied, smooth and a touch dry.

Good Porter.  Nearly opaque, but not head and very little lacing.  Decent malty, chocolate aroma.  Tastes like coffee, hot cocoa, hops near the back of the tongue.  Decent body and good maltiness.  Finish is a touch bitter - baker's chocolate.  The most chocolate porter I've had, and that counts Rogue Mocha Porter.

UPDATED: JUL 5, 2004 Had this on draft at the Taphouse in Norfolk. Beautiful color. Pitch black with little head. Smells of hops and coffee. Stronger than I prefer. The hops seem dominant in the aroma. The taste is better with more coffee and cocoa coming out. Finishes bitter with hops being evident. Good beer, though. ***Re-rate. Just had this again on draft at County Grill in Yorktown. Much better than before. Pours a rich blackened brown with ruby edges. Small brown head. Aroma is roasted but sweet with some brown sugar notes. Taste is coffee and dark chocolate. On top of it all, it went well with the pulled-pork BBQ I had. Complimented the meat and sauce spot-on. Finish was a tad bitter but doesn't detract. Time to pump the rating up for this!
This is a good porter!  Very smooth, creamy and easy to drink.  Coffee-esque flavor and a chocolate milk aroma/flavor.  Just a perfect touch of bitterness in the finish.  Impressive.
Dark brown colour, almost like a stout. Thick with little head and a roasted aroma. Initial flavour is very sweet and the roasted aspect comes through in the middle, ending with a hoppy finish.

Very dark pour, with a slight hint of rubyness around the edge.  Head was small and tan, and left light lace on the glass.  Aroma is all roasted - some coffee, chocolate, and hint of caramel.  Flavor starts of quite sweet, with a little caramel in there, middle becomes more roasted coffee-like, with hints of chocolate.  Body is medium, flavor lingers.  This brew goes down very smooth.

Nearly black with a tan head. The nose is roasty and chocolate. The flavor is is roasted and espresso turning to a dry, then bitter finish. Very complex and well balanced. Thanks to Captain Flurries for this one!!

MMMMM, black beer. Brown , short lived head.Grainy, dirty(in a good way)aroma.Big chocolatey, crispy,kinda smokey, burnt grain flavors, nice!Full bodied chewy brew finishes slick and filling.Great lingering dry toasty malt flavors are left behind. Nice brew.

This is an excellent porter.  The nose is all hops and chocolate malt.  The flavour is typical of late cascade and centenial hop additions.  My bottle was slightly oxidized but the overall impression is of a hoppy robust porter with plenty of hop bitterness, flavour and especially in the nose.  Dark brown to almost black, with almost no carbonation and hardly any head retention.
Dark colour.  Deep scent.  Rich coffee scent, not much chocolate. Hazelnut taste.  Nice traditional porter.

Rich Black w/ small coffee coloured head. Roasty, malty nose with w/ notes of chocolate & vanilla. Smooth, silky palette. Starts off nicely w/ complex roasted malt, chocolate, & coffee flavours. Finish is clean, dry, & bitter. Well-balanced porter.
Pours with no head and is very dark brown in color.  Has strong burnt favor, with hints of chocolate and coffee.  If you would have ask me without knowing Id have said it was a stout.

Very dark brown color with some red around the edges. Head is medium and lasting, light brown/tan in color. Aroma is char and cocoa, maybe something else there too. Flavor is well blanced, starting off like a typical porter, malty with some coffee and cocolate tones, solid body through the middle with roasted grains and some smoke, and just enough hoppiness in the finish to keep you wanting another drink. A great beer.
Big dark beer. Robust? I thought I had misread the lable since this had to be a stout. This has got to be the thickest, tastiest porter Ive ever had
This stuff is excellent! Pours a reddish-brown head and a deep dark body. Aroma of cocoa and roasted malt. Beautiful finish... I love Smuttynose! New Hampshire, here I come!!!
Dark matly roasted aroma, very dark with a nice golden brown head. Very nice mix of flavors very delicious. Chocolate hints. Very nice to sip. Robust.
Nice malty, roasted aroma.  Very black appearance. A bit too hoppy for my taste, but otherwise an excellent porter.
UPDATED: DEC 4, 2003 Excellent beer. roasted, burnt malts, chocolate and some very slight fruitiness. Delicious to say the least.

Head is initially small, fizzy, brown, fully diminishing. Body is black (but not opaque).
Aroma is moderately malty (roasted grain, dark chocolate), moderately hoppy (grapefruit).
Flavor is lightly sweet, moderately acidic, lightly bitter.
Finish is moderately acidic, moderately bitter, husky.  Light to medium body, watery texture, lively carbonation, lightly astringent. Lots o grapefruit (which comes out even more as it warms, damn it all) and acidity makes this thin bodied beverage no pleasantry for yours truly.  The aftertaste is like chewing on straw.
Has a very dark brown color and a roasted smell.  Taste is roasted and finishes with moderate bitterness.  Overall porters are not my thing, but this one was not that bad and was better with food.

Very black.  It is very roasty and very bitter.  Notes of coffee and dark chocolate in the flavour.  Amora of freshly ground coffee beans.  Quite a filling beer with a bitter aftertaste that lingers for what seems forever.
Black, absolutely no light coming through.  Thick brown head.  Excellent companion on a cold night.  Tasty.  Lip smacking good.

Malty, roasty, fruity, sweet aroma. Brown-black color, mostly opaque with a decent head which subsided quickly.  Flavor is also largely malty and roasty, with dark chocolate, espresso, toffee and some pleasant, lightly bitter hop flavors infused throughout.  Effervescence on the dryish finish but having a smooth palate. Medium to full bodied.  Some complexity.  Pretty darned tasty.

porter and stout tasting 02:  pours jet black with a big beige head.  aroma of plums, burnt sugar, hops.  starts out very roasty and bitter with a huge peanutty finish.  as the beer warms, it becomes more mellow, smooth, chocolatey, and slightly smoky.  very nice.

opaque black with two fingers of beige head.
vinous nose with a plum and anise character.
lots of subtleties in th taste that lie behind the solid malt. burned plum, wood, sherry, bitter chocolate and asmokines one associates with a nice islay scotch.
luxurious smooth palate.
overal a great beer .this is a porter that aspires to be an imperial stout.
Robust is the word here.  VERY roasty!  Would be a great porter on a cold night.
Not as complex as I would have hoped.  Clean and crisp with plenty of malt flavor , but lacking bitterness and durability.  Needs a little more fine tuning.
Looks great - the head is like the top of a cappuncino.  Flavours are quite subtle but very pleasant.  A nice rounded porter.

Great nearly pitch-black colour with small but nicely tan head. Whiffs of coffee and chocolate that extend from the aroma into the flavour. Goes down smooth and easy with a hint of bitterness sliding into the finish. Yummy!

Nothing porraceous about this one!  Classic excellent porter.  Colored head, bit of it retained, with lovely iced coffee aroma and a rich flavor that lasts all the way.  All-in-all, this beer struck very close to my preferred beer in almost all the dimensions.
Complex roasted coffe ground flavours with some sweetness to balance.

UPDATED: MAY 19, 2003 ruby-blackish hue. Aroma of mocha, vanilla, some fruit. nice beige head.  Rich malts, medium bodied.  Hops kick in with some citrus in the finish along with espresso and dark chocolate.  A very nicely balanced brew, complex and rich.  Robust it is, most definately. An excellant porter.

really black, with a nice tan head. very roasty and rich, but not too thick. lots of grapefruity hops and assorted vegetablenesses like asparagus and lemon mint. vanilla pops up too. whatever, its complex, very drinkable, very tasty, and i want to try it sober some time.

UPDATED: AUG 22, 2003 Dark brown,near black. Nice,creamy,tan head.  Big roasty,espresso,cocoa,and juicy hops in aroma. Bottle Conditioned??      Small,short lived,and khaki head. Flavors are aimed in different directions than aroma.Espresso like palate,with a Malty, and slightly bitter finish.As it warms the bittersweet flavor intensifies and the maltiness in the finish takes over.Robust?I hope to tell ya!Haven't had many porters besides taddy,but I'm betting this is one of the better ones.Good call,Mittenstein.Thanks man!!
Maybe Im partial to it because its from my home state but....its really good.

Very dark brown in color. Pours with medium-sized head, tightly carbonated, very dark tan in color. Medium strength nose, bakers chocolate and tangy hops. Flavors of roasted cofee and dark/bittersweet chocolate ... slight touch of hops.

Overall a solid beer - not the biggest of flavors, but delicious indeed!
very dark colour, fine head, deeply complex aroma: blackcurrant, plum, vanilla, coffee and cinnamon; sweet and oily with a long bitter finish - simply wonderful !

UPDATED: AUG 9, 2003 Pours with a nearly opaque dullness. Not so dark foam with excellent stickiness. There is so much going on in this Imperial stout knock-off aroma; wine notes, black cherry/concord grape combo, dark fruits, peanuts, currants, cocoa, coffee bean, citric hops, roasted grain, port wine, chocolate, and whispers of alcohol. Super creamy texture and low carbonation with dryish cocoa characteristics. Slightly acidic, charred, and bitter finish. Flavors are complex, but not like the aroma, with coffee being the main theme. The alcohol is rather warming for being a modest 5.7. The complexity approaches a Baltic Porter, but the medium body and abv keep it from being such. Nevertheless, a long and overdue favorite.
user_location: Blue Ridge Mountains, North Carolina, USA

text: UPDATED: MAR 22, 2012 A seductive milk coffee nose is spiced with citrusy hops...Disparate fieldberries grow amongst the coffee plantation...Intelligent roastiness coats the chocolate syrup...Astounding hop complexity of strong grassy bitterness evolving into resins and citrus...There is an intense attempt at balance in the rich yet drinkable mouthfeel...A fantastic porter with a larger flavor profile than the stronger Arcadia London Porter, for example...

Dark, blackish thick brew with a hint of red and smallish head; aroma of cocoa, burnt wood -- nice but on the weak side.  Flavor starts out sweet and chocolaty, but with some strong hoppiness coming in leading to a very dry finish.  Robust porters are not my favorite style by any means, but this is a very good example.  Excellent body.
deep brown/black body.  roasty-chocolate flavor, dry finish.  excellent porter.

Deep dark brown, the head large, chocolate, the lace lies in sheets upon the glass. Nose is caramel, roasted grains, sweet, and the beer starts sweet, the top light, the finish is lightly carbonated. Also somewhat dry, nice hop presence, and a quite quaffable beer.
Jbrus is right. The chocolate is not overdone, which can happen easily, slight licorice, medium body. A very slight otherworldly sweetness as it warms. Very nice. Hoppy finish, but just a bit.
user_location: Łódż, Warsaw, Poland; Michigan, Ohio, USA

text: Very rich, mellow. An almost perfect palate and excellent flavor to boot. Well Done.

[email protected]/* <![CDATA[ */!function(t,e,r,n,c,a,p){try{t=document.currentScript||function(){for(t=document.getElementsByTagName('script'),e=t.length;e--;)if(t[e].getAttribute('data-cfhash'))return t[e]}();if(t&&(c=t.previousSibling)){p=t.parentNode;if(a=c.getAttribute('data-cfemail')){for(e='',r='0x'+a.substr(0,2)|0,n=2;a.length-n;n+=2)e+='%'+('0'+('0x'+a.substr(n,2)^r).toString(16)).slice(-2);p.replaceChild(document.createTextNode(decodeURIComponent(e)),c)}p.removeChild(t)}}catch(u){}}()/* ]]> */, May 02, 4.5: Man, I used to think (years ago) that all American beers were like Budweiser and Miller. How wrong could I be? This beer is almost perfect. Light roasted, licorice, hint of chocolate aroma. Black color, light brown frothy/creamy firm head, perfect lace. Sweet, chocolate and all other stuff a porter should have. Moderate full. Nice roasted, licorice finish.
Mmmm...roasted, creamy, almost vanilla-like nose. Stout-like in color-- and in body.  Wonderful full-roastedness and plenty of hop finish.  A top notch porter.

Small, but thick and chocolatey colored head.  Smells a little like a french roast with alcohol.  Strong alcohol flavor, which is about all that comes through.  Has some roasted maltiness.  Burns as it goes down.
Roasty/chocolate aroma that carries over really well in the flavor.  Bit of bitterness in the aftertaste makes this beer finish great.
Excellent porter, nice flavors of coffee, burnt malts.  Its sweet, rich, and malty.  Balanced very niceley by an excellnt hops presence.

ecent aroma if you talk about porters . Personally not my favourite . Typical porter like apperance , nothing special . Flavour dark coffe (a la robust ?)... To bitter but who am I ... pilsener lover so .... 11/20 for trying and nice aroma .
Mild liquorice scent. Mahogany colour, huge coffee head,(short lived) Bitter coffee taste, chocolate and liquorice also. Thick, oily Extra good.
Not much in the way of aroma, but has a nice full roasted flavor to it.  I am not a big fan of porters, but this is one I could enjoy.

UPDATED: JAN 11, 2004 3/27/02 re-rate:  This beer is great.  A little more hops kicks in at the beginning and end than our UK friends would like, but it works for me.  More chocolate that I've gotten from a non-chocolate beer.  (+0.1) First rating:  This beer is great!  Smooth and malty.Earlier Rating: 11/25/2001 Total Score: 3.5Big coffee taste.  Had a strange taste that seemed to disappear half way through the glass.

Blacker than the river Styx with a golden-brown quickly diminishing head.  From the smell and initial tastes I thought this would be brutally bitter, but as you continue to drink and let it warm up a bit, it has a pleasing bittersweet mocha flavour and hoppy scent. Heavy, slick mouthfeel and rich aftertaste.

Nice chocolatey aroma.  Color is nice and dark, especially the caramel-colored head.  Taste was nice with touches of chocolate and coffee, maybe too much coffee though.  I thought the aftertaste was almost perfect, as it was not too overpowering.  Smooth on the way down and better when allowed to warm a bit.
Black enough for me to call it opaque.  Perfect lasting head, firm and beige-brown.  Toasty nose with super, super flavour.  Wow!  Quite dry with a long, long aftertaste.  Super beer!

Totally nontransparent, Nice beige head.
Peanuts and blue cheese notes in the aroma (I find blue cheese notes to be very common in american dark beers)
Coffee and chocolate in the taste, very full bodied.
And then it hits you like an expresstrain.
The bitterness that slowly evolves into a perfect finish of dark chocolate.
All I can say is YIHAA!!!!!
Very black - nearly intransparent. Nicely softly malty, and full bodied. Very roasty, salty with notes of dark chocolate. Well balanced with a bitter finish. This is an outstanding porter!

Black, tan foamy head.  A great nose of coffee and fruit and some hops.  Great coffee tastes, some licorice-like hop tastes.  Perfect carbo, nice fruity palate.  This is a great porter.  I dont know if Ive had a bad Smuttynose product.

Blackened cherrywood colour with a finger of foam; though hampered by a cold Ive got some good quality roast grains in the aroma, some black rye bread, wood, vanilla and a little bit of cocoa.  Palate-wise this is smooth, sweet, and filling - the body is rich enough to carry through.  Sweet malts, demerara, and chocolate chip cookie dough lead the way, but the beer turns drier, roastier, and hoppier in the finish.  I love the way the two elements are balanced off of each other.  Very enjoyable - a winter beer that you can drink in quantity.  Thanks to Jeffrey at Esprit for calling in the favours to bring this to Toronto.

What a wonderful beer!!!

Cheers!
No Lactoincephalitis here. But then again, I got a sample that was fresh & direct from the brewery. I found it rich, chocolatey, bitter, full-bodied and burnt... Good Stuff!

Interestingly, my sample was also
badly contaminated with lactobacillis.
Badly soured.  Other: nice dark, almost
black color.  Beneath the souring lurked
what seemed to be a pretty good roasty
porter.
Need to re-rate, strong indication of being infected by lacto-bacillus.  Very sour.  Hoppy aroma.
